revisions:
[{'created': '2013-05-23 12:41:57.000000000', 'message': 'Added insecure SSL support to quantum api

Get OPENSTACK_SSL_NO_VERIFY value from settings.
Pass it to quantum client on initialization.

Fixes Bug 1183273

Change-Id: Ic52a103952a6c46a3e5918a84e362f2491ecee16
'}]
commit_message:
Added insecure SSL support to quantum api

Get OPENSTACK_SSL_NO_VERIFY value from settings.
Pass it to quantum client on initialization.

Fixes Bug 1183273

Change-Id: Ic52a103952a6c46a3e5918a84e362f2491ecee16

commit_message:
Adding Domain CRUD in Admin Dashboard.

Add basic support for CRUD on Domain for admin users.

This feature is only exposed if the user explicitly set
the OPENSTACK_KEYSTONE_MULTIDOMAIN_SUPPORT to True and
keystone supports V3.

Creating projects, users and groups on a specific domain
will be covered separately on domain-context blueprint.

Implements blueprint admin-domain-crud

Change-Id: If2684331776166dd9579716deebca100770a5ce0

revisions:
[{'created': '2013-05-23 21:15:38.000000000', 'message': 'Fixed format string vulnerability in reddwarf call to OpenstackException handler

Exception messages from the mysql extension which may contain user input are
now properly escaped. This fixes any chance of a format string vulnerability.

Fixed bug: 1177936

Change-Id: I7762f605f08a7e7b5f884ee4062aa16e4048f928
'}]
commit_message:
Fixed format string vulnerability in reddwarf call to OpenstackException handler

Exception messages from the mysql extension which may contain user input are
now properly escaped. This fixes any chance of a format string vulnerability.

Fixed bug: 1177936

Change-Id: I7762f605f08a7e7b5f884ee4062aa16e4048f928

revisions:
[{'created': '2013-05-23 19:43:43.000000000', 'message': "Fix ownership transfer when cloning with SolidFire

When cloning a volume with SolidFire driver, the owner of
the cloned volume is not set correctly in SolidFire when there is
a transfer of ownership.

This results in inconsistent states where the cloned volume
is owned by the new tenant in Cinder but SolidFire thinks it is still
owned by the original volume's tenant.

This patch adds the newAccountID parameter to all CloneVolume calls.

If the cloned volume is owned by the same tenant, newAccountID will
be set to the same value as the original SolidFire volume. There
will be no change of ownership done by the cloning process in SolidFire.

If the cloned volume should be owned by a different tenant, newAccountID
will be set to the appropriate SolidFire account corresponding
to the new tenant. If the SolidFire account does not exist already,
it will be created.

Fixes: bug #1183521
Change-Id: I622ca2962478298e3e0c5a26866e39919805075f
"}]
commit_message:
Fix ownership transfer when cloning with SolidFire

When cloning a volume with SolidFire driver, the owner of
the cloned volume is not set correctly in SolidFire when there is
a transfer of ownership.

This results in inconsistent states where the cloned volume
is owned by the new tenant in Cinder but SolidFire thinks it is still
owned by the original volume's tenant.

This patch adds the newAccountID parameter to all CloneVolume calls.

If the cloned volume is owned by the same tenant, newAccountID will
be set to the same value as the original SolidFire volume. There
will be no change of ownership done by the cloning process in SolidFire.

If the cloned volume should be owned by a different tenant, newAccountID
will be set to the appropriate SolidFire account corresponding
to the new tenant. If the SolidFire account does not exist already,
it will be created.

Fixes: bug #1183521
Change-Id: I622ca2962478298e3e0c5a26866e39919805075f

commit_message:
Guard against content being None

`content` can be passed in as None, so we need to set it to the empty
list if that occurs.

This also fixes the bad-practice of using a mutable data-type as a
default argument.

Fixes bug 1163598

Change-Id: Ie991c9452a21cfb036d3955a094ec345805d63d1
(cherry picked from commit 782bab8dd2930a4479d84dcb906321313d06b25b)

commit_message:
nova coverage creates lots of empty folders

With nova coverage extension disabled as a default behaviour,
nova will create lots of empty folders under /tmp folder. And also
with each time the nova service reboot, it will create a new
directory with name like nova_coverage_*. There will be number of
the empty folders accumulated.

Patch-Set 3: Rebase for merging code
Fixes: bug 1169005

Conflicts:
	nova/api/openstack/compute/contrib/coverage_ext.py

Change-Id: I26d1037eb66d781ac6ef6b600cca04a709bff3f7
(cherry picked from commit b6e072a84a31eca1f7d7c44117327c5042e153c2)

revisions:
[{'created': '2013-05-10 02:15:23.000000000', 'message': 'Fix zookeeper import and tests

Import zookeeper.membership rather than zookeeper.membersip.
Also fixed some issues with setting up the tests for the zookeeper
servicegroup driver.  Config options were not being set before
initializing the driver leading to failures.

There is no added test for this because the bug is indistinguishable
from not having the zookeeper python modules installed, which leads to
skipping these servicegroup tests.

Bug 1177776

Change-Id: Idd6dca2e03169399b930cc1fc1a85636497cb0b5
(cherry picked from commit 4a2845095c0e35336c60836050ca11c71898fb8c)
'}]
commit_message:
Fix zookeeper import and tests

Import zookeeper.membership rather than zookeeper.membersip.
Also fixed some issues with setting up the tests for the zookeeper
servicegroup driver.  Config options were not being set before
initializing the driver leading to failures.

There is no added test for this because the bug is indistinguishable
from not having the zookeeper python modules installed, which leads to
skipping these servicegroup tests.

Bug 1177776

Change-Id: Idd6dca2e03169399b930cc1fc1a85636497cb0b5
(cherry picked from commit 4a2845095c0e35336c60836050ca11c71898fb8c)

So, I'm going to ask that you provide unit tests of your new code using this example spec/registration_spec.rb:

The above shows how to use the :step_into argument to the ChefSpec.Runner and validate that a call to the appropriate keystone CLI command was run.

[{'created': '2013-05-20 19:55:52.000000000', 'message': 'A complete rewrite of this LWRP

The previous LWRP used HTTP/S to interrogate and modify
opentstack-identity data. As the API is somewhat of a moving target,
migrate the register provider to include everything it had previously,
combine that with the credentials provider, and rework all the
identity calls to use the Identity (keystone) CLI tools.

This logic follows the same logic that was found in the previous
provider. In fact, code was recycled where appropriate - much of the
same log messages and branch logic remain.

The two functions that power this methodology are:
identity_command - calls the identity client with the parameters
supplied and returns stdout upon success. Upon failure, raise a
RuntimeException with the message being stderr.
identity_uuid - wrapper around identity_command that given a type
of resource to interrogate and an index for the data returned, will
provide the UUID of the target or nil if not found. Upon error, this
function will bubble up an exception.

Bumping the openstack-common dependency to 0.2.1.

All tests pass.

Change-Id: I4230f047ee9c26d076ad14c48afac73f0e92c4ad

commit_message:
A complete rewrite of this LWRP

The previous LWRP used HTTP/S to interrogate and modify
opentstack-identity data. As the API is somewhat of a moving target,
migrate the register provider to include everything it had previously,
combine that with the credentials provider, and rework all the
identity calls to use the Identity (keystone) CLI tools.

This logic follows the same logic that was found in the previous
provider. In fact, code was recycled where appropriate - much of the
same log messages and branch logic remain.

The two functions that power this methodology are:
identity_command - calls the identity client with the parameters
supplied and returns stdout upon success. Upon failure, raise a
RuntimeException with the message being stderr.
identity_uuid - wrapper around identity_command that given a type
of resource to interrogate and an index for the data returned, will
provide the UUID of the target or nil if not found. Upon error, this
function will bubble up an exception.

These changes are accompanied by some spec tests to test the various
function of the LWRP itself.

Bumping the openstack-common dependency to 0.2.1.

All tests pass.

Change-Id: I4230f047ee9c26d076ad14c48afac73f0e92c4ad

commit_message:
Changed _create_volume()'s signature

So that it now accepts a 'attach_status' param.

subject: remove fauxhai from Gemfile and update Gemfile.lock
reviewers: [{'_account_id': 3, 'name': 'Jenkins', 'username': 'jenkins'}, {'_account_id': 7, 'name': 'Jay Pipes', 'email': 'jaypipes@gmail.com', 'username': 'jaypipes'}, {'_account_id': 216, 'name': 'John Dewey', 'email': 'john@dewey.ws', 'username': 'retr0h'}, {'_account_id': 2340, 'name': 'Ionut Artarisi', 'email': 'iartarisi@suse.cz', 'username': 'mapleoin'}, {'_account_id': 5300, 'name': 'Sean Gallagher', 'email': 'sean@torandu.org', 'username': 'torandu'}, {'_account_id': 7220, 'name': 'Abel Lopez', 'username': 'alop', 'inactive': True}]
messages:
[{'account_id': 3, 'date': '2013-05-22 10:46:07.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Works for me

Build succeeded.

- http://logs.openstack.org/30075/1/check/gate-cookbook-openstack-identity-chef-lint/20 : SUCCESS in 3m 53s
- http://logs.openstack.org/30075/1/check/gate-cookbook-openstack-identity-chef-unit/20 : SUCCESS in 4m 09s
'}, {'account_id': 5300, 'date': '2013-05-22 17:47:13.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1: I would prefer that you didn't merge this

Gemfile.lock *should* be included in the project to ensure correct versions of dependencies. The only time you should ignore a Gemfile.lock is if you are writing a gem.

Ref to this post on SO for more info
http://stackoverflow.com/questions/4151495/should-gemfile-lock-be-included-in-gitignore"}, {'account_id': 216, 'date': '2013-05-22 21:50:03.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1: I would prefer that you didn't merge this

Agree with Sean's assessment."}, {'account_id': 2340, 'date': '2013-05-23 09:10:39.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 2.'}, {'account_id': 2340, 'date': '2013-05-23 09:11:31.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2:

Ok, then. I've changed this patch to update the Gemfile.lock file instead of removing it.

I've submitted in the same change to keep the discussion in one place."}, {'account_id': 3, 'date': '2013-05-23 09:15:46.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2: Works for me

Build succeeded.

- http://logs.openstack.org/30075/2/check/gate-cookbook-openstack-identity-chef-lint/67 : SUCCESS in 3m 21s
- http://logs.openstack.org/30075/2/check/gate-cookbook-openstack-identity-chef-unit/67 : SUCCESS in 3m 31s
'}, {'account_id': 7220, 'date': '2013-05-23 16:12:42.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2: Looks good to me, but someone else must approve

'}, {'account_id': 5300, 'date': '2013-05-23 16:13:26.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2: I would prefer that you didn't merge this

Hi Ionut.
IMO we should remove fauxhai from Gemfile altogether. It's not a direct dependency, but rather a dependency of chefspec. To keep things flexible, we should let chefspec drive the versions of its dependencies and not set them explicitly in Gemfile (unless there's a valid reason to do that, of course).

What I recommend:
1- Remove fauxhai from Gemfile
2- Ensure Gemfile has: gem "chefspec", "~> 1.2.0"
3- bundle install
4- Examine the diff. Gemfile.lock should include fauxhai (1.1.0).
5- Commit both Gemfile and Gemfile.lock (there should be changes to both files)
6- Update the change request

Apologies that I missed your prev change request for Gemfile! I wish that I could have given you this feedback sooner.

Regards,
Sean'}, {'account_id': 2340, 'date': '2013-05-23 16:20:37.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 3.'}, {'account_id': 2340, 'date': '2013-05-23 16:22:33.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 3:

Agh, thanks Sean!

It makes a lot of sense to not bind the fauxhai version and I didn't want to do that originally, but I got confused in thinking that chefspec would pull in an older version of fauxhai automatically which it wouldn't of course."}, {'account_id': 3, 'date': '2013-05-23 16:24:37.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3: Works for me

Build succeeded.

- http://logs.openstack.org/30075/3/check/gate-cookbook-openstack-identity-chef-lint/68 : SUCCESS in 3m 47s
- http://logs.openstack.org/30075/3/check/gate-cookbook-openstack-identity-chef-unit/68 : SUCCESS in 3m 49s
'}, {'account_id': 5300, 'date': '2013-05-23 17:28:13.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3: Looks good to me, but someone else must approve

Looks great! Thanks for making the changes.'}, {'account_id': 7, 'date': '2013-05-23 17:48:39.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3: Looks good to me (core reviewer)

thx for your patience, Inout! lgtm.'}, {'account_id': 216, 'date': '2013-05-23 18:50:54.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3: Looks good to me (core reviewer); Approved

'}, {'account_id': 3, 'date': '2013-05-23 18:50:57.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3: No score

http://status.openstack.org/zuul/'}, {'account_id': 3, 'date': '2013-05-23 18:56:12.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3: Verified

@Michael / @Dan - with using the examples Dan gave, will mox enforce the order that those methods are called in or just that they are called (or not) and how they behave if called?  Otherwise I agree, that's one of the reasons I've avoided diving into mox is because of the strictness it sounds like it places on the unit tests, i.e. methods must be called in order. I liked using JMock with Java because you could setup expectations of what would happen when a method was called, and you could enforce consecutive order of calls, but it was not mandatory. The problem we run into a lot it seems is the UT is so tightly coupled to the source code that when the source code changes, my test isn't really performing regression if it breaks because of that coupling, and I'm essentially put into dual maintenance."}, {'account_id': 4393, 'date': '2013-05-23 13:30:05.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2:

Matt, yes it will enforce the order, and I see that as a benefit, not the converse :)

There are certainly places where stubs are warranted, but not when you use them merely to make sure something gets called, IMHO.'}, {'account_id': 6873, 'date': '2013-05-23 13:31:43.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 3.'}, {'account_id': 6873, 'date': '2013-05-23 13:34:22.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3:

commit_message:
Fix UnboundLocalError in powervm lvm cleanup code

During spawn, if a local volume for the backing block device fails to
be created, the cleanup operation for the volume can fail with a
"UnboundLocalError: local variable 'disk_name' referenced before
assignment" error.

The fix is to assign to disk_name earlier and check for None before
running cleanup.

This patch also adds tests to cover the failure case.

Fixes bug 1180955

Change-Id: I0f32df1586d7bd87eccb674fec2a9597b1ce351d

subject: Fix: getting the right screen name in stop-base
messages:
[{'account_id': 2750, 'date': '2013-05-22 12:39:30.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1: I would prefer that you didn't merge this

(1 inline comment)

"}, {'account_id': 2750, 'date': '2013-05-22 12:40:24.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

I think we should be better than a sleep, instead have something that actually checks to make sure the services are down.'}, {'account_id': 3, 'date': '2013-05-22 12:49:36.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Works for me

Build succeeded.

- http://logs.openstack.org/30097/1/check/gate-noop/1783 : SUCCESS in 0s
- http://logs.openstack.org/30097/1/check/gate-grenade-devstack-vm/5206 : SUCCESS in 13m 45s (non-voting)
'}, {'account_id': 2976, 'date': '2013-05-22 14:21:42.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

The sleep is to guarantee time to kill all the process in the screen. 
The script checks after that if the services are up, as you mentioned. If some of them are, it returns an error and stops. I believe the sleep here guarantee that not to happen, although I agree that might not be the most performatic way to do it.'}, {'account_id': 2750, 'date': '2013-05-22 19:08:26.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

I'm more concerned that it's an unreliable race. We should make some tight loop that checks for the services to be down every second for 30 seconds or something to make sure we don't set a sleep value that is good on some machines but not others."}, {'account_id': 970, 'date': '2013-05-22 21:42:06.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

That sleep is the flip side of the screen startup problem we have in DevStack's screen_it() function.

If this is causing immediate pain we should let it in.  Either way I think our long-term move needs to be to switch to using USE_SCREEN=False in Grenade's DevStack runs."}, {'account_id': 2750, 'date': '2013-05-22 22:37:10.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1: Looks good to me (core reviewer)

ok, I'll budge for now"}, {'account_id': 970, 'date': '2013-05-23 16:50:41.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1: Looks good to me (core reviewer); Approved

I've filed https://bugs.launchpad.net/grenade/+bug/1183449 to track converting Grenade to USE_SCREEN=False."}, {'account_id': 3, 'date': '2013-05-23 16:50:42.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: No score

Starting gate jobs.
http://status.openstack.org/zuul/'}, {'account_id': 3, 'date': '2013-05-23 16:51:16.000000000', 'content': 'Change has been successfully merged into the git repository.'}, {'account_id': 3, 'date': '2013-05-23 16:51:16.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Verified

commit_message:
Improvements in csv export for usage data

Added a csv writer using the 'csv' library to format
properly exported data - escaping, encoding etc.
Added a HttpResponse-based class to handle csv generation
Added translation for the CSV columns and template.
Improved consistency for exported data - now passing project name
instead of project id for csv export. Also added both project name/id
in the header of a project usage export.

Fix bug #1158383

Renamed few occurencies of 'tenant' to project.

Also added a new 'project' in nova_data.py, which required
some refactoring of few tests, that didn't consider the current project
for project-based calls.

Note: I've added a StreamingHttpResponse example,
which is introduced in Django 1.5+ and  being advised in the ticket.
However, my opinion is that at the moment we don't need this - it is
too complicated for the current usage.

Change-Id: Ic00626b273921fa5c6c89704b3a9e08b252aaeb0

commit_message:
xenapi: Moving tests under tests/virt/xenapi/

We have both a tests/xenapi/ and a tests/virt/xenapi/ directory which
is confusing. This patch standardizes on tests/virt/xenapi/ which
matches the nova/ directory layout.

Change-Id: I324a4730e2477aa1863b17c7ea404ce2932a681c

commit_message:
xenapi: Disable VDI size check when root_gb=0

Nova uses root_gb=0 to indicate that we should use the image as-is without
trying to resize the root disk. Currently the xenapi virt-driver doesn't
properly implement this behavior.

This patch gets us a step closer by disabling the VDI size check when
root_gb=0. We still need to ensure that the disk-resize code handle root_gb=0
as well.

References bug 1155113

Change-Id: If91963e079e197a1315c48b8643f3419b42b0b2c

commit_message:
Remove ImageTooLarge exception

InstanceTypeDiskTooSmall and ImageTooLarge are really two sides of the same
coin; an image is larger than the root_gb of the instance_type. Rather than
have two exceptions for this, this patch consolidates down to just
InstanceTypeDiskTooSmall.

Change-Id: I401205072c111a960beb2932c6c1889141ae03c3

commit_message:
Move ImageTooLarge check to Compute API

The existing ImageTooLarge check is in the compute manager, meaning that a
validation error puts the instance into an ERROR state without the ability to
communicate the fault back to the user.

This patch moves the check to the API where we can return the appropriate
error to the user.

Change-Id: I2183449351e3b70f98d0552ea247184a3641d85a

commit_message:
Move attributes to [openstack][compute] namespace.

As we have decided to move all cookbooks to use the
[openstack][<service>] attribute namespace convention, move compute
to fit this model.

Change-Id: Ibc19fd5326af0340ea1e3788aa7d2701e187f3a0

'}, {'account_id': 6530, 'date': '2013-05-18 04:00:38.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1: I would prefer that you didn't merge this

I have considered this change previously and I have code that will address this.  I can submit a change tomorrow for it.

The reason I do not like this is that this code is duplicated in each of the providers. Similarly, this is the type of thing that is useful beyond the scope of this identity cookbook, and therefore I think this belongs in openstack-common.

My replacement function is intended to land in the uri library in the Openstack module and be sensible about joining URI paths (ie. stripping extraneous slashes, etc.)"}, {'account_id': 7, 'date': '2013-05-18 15:58:49.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

I don't have too strong opinions on the joining of paths and cleaning up of this function -- our goal is to replace the HTTP direct calls in the openstack-identity resource providers with calls to python-keystoneclient's CLI tool instead, which will dramatically reduce the amount of code in there, including the manual munging of URI paths."}, {'account_id': 6530, 'date': '2013-05-18 16:47:20.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: No score

Jay, love hearing that we are moving to using the python clients.  That should make things a lot easier!

With regard to this change, I have submitted my 2 changes for review:
https://review.openstack.org/#/c/29659/
and
https://review.openstack.org/#/c/29663/

These changes had already been done on one of my former branches, so no lost cycles there.'}, {'account_id': 216, 'date': '2013-05-18 17:23:53.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

This cleanup is fine.  However, this LWRP should really use the python-keystoneclient CLI tool as Jay stated.'}, {'account_id': 2340, 'date': '2013-05-22 10:50:05.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 2.'}, {'account_id': 2340, 'date': '2013-05-22 10:51:16.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 3.'}, {'account_id': 3, 'date': '2013-05-22 10:58:18.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 3: Doesn't seem to work

revisions:
[{'created': '2013-05-20 23:32:20.000000000', 'message': 'Add requirement for PBR level >=0.5.10,<0.6

There is a bug in PBR that I discovered while doing Cinder development
on Havana.  It causes the migrate.cfg file to not be properly
setup in /usr/lib/python2.X/site-packages/cinder/db/sqlalchemy/migrate_repo
which results in the database not being properly populated.  That was
seen with pbr==0.5.8.

This change is proposing making a more specific requirement of pbr>=0.5.10 as
the problem encountered with 0.5.8 is resolved with 0.5.10 and later
versions of PBR.

Change-Id: I4ee527331f65751621d0763910d48f963697bbd2
fixes: bug 1182203
'}, {'created': '2013-05-20 23:56:07.000000000', 'message': 'Add requirement for PBR level >=0.5.10,<0.6

There is a bug in PBR that I discovered while doing Cinder development
on Havana.  It causes the migrate.cfg file to not be properly
setup in /usr/lib/python2.X/site-packages/cinder/db/sqlalchemy/migrate_repo
which results in the database not being properly populated.  That was
seen with pbr==0.5.8.

This change is proposing making a more specific requirement of pbr>=0.5.10 as
the problem encountered with 0.5.8 is resolved with 0.5.10 and later
versions of PBR.

Change-Id: I4ee527331f65751621d0763910d48f963697bbd2
fixes: bug 1182203
'}]
commit_message:
Add requirement for PBR level >=0.5.10,<0.6

There is a bug in PBR that I discovered while doing Cinder development
on Havana.  It causes the migrate.cfg file to not be properly
setup in /usr/lib/python2.X/site-packages/cinder/db/sqlalchemy/migrate_repo
which results in the database not being properly populated.  That was
seen with pbr==0.5.8.

This change is proposing making a more specific requirement of pbr>=0.5.10 as
the problem encountered with 0.5.8 is resolved with 0.5.10 and later
versions of PBR.

Change-Id: I4ee527331f65751621d0763910d48f963697bbd2
fixes: bug 1182203

[{'created': '2013-05-22 18:38:42.000000000', 'message': "Don't require flat_inferface.

The nova default for flat_interface is None but our puppet modules
currently require it to be set. This patch updates the network/flat
module so that it defaults to undef thus making it possible to use
nova::network w/ flat networking when no flat_interface(private_interface)
is defined.

Change-Id: I7167b76f95f3fe9a1ad208223def9597e56a4ecc
"}, {'created': '2013-05-23 14:44:21.000000000', 'message': "Don't require flat_inferface.

The nova default for flat_interface is None but our puppet modules
currently require it to be set. This patch updates the network/flat
module so that it defaults to undef thus making it possible to use
nova::network w/ flat networking when no flat_interface(private_interface)
is defined.

Change-Id: I7167b76f95f3fe9a1ad208223def9597e56a4ecc
"}]
commit_message:
Don't require flat_inferface.

The nova default for flat_interface is None but our puppet modules
currently require it to be set. This patch updates the network/flat
module so that it defaults to undef thus making it possible to use
nova::network w/ flat networking when no flat_interface(private_interface)
is defined.

Change-Id: I7167b76f95f3fe9a1ad208223def9597e56a4ecc

commit_message:
Stop creating a new db IMPL for every request.

IMPL should be created once, at module load, not once for every
get_instance() call.

Change-Id: Ib2c7888cf9fe074891984e67af83526c994d2e2e

commit_message:
Satisfy flake8 import rules F401 and F403

- Removed unused imports
- Ignore wildcard and unused imports from core modules (and avoid
  wildcard imports otherwise) to __init__ modules

Change-Id: Ie2e5f61ae37481f5d248788cfd83dc92ffddbd91

revisions:
[{'created': '2013-05-23 12:39:08.000000000', 'message': 'Add the service_state into test_schedule_happy_day.

Since the fake filter scheduler does not update the capabilities, the sevice
states remains empty. To avoid the None value for free_capacity_gb, we set the
host_manager to a fake host manager with a list of service states.

Fixed Bug 1171906.

Change-Id: I359ea6952392cc5e6b8eff513f3ca4d8161a30e3
'}]
commit_message:
Add the service_state into test_schedule_happy_day.

Since the fake filter scheduler does not update the capabilities, the sevice
states remains empty. To avoid the None value for free_capacity_gb, we set the
host_manager to a fake host manager with a list of service states.

Fixed Bug 1171906.

Change-Id: I359ea6952392cc5e6b8eff513f3ca4d8161a30e3

commit_message:
Reimplement reserve_nodes and release_nodes.

Implement these two methods based on a host, rather than based on
an instance_uuid.

Also adds some doc strings to db/api.

Part of bp:ironic-manager

Change-Id: I41ddcec90f4dc2b22712cdb069a3d4626fb7c19d

commit_message:
Change 'nodes' to use more driver-specific JSON.

Change the 'nodes' table to be more generic, allowing
drivers to be more flexible in the informatin they track.

Also adds a minimalistic 'chassis' table, and a FK pointing
from 'nodes' to 'chassis'.

Part of bp:ironic-manager

Change-Id: I0022841f31fdb3aa40883a0403a8427bd9a09a00

issues on RedHat distributions. This should allow this

commit_message:
Soft link /usr/bin/pip (fix xenapi install).

Updates the xenserver.pp manifest to work around pip install
issues on RedHat distributions. This should allow this
manifest to run on older puppet versions (2.7 for example)

Fixes LP Bug #1183060.

Change-Id: If65ae6ac0d848316b0533d6571755f520f8b14b4

Sahdev,
Just want to be sure you noticed the following on openstack-dev mailing list, so any solution developed does not need to be revisited too soon!

and before that, 2 little comments:
1) do we really need the variable?
_set_default_domain = True
On system init, create one if none exists (either from LDAP backend that stores it or does not store it).

That is  get domain path and get-domain-list paths would both be covered.

Secondly, if you want to keep current impl, more efficient:

domains = self.domain.get_all()
for domain in domains:
    if domain.get('id') == CONF.identity.default_domain_id:
        return domains
domains.insert(0, self.domain.get_default_domain())
return domains

===============
Aaron Knister <aaron.knister@gmail.com> ..
Hi Brad,

FWIW-- I'm using AD as the LDAP backend and was using the msSFU30NisDomain attribute for the domain_id mapping. I'm now leveraging some OpenLDAP overlay magic instead, but I digress. I could see value for us in being able to leverage a domain_id stored in LDAP although admittedly we aren't yet using it. Could option 1 be implemented but be configurable? Something like "domains_enabled"? If disabled then the behavior in the default domain is used for all operations, if enabled then the current behavior is used?
-Aaron

On Tue, May 7, 2013 at 3:56 PM, Brad Topol <btopol@us.ibm.com> wrote:
Hi Folks, 

The current implementation of Keystone's domain support when using LDAP as a backend is broken in the read-only case for Grizzly.  This is because Keystone in Grizzly assumes it can create a default domain which is not possible for many read-only LDAPs.  We are trying to backport a fix for this.  Basically  we have two options: 

1.  Completely refrain from trying to store domains in LDAP.  If we run with the assumptions that most LDAPs don't have the concept of a domain than we just assume that there is one default domain per LDAP backend for Grizzly. 

2.  Patch the current implementation so that if the default domain does not exist essentially emulate having one.  This will work but will leave in storing the domain_id in an LDAP attribute such as businessCategory (or equivalent attribute, its mappable).   This design has been seen by many as not desirable so we would like to avoid having to leave it in if we can and then  start fresh for Havana. 

Ideally we would like to go with Option 1.  We need to know if there are any early adopters of Grizzly that are using keystone with an LDAP backend and using it to store multiple domains in the LDAP.   Because if we backport option 1 we will most certainly break anyone who is using  keystone with an LDAP backend and using it to store multiple domains in the LDAP. 

Please provide us input on this if you are using keystone ldap domain support! 

Thanks, 

Brad'}, {'account_id': 6456, 'date': '2013-05-08 04:59:08.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 9:

Hi Malini, thanks a bunch for sharing the mail and comments. Since nobody liked the boolean, I thought of another approach and I am going to have that in new patch. About the second comment, I agree that reduces LOC but I do not prefer multiple returns if possible so leaving it the way I have - I hope that's OK :-). Thanks again!"}, {'account_id': 6456, 'date': '2013-05-08 05:05:40.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 10.'}, {'account_id': 6456, 'date': '2013-05-08 05:12:36.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 10:

Since most didn't like the Boolean and condition based return of default domain, I have thought of a new approach. Since we all agree that our default is static and virtual, I think it makes sense not to worry about allowing create a default domain. 
I have also made changes to ignore default_id attribute and due to this, I had to make some changes in our Tests. 
Thanks!"}, {'account_id': 3, 'date': '2013-05-08 05:56:32.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 10: Works for me

Dolph, we are trying to take care of two problems here:
1. Default domain bug (Bug1168726)
2. Ignore domain_id attribute (this is what reducing the test coverage)

Considering the need for backporting can we just have this patch as a fix for the problem one and we work on problem two as a separate one? I am not sure how much time we have to commit backporting changes but at least fix to the problem one is something we all are good with it and that can go in backporting just today. Thanks!'}, {'account_id': 6486, 'date': '2013-05-09 21:54:38.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 13: (1 inline comment)

'}, {'account_id': 6456, 'date': '2013-05-09 23:59:16.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 13: (1 inline comment)

'}, {'account_id': 6486, 'date': '2013-05-10 00:20:52.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 13:

maybe what you should do is, for the LDAP backend, change the configuration so that domain_id isn't an ignored attribute."}, {'account_id': 6456, 'date': '2013-05-10 01:58:55.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 13:

Brant, but we want to change the configuration for LDAP to ignore domain_id. 

Since we are handling domain differently (with domain_id ignore), may be we can leave the original tests as it as and override them in LDAP adding domain_id to the domain ref we get back, knowing that it's stripping off because of ignore (something how we handle 'enable' atrribute in test_backend_ldap)? I am not sure if that's a good idea but just a thought."}, {'account_id': 6486, 'date': '2013-05-10 02:03:31.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 13:

The default configuration is changed to ignore domain_id, but Keystone can still be configured to not ignore domain_id. So Keystone needs to be able to handle both configurations.'}, {'account_id': 6456, 'date': '2013-05-10 03:36:32.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 13:

Brant, if I do not ignore domain_id in the config file we use with testing (*ldap.config) then everything is fine. Is that what you are proposing?'}, {'account_id': 6486, 'date': '2013-05-10 03:44:03.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 13:

Yes, but it would also be good to add tests where the domain_id is ignored too, for the LDAP backend specifically.'}, {'account_id': 6456, 'date': '2013-05-10 13:31:09.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 13:

Hi Brant, with what I am testing and if I didn't misunderstand what you are saying, I think we just need to do one of two options you mentioned, 
1. If we do not ignore "domain_id" in test config files (backend_ldap.conf and backend_liveldap.conf), then that will overshadow the "domain_id" ignore changes we are making and tests will works as it is. But I believe that's a dangerous test approach. 
2. If we move test functions, which reduces coverage due to the LDAP ignoring domain_id, to the LDAP specific test and modify little bit according to the patch changes that will work. I think if we go this way, we will not reduce test coverage in most or all the test methods specific to LDAP. In this approach, we will not be making any changes to configuration. 
Thoughts?'}, {'account_id': 6456, 'date': '2013-05-10 22:19:55.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 14.'}, {'account_id': 4992, 'date': '2013-05-10 22:27:25.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 14: Looks good to me, but someone else must approve

Looks good!  Thanks for making all the code improvements!!!'}, {'account_id': 5707, 'date': '2013-05-12 19:04:52.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 15: I would prefer that you didn't merge this

So I am fine with all the handling of the default domain in this patch.  However, I still don't quite understand why we are making domain_id an ignored value.  Although we all agree we are going to remove domains from the LDAP backend (and handle them at a higher level), right now we just want to fix the domain-enabled version of the LDAP backend for the problems we have with the default domain.  So this is a two step tango:

1) A patch that fixes the default domain issue result should be an LDAP backend that people could use to store domains (albeit in a hokey schema...but if you really wanted to make it work you could).  We can also back-port this to Grizzly to fix it.

2) We follow 1) with another, more substantial, update that removes domains from the LDAP backend - this only goes into Havana

Maybe I have mis-understood, but I thought the above was the plan - in which case I don't understand why we are making domain_id ignored in the this patch (which represents 1) above)."}, {'account_id': 6460, 'date': '2013-05-12 19:41:53.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 15:

Hi Henry,  I see your point.  My personal view is that this patch be as minimal as possible to fix this bug cause we are broken which is not good.  I think some of the other core folks requested that we start setting the direction of pulling out the hated implementation of domains by using the ignore config option.  So I think Sahdev is getting ping-ponged a little  by the core folks as he tries to get the patch to the point where it will be approved.   Ideally the core folks can come to consensus on the proper scope of this patch so it can move forward.   My big picture view of this is we know we will make well thought out design changes for domains & LDAP in Havana so whatever we decide on this patch now is going to be overshadowed by something else anyway.  So ideally it would be nice if the core folks can come to consensus, Sahdev will code it to meet this consensus and then we can finally have a fix for a really nasty bug that will frustrate many of our stakholders.'}, {'account_id': 2218, 'date': '2013-05-14 02:12:12.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 15:

We need to be able to run with A read only LDAP.  Otherwise, LDAP is broken.  We can split fixing that into two patches, but we need both.'}, {'account_id': 6486, 'date': '2013-05-17 00:09:32.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 15: Looks good to me (core reviewer)

domain_id is specifically missing in tests?"}, {'account_id': 2218, 'date': '2013-05-18 01:40:30.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 17: I would prefer that you didn't merge this

Does not work.

Attribute_ignore is being overwritten by devstack. If you look in /etc/keystone/keystone.conf as generated by devstack:

user_attribute_ignore = enabled,email,tenants,tenantId

If you comment out that line:
2013-05-17 21:38:40    ERROR [keystone.common.wsgi] 'domain_id'
Traceback (most recent call last):
  File "/opt/stack/keystone/keystone/common/wsgi.py", line 265, in __call__
    result = method(context, **params)
  File "/opt/stack/keystone/keystone/token/controllers.py", line 82, in authenticate
    core.validate_auth_info(self, context, user_ref, tenant_ref)
  File "/opt/stack/keystone/keystone/token/core.py", line 84, in validate_auth_info
    user_ref['domain_id'])
KeyError: 'domain_id''}, {'account_id': 6456, 'date': '2013-05-18 22:52:28.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 17:

Hi Adam, thanks for keep this rolling. 

Along with live ldap and regression test, I tested with devstack too but I didn't think of it's overwritten behavior so didn't play with keystone.conf while my testing, and it was working as expected. I am glad that you caught it. I could recreate the problem now. 

Since we can't easily ignore the domain_id as we thought, should we go with my patch without domain_id changes as a quick fix to the dashboard bug and go with Dolph's approach as a long term solution or go with Dolph's approach only and abandon my patch? 

Thanks!!"}, {'account_id': 6456, 'date': '2013-05-19 21:35:47.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 15: (1 inline comment)

This fix was moved to a newer bug 1183055..'}]

commit_message:
Provide static default domain if one does not exist

Fixes Bug1168726

If default domain is not created in the user's environment, which
typically is the  case, then provide a default domain which we use.
There is nothing special about the default domain other than the fact
that it needs to be there to maintain support for v2 clients.
for more detail, https://etherpad.openstack.org/readonly-default-domain

Multiple Domain support is disabled by default with this patch.

Change-Id: Ibc593481ff8ee2499f2376a781c629936f40b6c8

I'm not 100% sure how to fix it once it's happened, but I think you can do something like this:

  git checkout master
  git pull    [assuming your "origin" remote is something like https://github.com/openstack/swift]
  git checkout YOUR_BRANCH
  git rebase -i master
  [squash your multiple commits into one, keeping the "Change-Id" tag from your first/oldest commit]
  git review

Hope that helps!'}, {'account_id': 6831, 'date': '2013-05-23 13:16:02.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Abandoned

[{'created': '2013-05-21 16:02:31.000000000', 'message': 'Changed '/endpoints' to return info from all rings, cleanup

Added ability to extract all in-use nodes from the 'endpoints' target.
Changed '/endpoints' to return info from all rings, cleanup

Changed the 'endpoints' target so it returns data from all rings and
added 'service' filter.
Added a 'raw' filter that provides more detail.

Added 'service' filter which allows the user to specify which service(s)
they are interested in.

Example:

	curl -i http://10.254.11.1:6010/endpoints
			Returns:
		["http://127.0.0.1:6010/",
		"http://127.0.0.1:6011/",
		"http://127.0.0.1:6012/",
		"http://127.0.0.1:6020/",
		"http://127.0.0.1:6021/",
		"http://127.0.0.1:6022/",
		"http://127.0.0.1:6030/",
		"http://127.0.0.1:6031/",
		"http://127.0.0.1:6032/",
		"http://127.0.0.1:6040/",
		"http://127.0.0.1:6041/",
		"http://127.0.0.1:6042/"]

	curl -i http://10.254.11.1:6010/endpoints?service=object
			Returns:
		["http://127.0.0.1:6010/",
		"http://127.0.0.1:6020/",
		"http://127.0.0.1:6030/",
		"http://127.0.0.1:6040/"]

	curl -i http://10.254.11.1:6010/endpoints?service=object\&raw
			Returns:
		[{"ip": "127.0.0.1",
		  "region": 1,
		  "service": "object",
		  "port": 6010,
		  "zone": 1},
		  {"ip": "127.0.0.1",

commit_message:
Changed '/endpoints' to return info from all rings, cleanup

Added ability to extract all in-use nodes from the 'endpoints' target.
Changed '/endpoints' to return info from all rings, cleanup

Changed the 'endpoints' target so it returns data from all rings and
added 'service' filter.
Added a 'raw' filter that provides more detail.

Added 'service' filter which allows the user to specify which service(s)
they are interested in.

Example:

	curl -i http://10.254.11.1:6010/endpoints
			Returns:
		["http://127.0.0.1:6010/",
		"http://127.0.0.1:6011/",
		"http://127.0.0.1:6012/",
		"http://127.0.0.1:6020/",
		"http://127.0.0.1:6021/",
		"http://127.0.0.1:6022/",
		"http://127.0.0.1:6030/",
		"http://127.0.0.1:6031/",
		"http://127.0.0.1:6032/",
		"http://127.0.0.1:6040/",
		"http://127.0.0.1:6041/",
		"http://127.0.0.1:6042/"]

	curl -i http://10.254.11.1:6010/endpoints?service=object
			Returns:
		["http://127.0.0.1:6010/",
		"http://127.0.0.1:6020/",
		"http://127.0.0.1:6030/",
		"http://127.0.0.1:6040/"]

	curl -i http://10.254.11.1:6010/endpoints?service=object\&raw
			Returns:
		[{"ip": "127.0.0.1",
		  "region": 1,
		  "service": "object",
		  "port": 6010,
		  "zone": 1},
		  {"ip": "127.0.0.1",
		  "region": 1,
		  "service": "object",
		  "port": 6020,
		  "zone": 2},
		  {"ip": "127.0.0.1",
		  "region": 1,
		  "service": "object",
		  "port": 6030,
		  "zone": 3},
		  {"ip": "127.0.0.1",
		  "region": 1,
		  "service": "object",
		  "port": 6040,
		  "zone": 4}]

Change-Id: Ib2c428974e486742f1051eb37d08a5f057dd6624

[{'created': '2013-05-21 16:02:31.000000000', 'message': "Added ability to extract all endpoints from the rings.

The new capability returns a list of URL's to access services
associated with each of the rings.  Also added the ability
to recieve the endpoint data in a raw format that includes
additional relavent data.

Change-Id: Ibaa96d5321420cc46f3dbe8772bd0f11025709e8
"}]
commit_message:
Added ability to extract all endpoints from the rings.

The new capability returns a list of URL's to access services
associated with each of the rings.  Also added the ability
to recieve the endpoint data in a raw format that includes
additional relavent data.

Change-Id: Ibaa96d5321420cc46f3dbe8772bd0f11025709e8

commit_message:
Add the service_state into test_schedule_happy_day.

Since the fake filter scheduler does not update the capabilities, the sevice
states remains empty. To avoid the None value for free_capacity_gb, we set the
host_manager to a fake host manager with a list of service states.

Fixed Bug 1171906.

Change-Id: Ie629e808f80d976492f5fcb8d0a436a5048358a7

commit_message:
engine : Fix ResourceFailure exception issues

Fix some issues spotted in https://review.openstack.org/#/c/29543
These errors were spotted after the patch was merged, the
ResourceFailure exception takes an Exception not string argument

Change-Id: I72045ecf147c66a0a1cf1ef5df7fb3be8100384d

[{'created': '2013-05-09 06:39:57.000000000', 'message': 'cinder volume service keeps retrying even code exception

Make sure that ProcessLauncher does not try to restart the failed
service. And make sure the ProcessLauncher exits, when the number
of the failed services equal the number of total services.

Fixes: bug 1167841
Change-Id: I818c754534c18a62d292e21f0c98086571fe0565
(cherry picked from commit 2cee8fc3a4899097801ad93b5d6e6a4f373ad8fe)
'}]
commit_message:
cinder volume service keeps retrying even code exception

Make sure that ProcessLauncher does not try to restart the failed
service. And make sure the ProcessLauncher exits, when the number
of the failed services equal the number of total services.

Fixes: bug 1167841
Change-Id: I818c754534c18a62d292e21f0c98086571fe0565
(cherry picked from commit 2cee8fc3a4899097801ad93b5d6e6a4f373ad8fe)

@mark If Quantum is using it for legitimate reasons and we're OK with it being public then I'm fine with that. What changes is whether we consider this an implementation detail that might change in the future, in that case I'd prefer it to become private.

I mean, if this was considered an implementation detail and Quantum guys had to use it for some reason then I guess oslo.config might be lacking of some feature.

Again, I'm not against about it being public but, based on this case, I guess we should clarify what classes / functions are part of the details of oslo.config and make them private if they're not already. 

Hope that makes sense."}, {'account_id': 1247, 'date': '2013-05-23 11:35:02.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

revisions:
[{'created': '2013-05-23 10:14:17.000000000', 'message': 'Fix MultiConfigParser API breakage

Commit c952491 made an incompatible change to MultiConfigParser's
behaviour. The code in Quantum which was relying on the behaviour did
the following:

    p = MultiConfigParser()
    multi_parser.read(conf_file)

    for parsed_file in multi_parser.parsed:
        for section in parsed_file.keys():
            if section.startswith("CLUSTER:"):
                ...

However, we made a change such that the keys of the 'parsed' dict were
normalized to lowercase. Restore the previous behaviour and add another
dict for tracking the values with normalized section names. We also
add a normalized=False kwarg to the get() method so that we also restore
the previous behaviour of the method by default.

This shows the need to aggressively make implementation details as not
part of the public API of our libraries. In this case, I considered
MultiConfigParser as an implementation detail and that no projects would
be using it. But, sure enough, if it's public then *someone* will use
it.

Also, add a bunch of test cases to actually test the behaviour of this
class in isolation.

Change-Id: I0344e39222b3aecad5e30f820014f4d9f672e90c
'}]
commit_message:
Fix MultiConfigParser API breakage

Commit c952491 made an incompatible change to MultiConfigParser's
behaviour. The code in Quantum which was relying on the behaviour did
the following:

    p = MultiConfigParser()
    multi_parser.read(conf_file)

    for parsed_file in multi_parser.parsed:
        for section in parsed_file.keys():
            if section.startswith("CLUSTER:"):
                ...

However, we made a change such that the keys of the 'parsed' dict were
normalized to lowercase. Restore the previous behaviour and add another
dict for tracking the values with normalized section names. We also
add a normalized=False kwarg to the get() method so that we also restore
the previous behaviour of the method by default.

This shows the need to aggressively make implementation details as not
part of the public API of our libraries. In this case, I considered
MultiConfigParser as an implementation detail and that no projects would
be using it. But, sure enough, if it's public then *someone* will use
it.

Also, add a bunch of test cases to actually test the behaviour of this
class in isolation.

Change-Id: I0344e39222b3aecad5e30f820014f4d9f672e90c

commit_message:
initial seed for tempest doc directory

This is a first bit of experiment to get a doc tree for tempest
that will publish our doc content to the web as part of a larger
QA doc guide.

Update some of the base READMEs to be a little more accurate,
now that we're going to be pushing them to the web.

Added tox [venv] to ensure that docs get built

Change-Id: Id54e8fbc1d884525087630106e17b37dc1206cc9

[{'created': '2013-05-08 22:06:01.000000000', 'message': 'Add unittests for image upload functionality in v1

This patch adds unittests for the code that handles uploading image data to the
image store in v1 of the api. upload_utils.py was created in order to make this
area of code more testable and move upload logic out of the images api
controller.

Fixes bug 1177999

Change-Id: I97f0fa052e65228abb50090af812c3ebec605744

area of code more testable and move upload logic out of the images api
controller.

commit_message:
Add unittests for image upload functionality in v1

This patch adds unittests for the code that handles uploading image data to the
image store in v1 of the api. upload_utils.py was created in order to make this
area of code more testable and move upload logic out of the images api
controller.

Fixes bug 1177999

Change-Id: I97f0fa052e65228abb50090af812c3ebec605744

commit_message:
Fix problem with changing class attribute

Attribute get_repl_missing_table in FakeBroker class was changed in
test_replicate_object_quarantine function and not returned back. That's
why next test cases takes not expexted values from FakeBroker.

fixes bug 1180354
Change-Id: Iba55255771e6483832c7782fcbe331e20e818f4e

Share checks between create and rebuild

DRYs up the checks between create and rebuild in preparation for additional
checks going in.

to test-requirements.txt. These are standard files, and tools in the

commit_message:
Rename requires files to standard names.

Rename tools/pip-requires to requirements.txt and tools/test-requires
to test-requirements.txt. These are standard files, and tools in the
general world are growing intelligence about them.

Change-Id: I68ece8406fb1d4e082a42db8e76e17b1aaa7e775
Fixes: bug #1179008

commit_message:
Added validation for networks parameter value

A validation check is added for networks parameter value.
In server create request body, if networks parameter value
is not stored in a list then 'Bad networks format' error
is thrown with bad request exception.A new test case is
added to verify whether it is returning bad request exception
when invalid syntax is used.

Fixes: bug #1175683

Change-Id: I457a1626c56281f89d8c4a606ccc0d0e3aea05fa

revisions:
[{'created': '2013-05-23 06:03:06.000000000', 'message': 'Network MTU extension (unit test WIP)

This patch add support customizing MTU of networks (currently only
support ovs plugin).

To create a network with specified MTU using the CLI:

   (shell) net-create <net-name> --option:mtu <mtu-value>

To modify a network with specified MTU using the CLI:

   (shell) net-update <net-name> --option:mtu <mtu-value>

We push the MTU value to VM by using dhcp extensions, tested dhcp
clients:

  * isc-dhcp-client: ok
  * udhcpc: not supported

Here we introduced a new quantum extension to set network options,
and planning to add more options (eg dns server, static route).

Change-Id: Ib18f71aec4504b366c1d38b94e62291111f8275f
'}, {'created': '2013-05-23 06:03:06.000000000', 'message': 'Network MTU extension (unit test WIP)

This patch add support customizing MTU of networks (currently only
support ovs plugin).

To create a network with specified MTU using the CLI:

   (shell) net-create <net-name> --networkoption:mtu <mtu-value>

To modify a network with specified MTU using the CLI:

   (shell) net-update <net-name> --networkoption:mtu <mtu-value>

We push the MTU value to VM by using dhcp extensions, tested dhcp
clients:

  * isc-dhcp-client: ok
  * udhcpc: not supported

Here we introduced a new quantum extension to set network options,
and planning to add more options (eg dns server, static route).

Change-Id: Ib18f71aec4504b366c1d38b94e62291111f8275f
'}, {'created': '2013-05-23 06:03:06.000000000', 'message': 'Network MTU extension (unit test WIP)

support ovs plugin).

   (shell) net-create <net-name> --networkoption:mtu <mtu-value>

To modify a network with specified MTU using the CLI:

   (shell) net-update <net-name> --networkoption:mtu <mtu-value>

We push the MTU value to VM by using dhcp extensions, tested dhcp
clients:

commit_message:
Network MTU extension (unit test WIP)

This patch add support customizing MTU of networks (currently only
support ovs plugin).

To create a network with specified MTU using the CLI:

   (shell) net-create <net-name> --networkoption:mtu <mtu-value>

To modify a network with specified MTU using the CLI:

   (shell) net-update <net-name> --networkoption:mtu <mtu-value>

We push the MTU value to VM by using dhcp extensions, tested dhcp
clients:

  * isc-dhcp-client: ok
  * udhcpc: not supported

Here we introduced a new quantum extension to set network options,
and planning to add more options (eg dns server, static route).

blueprint network-options-mtu

Change-Id: Ib18f71aec4504b366c1d38b94e62291111f8275f

We know, devstack didn't explictly attach a physical interface
into $PUBLIC_BRIDGE. so need to do those things if hoping vm
can get external access after finishing installation.
But if user has created $PUBLIC_BRIDGE by hand ahead of time,
should avoid devstack to play with the exsiting bridge
configuration to cause the host can't get the external access.

fix the bug 1179356

"}]
commit_message:
Let devstack doesn't flush the ip of $PUBLIC_BRIDGE

We know, devstack didn't explictly attach a physical interface
into $PUBLIC_BRIDGE. so need to do those things if hoping vm
can get external access after finishing installation.
But if user has created $PUBLIC_BRIDGE by hand ahead of time,
should avoid devstack to play with the exsiting bridge
configuration to cause the host can't get the external access.

fix the bug 1179356

Change-Id: I8d0280c04b17390f928adb91289fd562f5cce803

commit_message:
lib/nova: Added shared storage live migration option

Based on http://docs.openstack.org/folsom/openstack-compute/admin/content/configuring-openstack-compute-basics.html#setting-flags-in-nova-conf-file
and http://docs.openstack.org/folsom/openstack-compute/admin/content/configuring-migrations.html
adding image_cache_manager_interval=0 will make nova to use the shared
storage instead of block live migration.

Change-Id: I9b7f4127f17c7e10f6a580f165a3567b34bb060d
Signed-off-by: Tal Kain <tal.kain@ravellosystems.com>

commit_message:
lib/nova: Added live_migration_flag and block_migration_flag

According to http://docs.openstack.org/trunk/openstack-compute/admin/content/hypervisor-configuration-basics.html
and http://docs.openstack.org/folsom/openstack-compute/admin/content/configuring-migrations.html
by configuring the live_migration_flag and block_migration_flag we can
enable live migration with a shared storage or without.

Change-Id: I1c7fafed2e67d222e1a4645312bd7bcca8023a38
Signed-off-by: Tal Kain <tal.kain@ravellosystems.com>

commit_message:
Switch to openstack.common.apiclient

openstack.common.apiclient can be used in novaclient,
keystoneclient, glanceclient, and other client projects.
The library contains common code and uses python-requests
for HTTP communication.

Features:
* auth_plugins
* secrets_helper to use keyring and get password from a tty
* rich exceptions hierarchy

Partially implements: blueprint common-client-library

Change-Id: Icbf5094c23c9a54839fe231811a55b952a171334

"}, {'account_id': 6159, 'date': '2013-05-06 08:02:24.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 5: Do not merge

Hey,

Thanks for your time and contributions. I've got some general comments here:

1) This hasn't been implemented in oslo, yet. It should land there before getting into glanceclient.

2) We're working on migrating to python-requests, how does this affect that process?

3) The patch is quite big, I'd rather split it in several patches adding specific, isolated and required changes.

4) The commit message needs to explain the motivations of this change a bit better.

I'd suggest to start a discussion in the m-l about this and get the bp approved before going forward with the implementation.

The idea is great and seems useful throughout OpenStack, although most of the clients already have some not-sharable customization of this code. 

Thanks a lot again."}, {'account_id': 1267, 'date': '2013-05-06 17:13:40.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 5:

Thanks for attention to my code!

> 1) This hasn't been implemented in oslo, yet. It should land there before getting into glanceclient.

I'm working on it. I have already written updates for oslo and five client packages (https://review.openstack.org/#/q/branch:master+topic:bp/common-client-library,n,z).

> 2) We're working on migrating to python-requests, how does this affect that process?

I use python-requests. Currently my patch allows sending images in chunks, accepting in blocks, and SSL certs/keys/cacerts.

> 3) The patch is quite big, I'd rather split it in several patches adding specific, isolated and required changes.

Well, it is relatively small :) It contains the new oslo apiclient library, cosmetic changes to Manager classes, updated shell code, and changes to unit tests to ensure that the job is done. I'm in doubt how can the patch be split out.

> 4) The commit message needs to explain the motivations of this change a bit better.

Absolutely! How about that:

Switch to openstack.common.apiclient

openstack.common.apiclient can be used in novaclient, keystoneclient, glanceclient, and other client projects. The library contains common code and uses python-requests for
HTTP communication.

Features:
* auth_plugins
* secrets_helper to use keyring and get password from a tty
* rich exceptions hierarchy

> I'd suggest to start a discussion in the m-l about this and get the bp approved before going forward with the implementation.

Frankly speaking, I have started the discussion several times during the last year, but it didn't help. I have participated in openstackclient design session (on Openstack Summit) and its developers agreed that such common API library would be desirable. So, I have written the implementation and a a bunch of patches in hope that they will be accepted as a ready solution.Jason K√∂lker is good with incubating openstack.common.apiclient in oslo, therefore, the process is started.

> The idea is great and seems useful throughout OpenStack, although most of the clients already have some not-sharable customization of this code.

Thank you!
When you speak about not-sharable customization, what do you mean? I see a large problem in adapting quantum- and swiftclient, but nova-, glance-, keystone-, and cinderclient can be switched to the new oslo apiclient and the required patches are written.

Could you remove -2, please?"}, {'account_id': 455, 'date': '2013-05-07 10:41:35.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 5:

Hi Alessio,

I think long term moving to a shared http/s code makes sense,  but I'm concerned that this patch seems to remove the --no-ssl-compression functionality. This can have a performance impact, eg see: http://15.185.160.228/ssl_comp.pdf"}, {'account_id': 6159, 'date': '2013-05-07 11:26:36.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 5:

Hey Alessio,

Thanks a lot for your reply. Let me reply using the same items' indexes:

1) Cool, glad to see you're working on that. We should wait for it to get merged in oslo-incubator before letting it land here.

2) Cool, I'll review that code in oslo-incubator

3) Fair enough. FWIW, I think it would be better to create a patch that adds oslo's client code and another - depending on the previous one - that does the actual change.

4) Awesome, I'd also suggest you to get that bp approved (try to ping markmc, dims, russellb)

About the custom code: An example of that is what Stuart just said. We have some custom code that disables ssl compression when specified in the CLI, and we'd like to keep that. (Pls, take a look at current requests migration patch).

Thanks a lot for your code."}, {'account_id': 1267, 'date': '2013-05-07 15:26:33.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 6.'}, {'account_id': 3, 'date': '2013-05-07 15:47:01.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 6: Doesn't seem to work

Fortunately, the blueprint has just been approved by Mark McLoughlin. I have updated oslo code and the clients once again and I hope that oslo will accept my patch during this week. Then I could split glanceclient's patch in two parts, if you would like to do so.

Could you add SSL without compression from "Replace old httpclient with requests" to my patch for oslo, please? Or, if you permit, I could do this job.

commit_message:
Switch to openstack.common.apiclient

openstack.common.apiclient can be used in novaclient,
keystoneclient, glanceclient, and other client projects.
The library contains common code and uses python-requests
for HTTP communication.

Features:
* auth_plugins
* secrets_helper to use keyring and get password from a tty
* rich exceptions hierarchy

Partially implements: blueprint common-client-library

Change-Id: Ic30871111ff65ad40d8f3e5c6c16008ed57ee47e

Hi Boris,

This change will ensure that the latest 'version' of a flavor_id is shown. 

If there is an instance of that flavor_id that is active, it will always be the latest one (since it would have been impossible to create another of the same flavor_id while this one was active).

If there are none active, it will just show the latest deleted one.

I'm not sure I understand why this will not resolve the bug?"}, {'account_id': 6172, 'date': '2013-05-09 12:00:44.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 4: (1 inline comment)

commit_message:
Switch to openstack.common.apiclient

openstack.common.apiclient can be used in novaclient,
keystoneclient, glanceclient, and other client projects.
The library contains common code and uses python-requests
for HTTP communication.

Features:
* auth_plugins
* secrets_helper to use keyring and get password from a tty
* rich exceptions hierarchy

Partially implements: blueprint common-client-library

Change-Id: Ic3087e5d8ff65ad40d8f3e5c6c16008ed57ee47e

commit_message:
Sync rpc changes from oslo-incubator

Syncs:

  93ee6e3 Add generic serialization support
  df7ea83 Allow RPC_API_NAMESPACE on RpcProxy objects
  1d7920a Extract matchmaker_ring to own module
  aa89d8b Support capping message versions in the client.

Change-Id: I80a2671997e8074bef9d1ef230ca3956888265e6

commit_message:
Removed session from fixed_ip_*() functions.

Removed session objects from public fixed_ip_*() functions
in nova/db/sqlalchemy/api module. Minor code refactiring.

blueprint db-session-cleanup

Change-Id: Ic2a96270745799496e365aee0380ac079e1edeff

Hi Kazuataka, I think all the three comments are not the problem of the code. See inline comments for detail.'}, {'account_id': 124, 'date': '2013-05-21 06:46:21.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2: Looks good to me, but someone else must approve

Looks good to me.'}, {'account_id': 6549, 'date': '2013-05-21 09:49:04.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2: I would prefer that you didn't merge this

I still consider you should use processutil within Oslo but rebuild it again in the store. You maybe can re-use/propose this: https://review.openstack.org/#/c/20469/

btw, IMO, the right way you should go is that propose this store idea to community via dev-maillist firstly, then to create a blueprint with the right idea, then commit those changes and write the blueprint number into the commit message. in that way, more other glance guys will review this quickly."}, {'account_id': 7598, 'date': '2013-05-21 10:01:51.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2:

Hi Zhi Yan Liu: I have grep the source code and found processutil isn't imported at all. So I'd like to keep it simple at the beginning and use a simple wrapper around popen process looks clean to me. Your suggestion is to write another wrapper around processutil, If I understand it correctly. I don't think this make much difference to Sheepdog store. If there is any candy helper to execute the command inside glance, I am open to replace current simple wrapper with it."}, {'account_id': 6549, 'date': '2013-05-21 10:05:36.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2:

So, I prefer we re-propose https://review.openstack.org/#/c/20469/ (need rebase), then sheepdog store can use it directly.

rootwrap importing is an independent change.'}, {'account_id': 7598, 'date': '2013-05-21 10:25:31.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2:

Zhi Yan Liu:

I think let's firstly keep sheepdog store more self-containing. I am quite new to openstack development and I have no idea of your proposal. Put the sheepdog store on the dependency of your unmerged (yet) patch set doesn't make sense to me. I think we can  cook a patch to replace execute() wrapper if your patch set get merged, assuming Sheepdog store set is merged before your patch set."}, {'account_id': 6549, 'date': '2013-05-21 10:51:48.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2:

I have sent the mail to dev-mailist to help you involve more guys here and make sure rootwrap/processutils infrastructure importing plan.'}, {'account_id': 616, 'date': '2013-05-21 16:44:58.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2: Do not merge

(1 inline comment)

Thanks for this submission. It is nice for glance to be able to work with more and more stores.

One minor question inline.

My -2 reflects the fact that the blueprint has not been discussed and approved in a glance team meeting yet. Once we have that discussion, I will remove my block.

Thanks!'}, {'account_id': 7598, 'date': '2013-05-21 17:20:43.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2: (1 inline comment)

Hello Mark

I have actually done a v2 of the patch that includes both unit and functional tests and all the comments addressed. This  v2 patch is ready for glance so I'll create a v2 branch just waiting for your approval after the blue-print discussion meeting

Sheepdog integration of Cinder was done earlier. And you can go to http://www.slideshare.net/multics/overview-of-sheepdog to get an overview of Sheepdog in minutes.

and our wiki page
https://github.com/collie/sheepdog/wiki

Sheepdog community will keep contiguous effort to integrate more closely  into Openstack system. Support of Swift API is planned."}, {'account_id': 616, 'date': '2013-05-21 17:41:12.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2:

Sounds great, Liu. I look forward to the discussion!'}, {'account_id': 7598, 'date': '2013-05-23 02:09:15.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2: Abandoned

get a v2 branch'}]

commit_message:
Add Sheepdog store

Sheepdog is a distributed block storage. This patch enables Sheepdog cluster
as a backend store for glance.

Test:

You can set up a simulated 3 node cluster on the local machine with
following script:

 $ sudo apt-get install liburcu-dev
 $ git clone git://github.com/collie/sheepdog.git
 $ cd sheepdog
 $ ./autogen.sh; ./configure --disable-corosync
 $ make; sudo make install
 $ for i in 0 1 2; do sheep /tmp/store$i -c local -z $i -p 700$i;done
 $ collie cluster format

Then change the default store in glance-api.conf as sheepdog

Change-Id: Iec99a5680532cfa14f76e44a37a4cefd57c9c0c0

commit_message:
Commit b8b2c4ebec7f8687215b5fd17a6f0fde84aee043 on Quantum changed Quantum to
use lower case names when referencing configuration options in the [ovs]
section. This patch is the matching half for devstack.

fixes bug 1183127

Change-Id: Icebff3f907d3b1fd6e750fca2b698b1e365a6cd0

commit_message:
account-reaper warns if not making progress

DocImpact
If account reaper has not managed to clean out an account after a long
period, it prints a message to the log (you can search your system looking
for such messages). Introduce reap_warn_after config variable to determine
when to emit the message (defaults to 30 days).

Also fix bug 1181995 (edge case where object name is an empty string)

Change-Id: Ic0dfee04742d06b6a51b59f302d7a272d7c1de92

commit_message:
Use webtest for v2 and v3 API testing.

The intention is to remain as close as possible to the original
implementation and so leaves a number of easy cleanups and optimisations
until a later patch.

In writing tests their are a number of changes for API tests that are a
result of webob/webtest restrictions:
 * response.body is now the string body and response.result is the parsed
   dictionary.
 * response.status is now a string eg. '200 OK', use
   response.status_code to get the integer
 * response.getheader no longer exists. response.headers is a dictionary
   like object that can be accessed (case independently) with [] or
   .get()

Working towards: blueprint extract-eventlet
Change-Id: I393b4bad2fd6eacc0b8ae98fc204d1323014b5e4

commit_message:
Update log.py and jsonutils.py from oslo-incubator

The update of log was mostly to get coloring to work again
in devstack, and jsonutils was picked up as well.

The update to jsonutils also requires the six dependency
which is added to pip-requires.

Change-Id: I95d23aafe19b12d4a427149aa5f7a66394d178c6

commit_message:
Added missing source variable in storage drivers

Addresses bug 1163479
*tests/storage/base.py
*ceilometer/storage/models.py
*ceilometer/storage/impl_hbase.py
*ceilometer/storage/impl_mongodb.py
*ceilometer/storage/impl_sqlalchemy.py

Added self.assertIn statements to test_get_resources() and test_get_meters()
functions in /tests/storage/base.py

These assert statements check for the existence of the source variable and
also if the source variable is in the set of sources hard coded by the database
test data.

Added the source variable to models.Resource and models.Meter in the HBase,
MongoDB, and SQLAlchemy drivers.  Added the source variable to the
specifications for the Resource and Meter classes in models.py

Change-Id: I5a407bc8c7ce82a71be7e56705c540ece4573340

commit_message:
Make openvswitch configurable for VMs.

Many options were hard-coded for boot-stack to work with baremetal only.
We want to use boot-stack as the seed for VM based clouds as well by
passing in Heat metadata.

Change-Id: Ia2512b174cacb57d694d783b6970b9732ab3fd55

commit_message:
force the test path to a str (sometimes is unicode)

else webtest lint will error about the PATH_INFO environment not being
a str.

Change-Id: I535386647fa8797ccfb13c251448a19fc077e848

revisions:
[{'created': '2013-04-10 12:57:08.000000000', 'message': "Remove gettext.install() from glance/__init__.py

The gettext.install() function installs a builtin _() function which
translates a string in the translation domain supplied to the install()
function. If gettext.install() is called multiple times, it's the last
call to the function which wins and the last supplied translation domain
which is used e.g.

 >>> import os
 >>> os.environ['LANG'] = 'ja.UTF-8'
 >>> import gettext
 >>> gettext.install('keystone', unicode=1, localedir='/opt/stack/keystone/keystone/locale')
 >>> print _('Invalid syslog facility')
 ÁÑ°Âäπ„Å™ syslog „Éï„Ç°„Ç∑„É™„ÉÜ„Ç£
 >>> gettext.install('nova', unicode=1, localedir='/opt/stack/nova/nova/locale')
 >>> print _('Invalid syslog facility')
 Invalid syslog facility

Usually this function is called early on in a toplevel script and we
assume that no other code will call it and override the installed _().
However, in Glance, we have taken a shortcut to avoid having to call it
explicitly from each script and instead call it from glance/__init__.py.

This shortcut would be perfectly fine if we were absolutely sure that
glance modules would never be imported from another program. It's probably
quite incorrect for a program to use glance code (indeed, if we wanted to
support this, Glance code shouldn't use the default _() function) but
nevertheless there are some corner cases where it happens. For example,
the keystoneclient auth_token middleware tries to import cfg from
gance.openstack.common and this in turn causes gettext.install('glance')
to be called in other projects like glance or quantum.

To avoid any doubt here, let's just rip out the shortcut and always
call gettext.install() from the top-level script.

However, there's a bit of an annoying detail here - by default,
nosetests starts in the current directly and tries to import all modules
it finds to look for tests. Without the _() builtin installed, importing
some modules like glance.common.exception will fail.

Since it only ever makes sense to load tests from the glance/tests dir,
we can ask nose to do that. We do that by changing the default test dir
rather than supplying glance/tests as a positional argument, because we
still want to allow people do e.g. 'tox -- glance.tests.foo' to choose
individual tests to run.

Change-Id: If4125d6bcbde63df95de129ac5c83b4a6d6f130a
"}, {'created': '2013-05-08 08:27:55.000000000', 'message': "Remove gettext.install() from glance/__init__.py

translates a string in the translation domain supplied to the install()

call to the function which wins and the last supplied translation domain
which is used e.g.

 >>> import os
 >>> os.environ['LANG'] = 'ja.UTF-8'
 >>> import gettext
 >>> gettext.install('keystone', unicode=1, localedir='/opt/stack/keystone/keystone/locale')
 >>> print _('Invalid syslog facility')
 ÁÑ°Âäπ„Å™ syslog „Éï„Ç°„Ç∑„É™„ÉÜ„Ç£
 >>> gettext.install('nova', unicode=1, localedir='/opt/stack/nova/nova/locale')
 >>> print _('Invalid syslog facility')
 Invalid syslog facility

Usually this function is called early on in a toplevel script and we
assume that no other code will call it and override the installed _().
However, in Glance, we have taken a shortcut to avoid having to call it
explicitly from each script and instead call it from glance/__init__.py.

This shortcut would be perfectly fine if we were absolutely sure that
glance modules would never be imported from another program. It's probably
quite incorrect for a program to use glance code (indeed, if we wanted to
support this, Glance code shouldn't use the default _() function) but
nevertheless there are some corner cases where it happens. For example,
the keystoneclient auth_token middleware tries to import cfg from
gance.openstack.common and this in turn causes gettext.install('glance')
to be called in other projects like glance or quantum.

To avoid any doubt here, let's just rip out the shortcut and always
call gettext.install() from the top-level script.

However, there's a bit of an annoying detail here - by default,
nosetests starts in the current directly and tries to import all modules
it finds to look for tests. Without the _() builtin installed, importing
some modules like glance.common.exception will fail.

Since it only ever makes sense to load tests from the glance/tests dir,
we can ask nose to do that by using the --tests argument via setup.cfg.

Note, this means that if you previously did this:

  $> tox -- glance.tests.foo glance.tests.bar

then you must now do this:

  $> tox -- --tests glance.tests.foo,glance.tests.bar

Change-Id: If4125d6bcbde63df95de129ac5c83b4a6d6f130a
"}]
commit_message:
Remove gettext.install() from glance/__init__.py

The gettext.install() function installs a builtin _() function which
translates a string in the translation domain supplied to the install()
function. If gettext.install() is called multiple times, it's the last
call to the function which wins and the last supplied translation domain
which is used e.g.

 >>> import os
 >>> os.environ['LANG'] = 'ja.UTF-8'
 >>> import gettext
 >>> gettext.install('keystone', unicode=1, localedir='/opt/stack/keystone/keystone/locale')
 >>> print _('Invalid syslog facility')
 ÁÑ°Âäπ„Å™ syslog „Éï„Ç°„Ç∑„É™„ÉÜ„Ç£
 >>> gettext.install('nova', unicode=1, localedir='/opt/stack/nova/nova/locale')
 >>> print _('Invalid syslog facility')
 Invalid syslog facility

Usually this function is called early on in a toplevel script and we
assume that no other code will call it and override the installed _().
However, in Glance, we have taken a shortcut to avoid having to call it
explicitly from each script and instead call it from glance/__init__.py.

This shortcut would be perfectly fine if we were absolutely sure that
glance modules would never be imported from another program. It's probably
quite incorrect for a program to use glance code (indeed, if we wanted to
support this, Glance code shouldn't use the default _() function) but
nevertheless there are some corner cases where it happens. For example,
the keystoneclient auth_token middleware tries to import cfg from
gance.openstack.common and this in turn causes gettext.install('glance')
to be called in other projects like glance or quantum.

To avoid any doubt here, let's just rip out the shortcut and always
call gettext.install() from the top-level script.

However, there's a bit of an annoying detail here - by default,
nosetests starts in the current directly and tries to import all modules
it finds to look for tests. Without the _() builtin installed, importing
some modules like glance.common.exception will fail.

Since it only ever makes sense to load tests from the glance/tests dir,
we can ask nose to do that by using the --tests argument via setup.cfg.

Note, this means that if you previously did this:

  $> tox -- glance.tests.foo glance.tests.bar

then you must now do this:

  $> tox -- --tests glance.tests.foo,glance.tests.bar

Change-Id: If4125d6bcbde63df95de129ac5c83b4a6d6f130a

commit_message:
Deprecating old dot path locations for Folsom configs

In grizzly, we made a lot of structure changes. This deprecates the old
locations so the dot paths in old configs still work but give warnings
in the logs of what needs to be updated.

Fixes: bug #1168573
Change-Id: I7b1754b0e59a923afa623871fc3be07362bf1bdc
(cherry picked from commit c355d68a868e9232a80c2f22557ffe228fcb4f8f)

I've read the bug, which I'm not sure I understand, and I'm sure there's something useful here, but I'm really struggling to wrap my head around the language used in the variable names. Services have names and types, and a catalog is an organized collection of endpoints...

And why is a contract-defined constant configurable..?"}, {'account_id': 6522, 'date': '2013-02-28 21:06:57.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 4: (2 inline comments)

So here is background around these changes, if i have misunderstood something please suggest better options (i.e. variable names).

Thesis :
A python application using api paste keystone client middleware would like to ensure that a user that is authenticated against auth service requires a service endpoint to be in users service catalog. This will be determined by confirming that the service name and service type are of expected values.

Task : 
Add configurable options to keystoneclient so that service name and types are required when a  user is authenticated with keystoneclient middleware.'}, {'account_id': 9, 'date': '2013-03-08 06:03:06.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 4:
