conceptually, I'm fine with the feature request, however, the following things are missing:

1) this only applies to UUID tokens, and not PKI tokens - if we're going to support this as a feature to the middleware, it must support both. 
2) the additional configuration options mean that the commit message should have at a minimum the DocImpact flag, which it doesn't
3) Documentation should be added within this repo to at least doc/source/middlewarearchitecture.rst describing the feature and how to configure it. 

side note - this should really be a blueprint, not a bug - as it's clearly a feature addition."}, {'account_id': 6522, 'date': '2013-04-18 15:31:26.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 6.'}, {'account_id': 6522, 'date': '2013-04-18 15:34:17.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 7.'}, {'account_id': 5494, 'date': '2013-04-18 15:34:24.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 7:

code review expired after 2 weeks of no activity, it can be restored using the `Restore Change` button  under the Patch Set on the web interface'}, {'account_id': 9, 'date': '2013-05-14 06:03:01.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 12:

code review expired after 2 weeks of no activity, it can be restored using the `Restore Change` button  under the Patch Set on the web interface'}, {'account_id': 6522, 'date': '2013-05-19 07:18:30.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 12: Restored'}, {'account_id': 4, 'date': '2013-05-22 18:39:16.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 12: Do not merge

(1 inline comment)

i'm not quite sure the best way to achieve the functionality that you're looking for, but i really don't think that configuring policy enforcement through auth_token is the right way to go

the ultimate problem you're trying to solve appears to be determining whether a token is authorized to access a particular endpoint, regardless of roles, etc... I think the right way to solve that is to either include an endpoint in the token's scope, or (perhaps preferably) encrypt the token so that it can only be validated by a particular endpoint (or set of endpoints)?"}, {'account_id': 6522, 'date': '2013-05-22 18:57:40.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 12: (1 inline comment)

It sounds like you are actually suggesting changes to the keystone backend. From my perspective it is entirely reasonable that you can expect from a middleware to provide functionality for restricting based on configurable options. Which is what this change entails.'}, {'account_id': 4, 'date': '2013-05-22 22:14:00.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 12:

two most significant problems I see here-

1. this puts the burden of policy enforcement into auth_token
2. auth_token can't be guaranteed to receive a token with a catalog at all, see https://blueprints.launchpad.net/keystone/+spec/catalog-optional

I think the use case is totally valid and worth pursuing, but the ideal long term solution won't be purely client-side and needs to consider that the catalog isn't intended to represent authorization."}, {'account_id': 6522, 'date': '2013-05-22 22:18:26.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 12: Abandoned

Makes sense.'}]

[{'created': '2013-02-19 21:47:54.000000000', 'message': 'Add config options for service catalog

Fixes Bug 1130283

application and user does not have service endpoints defined
then raise InvalidServiceCatalog exception resulting in access
denied.

Change-Id: Ifc1c3125f3274e5bbd5deebb5ef910072b0e299b
'}, {'created': '2013-02-19 22:05:20.000000000', 'message': 'Add config options for service catalog

Fixes Bug 1130283
If service catalog types or names are defined as options for
application and user does not have service endpoints defined

commit_message:
Add config options for service catalog

Fixes Bug 1130283
If service catalog types or names are defined as options for
application and user does not have service endpoints defined
then raise InvalidServiceCatalog exception resulting in access
denied.
DocImpact

Change-Id: Ifc1c3125f3274e5bbd5deebb5ef910072b0e299b

commit_message:
Set compute_driver in xenserver.pp.

Updates the compute/xenserver.pp module so that we set compute_driver.
Given we already do this for libvirt I think it makes sense to do
it here as well.

Change-Id: I1b42b4e7f638a94b0b1f933994569f7a502fadb9

commit_message:
Make nova-api use servicegroup.API.service_is_up().

Fix bug 1168861

Change-Id: I1e7e8f7519ec627b96736f74ee7123d101973544

The use of "file" as a variable name always makes me cringe. It's a Python builtin, so aside from overriding "normal" things (and therefore breaking expectations), it also makes syntax highlighters light up.

I know this is not something that you introduced, but you are making more use of it. So perhaps now is the time to make it better.

I'd prefer to see the variable name changed.'}, {'account_id': 6198, 'date': '2013-04-29 10:39:58.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3:

'}, {'account_id': 2622, 'date': '2013-05-03 06:22:52.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 4: I would prefer that you didn't merge this

Well, let me start by saying that I like the part where the bare file descriptor doesn't get outside of DiskFile any more. However, I think this makes the DiskFile API kind of weird in a bad way.

The code used to look like this this:

    with disk_file.mkstemp(size=fsize) as fd:
        # ...blah blah blah...
        for chunk in some_thing():
            os.write(fd, chunk)
            # maybe fsync, maybe not, who knows?
        disk_file.put(fd, size, metadata)    # internals hanging out all over
        
and that was ugly, but made sense: you call mkstemp() to start writing, and you get a handle to write to, and then when you're done the handle goes out of scope and the file gets closed. You would never think to write to the handle outside of the mkstemp() context since you don't have a handle in scope. The thought can't even be expressed in Python.

By shoving that into DiskFile in the way that this changeset does, we get code sort of like:

    with disk_file.mkstemp(size=fsize):
        for chunk in some_thing():
            disk_file.write(chunk)
        disk_file.put(metadata)

That's nice as far as not having the internals hanging out, but it's weird in that there's now a .write() on a DiskFile that you can *syntactically* call at any time, but if you want it to *work*, you have to call it in the context of mkstemp(). It invites misuse (IMHO).

I think one (but certainly not the only!) better way to do this would be to have a smart wrapper around the fd that handles all the syncing and cache dropping, but to return the smart wrapper from mkstemp() and only have the write()/put() methods available on the wrapper. Then you get code like this:


    with disk_file.mkstemp(size=fsize) as gizmo:
        for chunk in some_thing():
            gizmo.write(chunk)     # look, ma, no exposed fsyncs!
        gizmo.put(metadata)"}, {'account_id': 6198, 'date': '2013-05-03 10:53:32.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 4:

Good feedback. I'll try the gizmo thing..."}, {'account_id': 6198, 'date': '2013-05-08 20:02:26.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 4: Work In Progress

Working on a refactoring for this based on Sam's changes."}, {'account_id': 9, 'date': '2013-05-16 06:03:06.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 4:

code review expired after 1 week of no activity after a negative review, it can be restored using the `Restore Change` button under the Patch Set on the web interface'}, {'account_id': 9, 'date': '2013-05-16 06:03:06.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 4: Abandoned

commit_message:
Hide the file descriptor and disk write methodology for PUTs

Towards moving the DiskFile class into place as the API definition for
pluggable DiskFile backends, we hide the file descriptor and the
method of writing data to disks. The mkstemp() method has been renamed
to writer(), and no longer returns an fd, but a new object that
encapsulates the state tracked for writes. This new object is then
used directly to perform the reminder of the write operations and
application of required semantics.

Change-Id: Ib37ed37b34a2ce6b442d69f83ca011c918114434
Signed-off-by: Peter Portante <peter.portante@redhat.com>

While the functionality looks fine, I'm not clear on why you implemented this as a workflow rather than a simple form. There's only one step in the workflow and it doesn't have an special processing or manipulations that I can see. If a form would suffice, I'd use a form since it'd be more consistent and much simpler."}, {'account_id': 6914, 'date': '2013-04-24 09:32:58.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2:

Workflow has been chosen for consistency, as it is used in 'add vip' and other options implementation. Considering the 'add vip' option, what do you think about it? Should it be implemented as a from too?"}, {'account_id': 6914, 'date': '2013-04-24 10:02:29.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2: (1 inline comment)

code review expired after 1 week of no activity after a negative review, it can be restored using the `Restore Change` button under the Patch Set on the web interface'}, {'account_id': 6914, 'date': '2013-05-14 06:16:18.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2: Restored'}, {'account_id': 841, 'date': '2013-05-20 17:02:51.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2:

My view about form vs workflow is as follows:

- A simple form is better if it has one step. Workflow panel with one action provides additional redundant tab bar. 

- On the other hand, if the form plans to have more options and tab-based implementation provides better user experience, workflow is acceptable to me even though it has only one step now. (A transition from form to workflow and vice versa is not a trivial change.)

The change can be done in a separate patch which changes all create/update forms to keep consistency. What do you think?'}, {'account_id': 6914, 'date': '2013-05-21 13:19:39.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2:

Thank you for the comment!
I already made a transition from workflow to form and was waiting for an answer.
I think that in this case a form will suffice, but the implementation has comparable complexity: we need to add two templates for the form instead of a generic one for the workflow; we also need to add forms.py itself. It seems reasonable to me though to implement all new update options (I mean this one and update member, vip and monitor option in separate patch) as forms for consistency and keep all existent update options as they are.'}, {'account_id': 6914, 'date': '2013-05-21 13:28:03.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 3.'}, {'account_id': 6914, 'date': '2013-05-21 13:44:47.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 4.'}, {'account_id': 6914, 'date': '2013-05-21 13:47:21.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 4:

commit_message:
Add "Edit Pool" button

Add option for updating pool attributes on pools table page.
The following attributes can be updated:
* name
* description
* lb_method
* admin_state_up

fixes bug 1160555

Change-Id: Ifadc65e9624f77d258068c67947af5e49df7c110

subject: Introduces the PATCH method for the proxy's object controller.
messages:
[{'account_id': 2622, 'date': '2013-05-21 20:36:59.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: I would prefer that you didn't merge this

So, this definitely needs unit tests. Functional tests too.

Also, how the heck do I use this? I looked at RFC 5789, but section 2 just talks about "patch documents" without defining a format. I really want some example requests in the docs somewhere, or some curl commands in a comment here, or *something*. Right now I can't tell if it works because I don't know what it's supposed to do. :('}, {'account_id': 2622, 'date': '2013-05-21 20:42:05.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1: Do not merge

Okay, I'm starting to see what's going on here.

Please take https://review.openstack.org/29990 and combine it with this patchset or make a new one with the combined contents. There is no circumstance where I would want the proxy server to support PATCH but the object server not to, so there is no reason to have two separate changesets.

Thanks.

(Oh, and that stuff I said earlier about sample requests? Still want those. :) )"}, {'account_id': 3, 'date': '2013-05-21 21:06:26.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1: Doesn't seem to work

Build failed.  For information on how to proceed, see https://wiki.openstack.org/wiki/GerritJenkinsGithub#Test_Failures

- http://logs.openstack.org/29988/1/check/gate-swift-pep8/2445 : FAILURE in 36s
- http://docs-draft.openstack.org/29988/1/check/gate-swift-docs/2276/doc/build/html/ : SUCCESS in 1m 00s
- http://logs.openstack.org/29988/1/check/gate-swift-python26/2524 : FAILURE in 1m 13s
- http://logs.openstack.org/29988/1/check/gate-swift-python27/2522 : FAILURE in 55s
- http://logs.openstack.org/29988/1/check/gate-tempest-devstack-vm-full/17421 : FAILURE in 14m 00s
- http://logs.openstack.org/29988/1/check/gate-tempest-devstack-vm-quantum/24097 : FAILURE in 15m 14s
- http://logs.openstack.org/29988/1/check/gate-tempest-devstack-vm-postgres-full/17131 : FAILURE in 14m 01s (non-voting)
- http://logs.openstack.org/29988/1/check/gate-grenade-devstack-vm/4955 : FAILURE in 17m 19s (non-voting)
"}, {'account_id': 7601, 'date': '2013-05-21 21:48:14.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

@Samuel
Yeah these are the main changes and are a supposed to eventually be patched togther :)
There are couple of more changes that I still need to upload, mainly a PATCH method for the container and the check_int function in utils.
I just thought the changes would go to the same patchset since I work on the same branch and same blueprint is mentioned. I'm obviously new around here, still trying to figure out how things work, sorry if I made a mess...
May I ask how do I merge them without making one big commit? (or is that the recommended way?)
I will add a link to a snippet that uses this, but the main idea is that the content of the request is written in the offset of 'x-patch-offset' and after that the file may be truncated to the size in 'x-new-size'.
I assume some unit-tests will be needed as well. I'll start working on that once I'm done adding the main changes here."}, {'account_id': 7601, 'date': '2013-05-21 22:09:38.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

As promised, an example in python:
https://gist.github.com/benlapid/5623670
This is a part of my FUSE client, which mounts containers onto the filesystem.
Still need to figure out if to add it as a patch to the existed swiftclient codebase or to create a seperate project. What would you prefer?'}, {'account_id': 7601, 'date': '2013-05-21 23:38:01.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

Rebased everything, hopefully I've done it right this time :)
https://review.openstack.org/#/c/30013/"}, {'account_id': 7601, 'date': '2013-05-22 20:38:41.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Abandoned

Please refer to:
https://review.openstack.org/30013'}]

[{'created': '2013-05-22 10:41:58.000000000', 'message': 'Stub out sleeps in quantum unit tests

The patch 5d86e2f2ece51a79102aee2af9a3f306c929aaea
added wait states into the unit tests for quantum networks, routers and
ports, but did not stub out the resulting sleep. This caused the tests to
run for over 1s, which indirectly allowed bug #1182285 to become visible.

Change-Id: Id26daa87e1618533ee92c33827a9d01800b03752
'}]
commit_message:
Stub out sleeps in quantum unit tests

The patch 5d86e2f2ece51a79102aee2af9a3f306c929aaea
added wait states into the unit tests for quantum networks, routers and
ports, but did not stub out the resulting sleep. This caused the tests to
run for over 1s, which indirectly allowed bug #1182285 to become visible.

Change-Id: Id26daa87e1618533ee92c33827a9d01800b03752

[{'created': '2013-05-21 04:37:17.000000000', 'message': 'Change assertTrue(len()) to assertTrue(len() > 0).

The docs for assertTrue say that it equates to bool(expr) is True and
so is correct however it reads inconsistently.

Change-Id: I75acf75f6eaac9b7f92fd452cc60ab0cfd447c7f
'}, {'created': '2013-05-21 23:30:53.000000000', 'message': 'Add assertNotEmpty to tests and use it.

Extract the use of assertTrue(len(...)) into a method. The docs for
assertTrue say that it equates to bool(expr) is True and so the format
is correct however it reads inconsistently.

Change-Id: I75acf75f6eaac9b7f92fd452cc60ab0cfd447c7f
'}]
commit_message:
Add assertNotEmpty to tests and use it.

Extract the use of assertTrue(len(...)) into a method. The docs for
assertTrue say that it equates to bool(expr) is True and so the format
is correct however it reads inconsistently.

Change-Id: I75acf75f6eaac9b7f92fd452cc60ab0cfd447c7f

commit_message:
Use boolean instead of string

Use boolean values whenever possible for the sack of consistency.
The ini_setting type supports boolean values just fine.

Change-Id: Iaf576f512f34e9358a66a57f47b934468c55cc3b

[{'created': '2013-05-22 19:21:59.000000000', 'message': 'Skip baremetal config when there is no baremetal.

We want to be able to use boot-stack for booting an all-in-one
non-baremetal configuration as well.

Nova needs a lot of extra components for baremetal, these bits will fail
without the baremetal configuration section.

Change-Id: I24c073c7eb53a6cab92af2c6c30801b9a686f074
'}]
commit_message:
Skip baremetal config when there is no baremetal.

We want to be able to use boot-stack for booting an all-in-one
non-baremetal configuration as well.

Nova needs a lot of extra components for baremetal, these bits will fail
without the baremetal configuration section.

Change-Id: I24c073c7eb53a6cab92af2c6c30801b9a686f074

commit_message:
Capitalize boolean values in config files

This patch allows the usage of Puppet boolean values and still
configure values with OpenStack boolean style: True/False.

Change-Id: I972ac41757f253500f43dc285784f5f8af6ce2ab

Add rule for list_groups_for_user in policy.json

Providing an initial policy rule for the list_groups_for_user
operation in the sample policy.json file for the ease of
configuration.

Using the LDAP identity backend,
if a group member entry doesn't exist in the LDAP server anymore
and the group's members are listed using GET /v3/groups/{groupId}/users,
Keystone returns 404 Not Found.

The server should return all the group members that do exist
and ignore the missing members,
and probably log a warning message about the missing user.

Fixes bug 1174585

Change-Id: Idf7c8c7f87affc4a72c5fe5e18e09a0f362e2646
(cherry picked from commit 4eb8233d9c6b73cedf25ea66edaccbcd092e13aa)
"}]
commit_message:
LDAP list groups with missing member entry

Using the LDAP identity backend,
if a group member entry doesn't exist in the LDAP server anymore
and the group's members are listed using GET /v3/groups/{groupId}/users,
Keystone returns 404 Not Found.

The server should return all the group members that do exist
and ignore the missing members,
and probably log a warning message about the missing user.

Fixes bug 1174585

Change-Id: Idf7c8c7f87affc4a72c5fe5e18e09a0f362e2646
(cherry picked from commit 4eb8233d9c6b73cedf25ea66edaccbcd092e13aa)

[{'created': '2013-05-21 23:25:23.000000000', 'message': "Only add logging handlers if there currently aren't any

This corrects an odd problem where Horizon would stand up multiple
client objects, which would cause duplicate/triplicate/dozens of
repeated log lines in its log files, due to multiple identical
handlers being added to the logging object

Fixes Bug 1182678

Change-Id: I020b3999c9008b996286ccb74a7801c96c43e71c
"}]
commit_message:
Only add logging handlers if there currently aren't any

This corrects an odd problem where Horizon would stand up multiple
client objects, which would cause duplicate/triplicate/dozens of
repeated log lines in its log files, due to multiple identical
handlers being added to the logging object

Fixes Bug 1182678

Change-Id: I020b3999c9008b996286ccb74a7801c96c43e71c

commit_message:
Parse user hosts correctly in get and delete user

Inspect the request environment to find the end of user hostnames
that had been snipped off by the route mapper.

fixes bug #1178330

Change-Id: Ic5944be16b44545db0405e59c4643765ec069e0d

Capitalize boolean values in config files

This patch allows the usage of Puppet boolean values and still
configure values with OpenStack boolean style: True/False.

Change-Id: I1f96bf979e67fd7fb8fd1d984809fd072783224c

commit_message:
use fauxhai 1.1.0 for opensuse platform support

also had to update chefspec, because chefspec 1.0.0 has a strict version
requirement on fauxhai 0.1

set specific version in spec_helper: newer fauxhai complains otherwise

Change-Id: I855a15eff83de75c1f611c614e628c917f279538

commit_message:
Renamed keystone_registration recipe

Renamed keystone_registration to identity_registration, and added
identity_registration tests.  Added registration tests to simply
test the args being passed to the `openstack_identity_register` LWRP.
The identity LWRP should be tested at a deeper level than the consumers.

Testing args passed to a DSL (&block) is a bit tricky. The tests
are not ideal, but give us the necessary coverage to catch common
errors.

Fixes: Bug 1182574
Change-Id: I4794e555133852cfbacd407dc726c6b65ecdef65

revisions:
[{'created': '2013-05-22 16:31:36.000000000', 'message': 'Raise VolumeNotFound with correct volume_id

Make sure VolumeNotFound is raised with the correct volume_id
in the SolidFire driver. Some exceptions were wrongfully referring
to an undefined variable named uuid.

Fixes: bug #1182966
Change-Id: Ied101fc9778f51dfb74b39f466c2c13d6e775a40
'}]
commit_message:
Raise VolumeNotFound with correct volume_id

Make sure VolumeNotFound is raised with the correct volume_id
in the SolidFire driver. Some exceptions were wrongfully referring
to an undefined variable named uuid.

Fixes: bug #1182966

commit_message:
Make it easier to add namespaced rpc APIs.

Add an additional argument to the base create_rpc_dispatcher() method.
When a manager wants to override create_rpc_dispatcher() to add more
callbacks in their own rpc namespaces, it can just call the parent class
with the additional APIs to include.

Change-Id: I9cba8b176b35f55ba9d71365d0a8bf25d2ae311f

Fix double "host" option.

Remove the "host" option from the netconf.py because it's conflicting
with the "host" option specified in the common/service.py.

commit_message:
Fix small logo spacing issue

Slightly adjust combo.css so that it doesn't make the OpenStack
logo appear a few pixels too low. This makes the release status
page appear even more like the rest of the status.o.o pages.

Change-Id: I18b779c96e657b6a0b1482b95771670c10a18b6d

Tested-by: Jenkins

commit_message:
vnics: don't presume existence of filterref/filter

With quantum/ovs plugin, there is no necessarily a "filteref" in interface param.
If not present don't lookup the "filter", let it to None and no more use
vnics.fref as resource_id.
resource_id becomes : instance_name + instance_uuid + vnic_name

fix Bug #1180466

Change-Id: I21c15f9ee4bd5303a7f2e287c7fe69aa7d0d5b0a

commit_message:
Add sphinxcontrib-pecanwsme

Ceilometer had a Sphinx extension in our
code tree that we use to auto-generate
the API documentation from the Pecan/WSME
code. That extension is being moved to
a separate package so other projects can
use it more easily, and so we now need
the package added to the requirements list.

The change to use the package in ceilometer is
https://review.openstack.org/29148.

Change-Id: I07ad3a12c7420feeb6296e1b6ad982a910bbc03d
Signed-off-by: Doug Hellmann <doug.hellmann@dreamhost.com>

[{'created': '2013-05-22 14:46:01.000000000', 'message': "Recycle IPs used by 'gateway' ports

Bug 1182602

Previous code simply removed IP allocation for these ports which
should never have an IP. This patch triggers IP recycling so the
IP addresses can be reused by other ports.

Change-Id: I594e02d5bbc78b219eab07e595cde713d6450ffe
"}]
commit_message:
Recycle IPs used by 'gateway' ports

Bug 1182602

Previous code simply removed IP allocation for these ports which
should never have an IP. This patch triggers IP recycling so the
IP addresses can be reused by other ports.

Change-Id: I594e02d5bbc78b219eab07e595cde713d6450ffe

commit_message:
Revert "Fix ./run_tests.sh --pep8"

We are explicitly trying to get rid of scripts like this and flake8 makes
this one non-necessary.
Fix run_tests.sh to run flake8 properly.

This reverts commit 42243d6eb221d52bf6f62f835726cbe026e43447

Change-Id: I435e34b6acde7931a75f456ccc88da6476581643

commit_message:
Catch InstanceNotFound in instance_actions GET

Catch the InstanceNotFound exception in the instance_actions
index function and handle the error gracefully so a stacktrace is
not generated in the log files. This patch does not change the
API

Fixes bug 1182867

Change-Id: I0764f8abda7176deefe0d103bd86acd0af78780d

revisions:
[{'created': '2013-05-21 16:31:28.000000000', 'message': 'Accept env variables to override default passwords

Preserves the default passwords corresponding to the OpenStack Install
and Deploy Manual while allowing environment variables to specify user
provided passwords. As well, a single common password for all the service
users can be specified using the SERVICE_PASSWORD environment variable.

This fix restores compatibility with the version of this script released
in Folsom where the environment variables could override default passwords.
It also preserves compatibility with the fix for bug 1073291 that brought
the script into line with the docs (but unfortunately broke backwards
compatibility).

There is no warning emited if the user does not override the default
passwords as was present in Folsom, but not in Grizzly. This makes the
fix output compatible with Grizzly only. Note that the logic for warnings
pre-Grizzly was unclear. The script is, however, clearly named "sample"
and warnings are present in the comments.

Change-Id: I927fcddf04dcb87e5c9252f0874939b17f3c4809
Fixes: bug #1166182
'}]
commit_message:
Accept env variables to override default passwords

Preserves the default passwords corresponding to the OpenStack Install
and Deploy Manual while allowing environment variables to specify user
provided passwords. As well, a single common password for all the service
users can be specified using the SERVICE_PASSWORD environment variable.

This fix restores compatibility with the version of this script released
in Folsom where the environment variables could override default passwords.
It also preserves compatibility with the fix for bug 1073291 that brought
the script into line with the docs (but unfortunately broke backwards
compatibility).

There is no warning emited if the user does not override the default
passwords as was present in Folsom, but not in Grizzly. This makes the
fix output compatible with Grizzly only. Note that the logic for warnings
pre-Grizzly was unclear. The script is, however, clearly named "sample"
and warnings are present in the comments.

Change-Id: I927fcddf04dcb87e5c9252f0874939b17f3c4809
Fixes: bug #1166182

revisions:
[{'created': '2013-05-16 13:11:11.000000000', 'message': 'Add msgpack as a dependency

Ceilometer will use msgpack for encoding data in, at least, its UDP
based transport.

msgpack is distributed under the Apache Software License. It seems to
support Python 3, and is already packaged for Debian, Ubuntu, Fedora,
and probably a lot more OSes.

Change-Id: I35ceb44046fe3faaa7aebf9a6e1f173acc7b1c02
Signed-off-by: Julien Danjou <julien@danjou.info>
'}]
commit_message:
Add msgpack as a dependency

Ceilometer will use msgpack for encoding data in, at least, its UDP
based transport.

msgpack is distributed under the Apache Software License. It seems to
support Python 3, and is already packaged for Debian, Ubuntu, Fedora,
and probably a lot more OSes.

Change-Id: I35ceb44046fe3faaa7aebf9a6e1f173acc7b1c02
Signed-off-by: Julien Danjou <julien@danjou.info>

revisions:
[{'created': '2013-05-16 08:00:34.000000000', 'message': 'Change the implementation of is_uuid_like() as nova does

I found isalnum() doesn't allow "-" while for UUID,
format like aaaaaaaa-aaaa-aaaa-aaaa-aaaaaaaaaaaa is allowed.

Change-Id: I339974c75a32d27f8e4443a1b97bb6e410933aa4
Signed-off-by: Shane Wang <shane.wang@intel.com>
'}, {'created': '2013-05-18 06:57:33.000000000', 'message': 'Reuse oslo for is_uuid_like() implementation

In the original code, isalnum() in is_uuid_like() doesn't allow "-",
while for UUID, format like aaaaaaaa-aaaa-aaaa-aaaa-aaaaaaaaaaaa should be
allowed. This patch is to reuse uuidutils's API in oslo.

commit_message:
Reuse oslo for is_uuid_like() implementation

In the original code, isalnum() in is_uuid_like() doesn't allow "-",
while for UUID, format like aaaaaaaa-aaaa-aaaa-aaaa-aaaaaaaaaaaa should be
allowed. This patch is to reuse uuidutils's API in oslo.

Change-Id: I339974c75a32d27f8e4443a1b97bb6e410933aa4
Signed-off-by: Shane Wang <shane.wang@intel.com>

commit_message:
set ERROR state when scheduler hits max attempts

Presently when scheduler raises NoValidHost due to max attempts
being reached, the instance remains in a build state.
Exception handler for NoValidHost in manager.run_instance() needs
request_spec[instance_uuids] to know which host to put into an
error state in _set_vm_state_and_notify().
schedule_run_instances() was popping instance_uuids from the
request_spec prior to a call to _schedule().
Changed pop of instance_uuids prior to call to _schedule() to be a get.
Added pop of instance_uuids to beneath call to _schedule() as
individual creates do not need them.

Change-Id: I9654820e01d5611763e9e673f15f46b947d09e6d
Fixes: bug #1182056

These objects are going out of scope anyway. i suppose a logging .debug? i only like adding debug lines if I plan on using them for some purpose- which I don't think I would do in this case."}, {'account_id': 6198, 'date': '2013-05-21 21:29:14.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 4:

Sorry, not looking for logging, just looking to not use "except Exception", but something like:

    try:
        do.something()
    except OSError as e:
        if e.errno not in squelch_errno_set:
            raise

Does that make sense? And not for just OSError, but IOError, or whatever common exception class would be raised here (socketerror, etc.).'}, {'account_id': 2696, 'date': '2013-05-22 01:48:19.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 4: Looks good to me (core reviewer)

lgtm (the scope of those try/except blocks don't bother me wrt accidentally swallowing exceptions we might otherwise want bubbled up)."}, {'account_id': 1216, 'date': '2013-05-22 12:29:25.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 4: Looks good to me (core reviewer); Approved

This seems like a reasonable use-case for "except Exception".

The code is in the private method _exception_occurred which is called by other class methods when they want to log a blanket exception they're swallowing.

The code is doing some last-ditch-effort at faster cleanup and, if it fails, things are no worse off than they would've been otherwise.

If we set a list of known exception classes and known errnos, it'll just be annoying to keep updating them when, honestly, we don't care if .close() fails, we'd just like to give it a chance to succeed.

And the callers of this private method would then have to wrap the call with another "try: except Exception:" since their whole goal is to keep on keeping on unless there's a catastrophic coding error.

There is a "useless pass" in the test code; but, eh... ;-)'}, {'account_id': 3, 'date': '2013-05-22 12:29:26.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 4: No score

Starting gate jobs.
http://status.openstack.org/zuul/'}, {'account_id': 3, 'date': '2013-05-22 13:12:14.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 4: Verified

'}, {'account_id': 2835, 'date': '2013-05-15 13:41:22.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1: I would prefer that you didn't merge this

How about this instead?:

1) Make get_instance_nw_info not update calls at all, in any case.
2) In the _heal periodic task, get the network info and send an explicit message to cells to update the instance's info cache.

This way you can get rid of the update_cells kwarg everywhere and the call for what you're trying to accomplish is explicit.  Right now the _heal task is calling self._get_instance_nw_info, which happens to update cells as a side effect."}, {'account_id': 1030, 'date': '2013-05-15 21:50:35.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

Ah shoot.  That's exactly what I wanted to do for the trunk review, but forgot."}, {'account_id': 1030, 'date': '2013-05-15 21:54:01.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

Oh wait... that's what this review does, if I understood you correctly.  The network_api call 'get_instance_nw_info' doesn't take the update_cells arg.  But it uses it (with False value) when calling DB API or conductor.  So, every call to get_instance_nw_info() no longer updates cells.  Not sure I can simplify it any further because the conductor call is 'update_instance_info_cache' and I want it to update cells for most cases, but not the 'get_instance_nw_info' case."}, {'account_id': 2835, 'date': '2013-05-15 22:07:53.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1: No score

I was suggesting dropping the automatic cells update code from DB API altogether.  Then just call cells explicitly to do the update when the heal task runs.

Is there a use case I'm missing?  I was thinking maybe we could avoid putting 'update_cells' everywhere, at least in this case."}, {'account_id': 2835, 'date': '2013-05-15 22:08:45.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

(The heal task would just call cells directly and not _get_instance_nw_info)'}, {'account_id': 1030, 'date': '2013-05-15 23:51:59.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

Oh, gotcha.  Well, when interfaces are added/removed, I do need those updates to hit cells.  And the main point of this is the drop the info_cache healing from hitting cells at all...  because the cells healing itself takes care of it.  Your suggestion still works for what I want, though.  Ie, I just remove the update completely from DB/API and I add explicit calls to cells to update where networks are modified.'}, {'account_id': 1030, 'date': '2013-05-17 21:14:28.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Work In Progress'}, {'account_id': 1030, 'date': '2013-05-22 06:07:22.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 2.'}, {'account_id': 1030, 'date': '2013-05-22 06:09:57.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 3.'}, {'account_id': 1030, 'date': '2013-05-22 06:11:03.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3:

This is much more simple now. :)'}, {'account_id': 4395, 'date': '2013-05-22 06:41:52.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3: Looks good to me, but someone else must approve

'}, {'account_id': 3, 'date': '2013-05-22 07:00:35.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3: Works for me

commit_message:
Don't update API cell on get_nwinfo

Every call to get_instance_nw_info() updates an instance's info_cache.
The purpose of this is to make sure we're constantly healing the
info_cache table.  However, this causes a lot of unneeded updates
traveling up to the API cell.  Cells has its own periodic task that
heals all instance data.

Fixes bug 1180304

Change-Id: I07774712a6358999fd1fdd0f5a90c6f05e3d8d6e

revisions:
[{'created': '2013-05-22 08:25:47.000000000', 'message': 'Remove unrelated tracebacks from test output

This mocks some calls the ThreadGroup when testing update and delete of
the stack, resulting in tracebacks when the threads randomly run later
on in the test suite.

Change-Id: Ia1a376933c2e25b6cf0fe6a26f47e381cbb1a55e
Fixes: bug #1182285
'}]
commit_message:
Remove unrelated tracebacks from test output

This mocks some calls the ThreadGroup when testing update and delete of
the stack, resulting in tracebacks when the threads randomly run later
on in the test suite.

Change-Id: Ia1a376933c2e25b6cf0fe6a26f47e381cbb1a55e
Fixes: bug #1182285

revisions:
[{'created': '2013-04-26 23:36:58.000000000', 'message': 'Remove glance-control from the test suite

This patch removes the use of glance-control from the test suite. Instead
of forking out glance-control and letting it fork out the other programs,
we will now fork out the other programs directly. The file which tested
glance-control has also been removed.  While we will still have
glance-control as part of the distribution for a bit and thus it should
still be tested, that test was doing so in a way that depended upon the
forking behavior previously found in the test suite.

This patch also requires the patch
https://review.openstack.org/#/c/26076/ on which it is dependent. As a
side effect it tests for the problem found in bug: 1068051

fixes bug: 1173415
blueprint: refactoring-better-faster-stronger-functional-tests

Change-Id: Iabdb6fdc13b5f1993590b5a801a0e89df1a544c7
'}, {'created': '2013-04-29 23:56:21.000000000', 'message': 'Remove glance-control from the test suite

This patch removes the use of glance-control from the test suite. Instead
of forking out glance-control and letting it fork out the other programs,
we will now fork out the other programs directly. The file which tested
glance-control has also been removed.  While we will still have
glance-control as part of the distribution for a bit and thus it should
still be tested, that test was doing so in a way that depended upon the
forking behavior previously found in the test suite.

This patch also requires the patch
https://review.openstack.org/#/c/26076/ on which it is dependent. As a
side effect it tests for the problem found in bug: 1068051

Additionally, this fixes a race condition.  Previously each functional
test called cleanup() in tearDown().  Cleanup would open a pid file and
send a SIGTERM to the processes (api, registry, scrubber).  However,
it did not wait for this process to die and get cleaned up.  The signal
handler in the processes is over ridden so the death is not instant.
This leaves a chance for server from a previous test to be actively
listening on a port when the next test starts.

fixes bug: 1173415
blueprint: refactoring-better-faster-stronger-functional-tests

Change-Id: Iabdb6fdc13b5f1993590b5a801a0e89df1a544c7

forking behavior previously found in the test suite.

This patch also requires the patch
https://review.openstack.org/#/c/26076/ on which it is dependent. As a
side effect it tests for the problem found in bug: 1068051

Additionally, this fixes a race condition. Previously each functional
test called cleanup() in tearDown(). Cleanup would open a pid file and
send a SIGTERM to the processes (api, registry, scrubber). However,
it did not wait for this process to die and get cleaned up. The signal
handler in the processes is over ridden so the death is not instant.
This leaves a chance for server from a previous test to be actively
listening on a port when the next test starts.

fixes bug: 1173415
blueprint: refactoring-better-faster-stronger-functional-tests

Change-Id: Iabdb6fdc13b5f1993590b5a801a0e89df1a544c7

commit_message:
Remove glance-control from the test suite

This patch removes the use of glance-control from the test suite. Instead
of forking out glance-control and letting it fork out the other programs,
we will now fork out the other programs directly. The file which tested
glance-control has also been removed. While we will still have
glance-control as part of the distribution for a bit and thus it should
still be tested, that test was doing so in a way that depended upon the
forking behavior previously found in the test suite.

This patch also requires the patch
https://review.openstack.org/#/c/26076/ on which it is dependent. As a
side effect it tests for the problem found in bug: 1068051

Additionally, this fixes a race condition. Previously each functional
test called cleanup() in tearDown(). Cleanup would open a pid file and
send a SIGTERM to the processes (api, registry, scrubber). However,
it did not wait for this process to die and get cleaned up. The signal
handler in the processes is over ridden so the death is not instant.
This leaves a chance for server from a previous test to be actively
listening on a port when the next test starts.

fixes bug: 1173415
blueprint: refactoring-better-faster-stronger-functional-tests

Change-Id: Iabdb6fdc13b5f1993590b5a801a0e89df1a544c7

commit_message:
Access to heat API via python-heatclient

This adds python-heatclient as a dependency and a simple function
to get a client reference.

Required for blueprint: heat-ui

Change-Id: I5f7d8c7c17f6e78d3f88cc39d50826416b48ad2c

subject: Avoid error 414 when retrieving subnet cidrs for ListNetworks
reviewers: [{'_account_id': 3, 'name': 'Jenkins', 'username': 'jenkins'}, {'_account_id': 261, 'name': 'Salvatore Orlando', 'email': 'salv.orlando@gmail.com', 'username': 'salvatore-orlando'}, {'_account_id': 748, 'name': 'Armando Migliaccio', 'email': 'armamig@gmail.com', 'username': 'armando-migliaccio'}, {'_account_id': 1653, 'name': 'garyk', 'email': 'gkotton@vmware.com', 'username': 'garyk'}, {'_account_id': 2592, 'name': 'Mark McClain', 'email': 'mark@mcclain.xyz', 'username': 'markmcclain'}, {'_account_id': 2874, 'name': 'yong sheng gong', 'email': 'gong.yongsheng@99cloud.net', 'username': 'gongysh'}, {'_account_id': 4395, 'name': 'Aaron Rosen', 'email': 'aaronorosen@gmail.com', 'username': 'arosen'}]

'}, {'account_id': 261, 'date': '2013-05-22 08:58:37.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: (1 inline comment)

'}, {'account_id': 261, 'date': '2013-05-22 08:58:37.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

For a post, we will need to change the quantum API in order to avoid building a long query string.

We do not have at the moment a mechanism for storing filter criteria in the request body, and I'm not sure we want to provision such a kind of mechanism.
Also, I don't want to go into REST semantics, but POSTs are typically used for storing data; this is however a minor point, since we could also have a GET with a body.

I agree if one ends up with a very large URI something is fishy. In this case the mechanism of filtering subnets by ids for retrieving cidrs is fishy; nevertheless this is still a lot better than fetching subnets one by one.
There are a few things we can do to solve this problem, like expanding responses for GET /network to include more info about dependent subnets; or, as said earlier, allow for building filters in the body.
However, we are in a situation where with a little bit more than 200 networks we hit the 414 error on net-list; this is fairly serious IMHO and should be fixed asap.
We can then remove this code once we have a better soluton."}, {'account_id': 261, 'date': '2013-05-22 08:58:37.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: (3 inline comments)

commit_message:
Avoid error 414 when retrieving subnet cidrs for ListNetworks

Bug 1172537

In order to avoif 414 the list subnet requests will be split in
multiple requests. The total URI len for each of these requests
will be lower than 8K (the default maximum for eventlet.wsgi.server).
The patch tries to submit a single request, and if the URI is too
long an exception is raised before the request is sent over the
wire; the exception handler will split the subnet id list, and
submit the new requests.

This patch does not address the case in which the server is
configured with a maximum URI length different from 8K.

Change-Id: Ia2414cd5374a91d3d12215807037a5d46b836ad6

[{'created': '2013-05-19 10:44:15.000000000', 'message': 'Shows a warning message when deleting a container that contains data.

We cannot delete objects in the container since there may be millions
of objects in that. The batch deletion should be done in swift instead
of Horizon. The batch remove of objects function is only in swift CLI
command now. This commit replace the unclear message with a warning
message that tells the user the container is not empy.

Related bug: https://bugs.launchpad.net/horizon/+bug/1034890

Fixes bug: #1096084

Change-Id: I59b46a3535b8654734c3dae4eec916ab1b53c716
'}]
commit_message:
Shows a warning message when deleting a container that contains data.

We cannot delete objects in the container since there may be millions
of objects in that. The batch deletion should be done in swift instead
of Horizon. The batch remove of objects function is only in swift CLI
command now. This commit replace the unclear message with a warning
message that tells the user the container is not empy.

Related bug: https://bugs.launchpad.net/horizon/+bug/1034890

Fixes bug: #1096084

Change-Id: I59b46a3535b8654734c3dae4eec916ab1b53c716

commit_message:
Refactored the templates code

Created generic template _workflow_base.html
in horizon/templates/horizon/common folder
with 'workflow.name' to replace multiple nearly
identical templates with different titles.

Implements blueprint dry-templates

Change-Id: Ieb14e263381020ed6604149ff9295f8cc814a9e6

commit_message:
Log a warning if dnsmasq version is below the minimum required

It has been noted that older versions of dnsmasq may have unexpected
behavior, so this patch introduces a check on dnsmasq version; if
the minimum version is not met, a warning is logged. This is less
invasive than raising an Exception and abort the dhcp agent, even
though this also seems like a perfectly acceptable behavior.

Fixes bug 1170793

(cherry picked from commit 364032897293256436647cb89c61a3dffb408946)

Aforementioned cherry-pick has sudo issues hence the additional one
(cherry picked from commit 91b56e41eecf2cd8b4c848b4e773a1be307b40c3)

Change-Id: I8475afc6bdd6145d2a491177af080fee960cb3e6

Since (IMHO) the pressure is off a little on the quantum db thing, how about trying other ideas:

  cfg.StrOpt('sql_connection',
             default=....
             deprecated_opts=[
                 cfg.DeprecatedOpt('sql_connection'),
                 cfg.DeprecatedOpt('connection', group='sql'),
             ])


the reason I suggest that is you could imagine in future:

  class NewStyleSqlConnectionOpt(cfg.DeprecatedOpt):

      def __init__(self):
          super(NewStyleSqlConnectionOpt, self).__init__('sql_connection', 'DEFAULT')

      def transform_value(self, value):
          if value.startswith('sql:'):
              return 'sqlalchemy:' + value[4:]
          else:
              return value

(fairly random example, but you get the idea)

At first I was thinking I'd prefer deprecated_opts to be a list of tuples (what else would we ever want other than name/group) but then flipped the other way to wanting a full class when I thought of the use case of transforming from a legacy option format"}, {'account_id': 5638, 'date': '2013-05-20 19:13:51.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 3.'}, {'account_id': 3, 'date': '2013-05-20 19:14:46.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 3: Doesn't seem to work

commit_message:
Allow Multiple sets of deprecated name/group for options

We currently allow just one name/group for deprecation. For adoption
of oslo db by multiple projects, we need to be able to specify
multiple sets of deprecated name/group.

For example connection is defined as follows in various
projects and we need to be able specify all the combinations
for being able to upgrade from Grizzly to Havana

Nova: Section - DEFAULT; Key - sql_connection
Cinder: Section - DEFAULT; Key - sql_connection
Glance: Section - DEFAULT; Key - sql_connection
Quantum: Section - DATABASE; key - sql_connection
Keystone: Section - SQL; key - connection

Please see discussion on the dev mailing list and on the
review - https://review.openstack.org/#/c/27345 for
oslo-incubator

Change-Id: I8c2097275242a4fdbd4f0f9fb4e293d1ba793d16

commit_message:
Always return a list from VolumeTableMixIn._get*

Returning None from these methods leads to TypeError
(None is not iterable)

Fixes: bug #1182075
Change-Id: Ia5f5fe78669bbaed599b7dd5cae1beb69bde7796

revisions:
[{'created': '2013-05-20 15:37:42.000000000', 'message': 'Fix resize when instance has no image

This patch makes it possible to resize an instance that has no image
supplied (was booted from volume), by avoiding calling the image service
and thus causing an uncaught exception, if there was no image suplied in
the first place.

Fixes bug: 1182114
blueprint: improve-boot-from-volume

Change-Id: I67d63a7aef699b555897582c74b04e857db7aafb
'}]
commit_message:
Fix resize when instance has no image

This patch makes it possible to resize an instance that has no image
supplied (was booted from volume), by avoiding calling the image service
and thus causing an uncaught exception, if there was no image suplied in
the first place.

Fixes bug: 1182114
blueprint: improve-boot-from-volume

Change-Id: I67d63a7aef699b555897582c74b04e857db7aafb

revisions:
[{'created': '2013-05-15 19:45:41.000000000', 'message': 'Make discovery of version for KS catalog smarter.

Instead of relying on the configuration file for determining how
the catalog should be parsed, make it flexible by inspecting the
structure of the service catalog passed to it.

Fixes bug 1180486

Change-Id: I0c8caf4c8365bf25377ab3a249ac280d8add0f17
'}]
commit_message:
Make discovery of version for KS catalog smarter.

Instead of relying on the configuration file for determining how
the catalog should be parsed, make it flexible by inspecting the
structure of the service catalog passed to it.

Fixes bug 1180486

Change-Id: I0c8caf4c8365bf25377ab3a249ac280d8add0f17

commit_message:
parse_isotime filter to parse a date string.

This then allows the resulting date value to be piped
to one of the standard django date/time format filters

This is identical to oslo timeutils parse_isotime, but annotated with
@register.filter

Required for blueprint: heat-ui

Change-Id: Ibecca77d50bb5c0df59e07e9572069215229f60a

Nexus 5K and 7K switches require the 'vlan active' and 'no shutdown' VLAN configuration (these settings are not defaulted on these switches)."}, {'account_id': 6695, 'date': '2013-05-22 06:51:45.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2:

@garyk, re. unit test case:
The config that I'm modifying is part of some canned XML config (with some string substitutions) that we're just piping out to a Nexus switch via a NetConf client (ncclient).  The distinction between VLAN ranges comes from the Nexus switch itself. Note that the nexus plugin unit test cases are currently designed to be run without a Nexus switch by mocking out the NetConf client (so that a Nexus switch isn't required to run the unit tests).

I had thought about adding a unit test case to confirm that the 2 config lines that I'm deleting from this canned XML config do not show up as the canned config is passed to the ncclient, but I didn't think this would be very productive (as we're just piping the canned config). Also, I don't think this is a unit test that we'd want to keep around (someone a year from now might wonder why we're testing for the absence of some commands in the XML config passed to ncclient)."}, {'account_id': 3, 'date': '2013-05-22 06:51:45.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3: Works for me

revisions:
[{'created': '2013-05-22 06:51:45.000000000', 'message': 'Fix Cisco Nexus plugin failures for vlan IDs 1006-4094

Fixes bug 1174593

VLAN IDs in the range 1006-4094 are considered to be in the extended
range by the Cisco Nexus 3K switch. As such, the 3K rejects any
state change configuration commands for VLANs in this range, including
"state active" and "no shutdown". The errors returned by the 3K for
these commands can be ignored, since the default states for these commands
are acceptable for the 3K.

For the 5K and 7K versions of the Nexus switch, on the other hand, the
"state active" and "no shutdown" commands are required for proper VLAN
configuration, regardless of VLAN ID.

This fix splits the configuration commands which are used to create a
VLAN on the Nexus switch into three separate configurations:
  - VLAN creation
  - state active
  - no shutdown
For the "state active" and "no shutdown" configurations, the Cisco Nexus
plugin will tolerate (ignore) errors involving invalid setting of state
for VLANs in the extended VLAN range. These specific errors can be
identified by looking for the appearance of certain signature strings
in the associated exception's representation string, i.e. "Can't modify
state for extended" or "Command is allowed on VLAN".

This approach will yield a very small hit in performance, but the solution
is much less error prone than requiring customers to configure the
Cisco plugin for 3K vs. 5K vs. 7K, or perhaps even specific software
versions of the 3K, in order to inform the Cisco plugin whether
VLAN state configuration commands should be used or not.

Change-Id: I1be4966ddc6f462bca38428c4f904f8c982f318f
'}, {'created': '2013-05-22 06:51:45.000000000', 'message': 'Cisco nexus plugin fails for vlan IDs 1006-4094

Fixes bug 1174593

VLAN IDs in the range 1006-4094 are considered to be in the extended
range by the Cisco Nexus switch. As such, the switch rejects any
state change configuraion commands for VLANs in this range, including
"state active" and "no shutdown". This fix removes the "state active"
and "no shutdown" command lines from the config snippet used to
configure VLANs on the switches, regardless of VLAN ID. It is safe
to remove these commands for VLAN IDs which are not in the extended
range, since these are the default settings when VLANs are configured
on the switch, and the Cisco Nexus plugin never changes VLANs
into the suspended or shutdown states.

Change-Id: I1be4966ddc6f462bca38428c4f904f8c982f318f
'}, {'created': '2013-05-22 06:51:45.000000000', 'message': 'Cisco nexus plugin fails for vlan IDs 1006-4094

Fixes bug 1174593

Change-Id: I1be4966ddc6f462bca38428c4f904f8c982f318f

versions of the 3K, in order to inform the Cisco plugin whether
VLAN state configuration commands should be used or not.

Change-Id: I1be4966ddc6f462bca38428c4f904f8c982f318f

commit_message:
Fix Cisco Nexus plugin failures for vlan IDs 1006-4094

Fixes bug 1174593

VLAN IDs in the range 1006-4094 are considered to be in the extended
range by the Cisco Nexus 3K switch. As such, the 3K rejects any
state change configuration commands for VLANs in this range, including
"state active" and "no shutdown". The errors returned by the 3K for
these commands can be ignored, since the default states for these commands
are acceptable for the 3K.

For the 5K and 7K versions of the Nexus switch, on the other hand, the
"state active" and "no shutdown" commands are required for proper VLAN
configuration, regardless of VLAN ID.

This fix splits the configuration commands which are used to create a
VLAN on the Nexus switch into three separate configurations:
  - VLAN creation
  - state active
  - no shutdown
For the "state active" and "no shutdown" configurations, the Cisco Nexus
plugin will tolerate (ignore) errors involving invalid setting of state
for VLANs in the extended VLAN range. These specific errors can be
identified by looking for the appearance of certain signature strings
in the associated exception's message string, i.e. "Can't modify
state for extended" or "Command is allowed on VLAN".

This approach will yield a very small hit in performance, but the solution
is much less error prone than requiring customers to configure the
Cisco plugin for 3K vs. 5K vs. 7K, or perhaps even specific software
versions of the 3K, in order to inform the Cisco plugin whether
VLAN state configuration commands should be used or not.

Change-Id: I1be4966ddc6f462bca38428c4f904f8c982f318f

This patch adds support for mount options for NFS/GlusterFS volumes.

To set options, append them to the line for the volume in the
nfs_shares_config or glusterfs_shares_config file:
 192.168.175.166:/testvol -o backupvolfile-server=192.168.175.177
 host1:/testvol2 -o backupvolfile-server=host2,rw,other_option

These options are used when mounting from the cinder-volume
service and the nova-compute service.  (There is an associated
nova-compute patch to enable the same.)

This is a useful change for GlusterFS because the
backupvolfile-server option enables a mount to succeed even if
the first server specified is offline.

commit_message:
Support mount options for NFS/GlusterFS volumes

This patch adds support for mount options for NFS/GlusterFS volumes.

To set options, append them to the line for the volume in the
nfs_shares_config or glusterfs_shares_config file:
 192.168.175.166:/testvol -o backupvolfile-server=192.168.175.177
 host1:/testvol2 -o backupvolfile-server=host2,rw,other_option

These options are used when mounting from the cinder-volume
service and the nova-compute service.  (There is an associated
nova-compute patch to enable the same.)

This is a useful change for GlusterFS because the
backupvolfile-server option enables a mount to succeed even if
the first server specified is offline.

Change-Id: I13bb0a930d6a05e803ccb50e6dc5d4b2b412ac11

I'm worried about putting the instance into an error state in this situation.   Once the delete has been accepted into the system Nova really needs to honour that from the users perspective - and make sure for example that the state is clear enough that a billing system can always recognize instances that are on thier way to oblivion.   Billing users for instances that they want to (but can't delete), or holding quotas against them, is poor behaviour.

The API layer today deleted the instance if it detects the host is down, and trusts the host to clean up on restart.  Why can't this case be covered in a similar way - delete the instance and let a periodic task clean up libvirt when it comes back ?"}, {'account_id': 7407, 'date': '2013-04-29 13:56:28.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 3.'}, {'account_id': 3, 'date': '2013-04-29 14:40:10.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 3: Doesn't seem to work

Previous comments still stand - and haven't seen any response

I'm worried about putting the instance into an error state in this situation. Once the delete has been accepted into the system Nova really needs to honour that from the users perspective - and make sure for example that the state is clear enough that a billing system can always recognize instances that are on thier way to oblivion. Billing users for instances that they want to (but can't delete), or holding quotas against them, is poor behaviour.
The API layer today deleted the instance if it detects the host is down, and trusts the host to clean up on restart. Why can't this case be covered in a similar way - delete the instance and let a periodic task clean up libvirt when it comes back ?"}, {'account_id': 9, 'date': '2013-05-09 06:03:04.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 4:

commit_message:
Added verification for libvirt availability in driver.

  Added check for libvirt connection availability in
  nova.virt.libvirt.LibvirtDriver.destroy method, which
  raises new LibvirtNotAvailableException.

  Also in nova.compute.manager.ComputeManager._delete_instance
  added except block for LibvirtNotAvailableException, where
  instance's status in setted to 'error'.

  If libvirt service is unavailable and user wants to terminate
  an instance the instance gets vm_status 'error' instead of
  infinite task_status 'deleting' and vm_status 'active'.

  Fixes LP bug #966087

Change-Id: I80ec5c68946deed60f2091ac6025028899f1f991

This feels pretty hacky at best. 

I think this feature makes sense to have, but would belong under a set of APIs for leveraging the shadow table/archiving functionality in nova. Granted, that would be a lot more work to implement, but it would also be nice to have an admin API extension to trigger db archiving and possible even doing it lazily when someone does a look up on a soft deleted entry like your use case.'}, {'account_id': 5441, 'date': '2013-05-14 20:10:42.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 3: I would prefer that you didn't merge this

I agree with Matthew that this would work better in an extension.  I think there are two things that should be considered:

Ideally, grabbing deleted instances would take the shadow tables into account.  That way this feature just works and doesn't depend on understanding the policies on archiving data.

Also, I would rather see this as an optional capability per call.  This could greatly increase the list of returned servers for all queries by a user, whether they need them or not.  Policies aren't very dynamic and are therefore probably not the best toggle for this."}, {'account_id': 9, 'date': '2013-05-22 06:03:05.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3: Abandoned

As instances are soft deleted, instance data may still be
    available in the database. This feature allows users to
    retrieve this data if it's available. As it is implemented
    as a policy, it can be restricted to only certain users/roles.

When enabled, a show call on a deleted instance will return
    what data is available instead of a 404 Not Found. If the
    soft deleted data is purged from the database, a 404 Not Found
    will be returned to the user.

When disabled, a show call on a deleted instance will maintain
    it's normal behavior, thus returning a 404 Not Found.

DocImpact

Implements bp show-deleted-instances

Change-Id: If9e1f2fe1d7d7691a13aaa0d7c45dc126bee64c7

commit_message:
Add policy to enable showing of deleted instances

As instances are soft deleted, instance data may still be
    available in the database. This feature allows users to
    retrieve this data if it's available. As it is implemented
    as a policy, it can be restricted to only certain users/roles.

When enabled, a show call on a deleted instance will return
    what data is available instead of a 404 Not Found. If the
    soft deleted data is purged from the database, a 404 Not Found
    will be returned to the user.

When disabled, a show call on a deleted instance will maintain
    it's normal behavior, thus returning a 404 Not Found.

DocImpact

Implements bp show-deleted-instances

Change-Id: If9e1f2fe1d7d7691a13aaa0d7c45dc126bee64c7

[{'created': '2013-05-10 16:17:10.000000000', 'message': 'Added region affinity to proxy server

The proxy server now is made aware of its location by the configuration
setting "region" if this is not set changes dont affect the behaviour.
The affinity is useful for when two regions exist which have a high latency.
When the region is set to "2", the proxy pushes all nodes which are in the
region 2 to the top and are thus tried first.

Usecase:
Region 1: Asia
Region 2: Europe
Proxy in Europe

Default behaviour is that a random node is selected. Thus sometimes the
proxy selects the asian server. This causes latencies and not needed inter-
continental traffic.

Change-Id: I851b5dc12b9d7895635f5d53dd5b023737bded7b

commit_message:
Added region affinity to proxy server

The proxy server now is made aware of its location by the configuration
setting "region" if this is not set changes dont affect the behaviour.
The affinity is useful for when two regions exist which have a high latency.
When the region is set to "2", the proxy pushes all nodes which are in the
region 2 to the top and are thus tried first.

Usecase:
Region 1: Asia
Region 2: Europe
Proxy in Europe

Default behaviour is that a random node is selected. Thus sometimes the
proxy selects the asian server. This causes latencies and not needed inter-
continental traffic.

Change-Id: I851b5dc12b9d7895635f5d53dd5b023737bded7b

'}, {'account_id': 1179, 'date': '2013-04-26 02:22:19.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 4:

So... This is not a trivial change.  I keep thinking, man... we're going to be calling "get_info" a lot more now?  I know we can get bottlenecked getting into heavily loaded container... so, what's the performance impact here?  

I only have a few "fixed work loads" to compare?

functests:
before:  1380 calls to get_info
after: 6858 calls to get info

one replication run (after one func test run):
before: 258
after: 258

Then there's probe tests, or maybe dispersion report, or we could do some senario's with ssbench... Does anyone have a feel for why func tests might be so different?  Why replication is the same?

Here's all I'm doing:

    diff --git a/swift/common/db.py b/swift/common/db.py
    index 0c8e7ea..b68240d 100644
    --- a/swift/common/db.py
    +++ b/swift/common/db.py
    @@ -944,6 +944,7 @@ class ContainerBroker(DatabaseBroker):
                       If include_metadata is set, metadata is included as a key
                       pointing to a dict of tuples of the metadata
             """
    +        open('/home/clayg/get_info/%s' % uuid4(), 'w')
             try:
                 self._commit_puts()
             except LockTimeout:

bit of ls and wc'}, {'account_id': 1216, 'date': '2013-04-29 14:42:58.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 4: I would prefer that you didn't merge this

Replication's the same because the files are all copied over via rsync and therefore don't go through this logic.

This also means that there's always going to be a chance of collision if the new one doesn't hit a server where the old one is at the time the new one is put (in practice, not very likely, but possible).

If this is deemed important, it really needs conflict resolution since it can't ensure 100% prevention. i.e. if account1 > account2 then account1 wins; that sort of thing. This makes things "fun" since a conflict is likely referenced by other items (parent db). I'm fine with leaving those references dangling though, since this is such a rare event so as to never known to have occurred (or at least I haven't heard of it).'}, {'account_id': 1216, 'date': '2013-04-29 14:47:15.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 4: No score

Changing my review to "No score". As letterj was once fond of saying, "Whatever you guys wanna do." :)'}, {'account_id': 4108, 'date': '2013-04-29 17:00:33.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 4:

@Clay

Nothing in the design should get us to a point where we have more calls to get_info than before. 

I will explore the unittests issue and see if it hides a true problem. 
I will always analyze this again, but under real load you will only crease DiskFile and call .exists() if you actually suppose to do something with this DiskFile which means get_info was already called and is stored on a key of the request env - not requiring any extra work (at least with the get_info patch that will be out soon, once we get the autocreate thingy merged).'}, {'account_id': 4108, 'date': '2013-05-02 14:10:09.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 4:

Please ignore my previous response‚Ä¶ ;)

get_info is being called more times under this implementation ‚Äì as it being used for any PUT/POST/DELETE to a container and account ‚Äì which was not used before. 

This actually means that we need to read the DB before we can add a line to the pending file ‚Äì which doe shave a performance impact. This does not work well with the attempts by this author to get DB performance better‚Ä¶ see https://bugs.launchpad.net/swift/+bug/1170050. 

Options going forward: 
1.	Abandon this change and leave with the fact that Swift is susceptible to collisions in container and account  - I don‚Äôt like this option
2.	make this optional by config param ‚Äì this is like saying we can have a system which performs well or one that is susceptible to collisions in container and account  - I don‚Äôt like this option either
3.	Remove the need to do select over the DB before PUT/POST/DELETE by placing the path elsewhere ‚Äì for example we can put the path s extended attribute of the db file. 
4.	Change the direction of te implementation ‚Äì move the responnsiability for avoiding hash collisions on accounts and containers to the proxy. This can be done if the proxy would store the account_info and container_info in memcache based on their hash instead of based on their name  - this way we can identify hash collide at the proxy and refuse the request. The penalty here is the need to call MD5 prior to putting or extracting data from memcache. 


I need your thoughts on that.'}, {'account_id': 6198, 'date': '2013-05-02 14:44:32.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 4: (2 inline comments)

'}, {'account_id': 2696, 'date': '2013-05-02 16:14:10.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 4: (2 inline comments)

Couple minor things inline.'}, {'account_id': 1179, 'date': '2013-05-02 17:40:06.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 4:

I think maybe this patch set is not best place for this discussion?

The bug you linked re: container performance didn't open for me.  But I'm glad you're thinking about keeping the metadata services performant too.

I don't think option 4  (proxy layer) really works because or gholt's explanation of replication based collision.  In the "1-mile wide earth ending asteroid collision destroying the planet is more likely" *un-targeted* md5 collision case we can probably assume the new container coming in collides with an pre-existing container and do a double check of path and account_info - seems pretty cheap if you wanna add that.  But in the "sometimes scary but as yet unproven to be even theoretically possible given the fixed account prefix and limited size of urls" *targeted* md5 collision case - it seems an attacker could just create the colliding containers at the same time and the multiple proxies won't be able to serialize the "check memcache then create container" atomically.

This may also rule out option 2 as well, if it's only providing a false sense of security for a performance drain.

Option 1 still seems pretty not terrible to me, but I've come to terms with other people still worrying about it.  And if there was an option 3 that was basically free performance wise (like what you got us for objects), we'll that'd still be pretty cool in my book!

Are you going to abandon this change and purpose a new suggestion maybe on the bug or in a blueprint?'}, {'account_id': 4108, 'date': '2013-05-02 21:13:04.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 4: (1 inline comment)

Moving the discussion to:
https://bugs.launchpad.net/swift/+bug/1170050

(the previous link had a dot at the end...)'}, {'account_id': 4108, 'date': '2013-05-02 21:17:37.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 4:

which is the Container hash-collide bug'}, {'account_id': 597, 'date': '2013-05-04 01:21:28.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 4: (1 inline comment)

'}, {'account_id': 1179, 'date': '2013-05-14 15:05:04.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 7: I would prefer that you didn't merge this

It seems that this patch only adds the metadata on new databases (write_metadata only called from initialize) - but it checks metadata on every read for every database?  Seems like wasted effort on existing deployments - I was hoping there would be something in the auditor that could migrate existing databases?

account auditors threw a traceback for me

account-auditor ERROR Could not get account info /srv/node4/sdb4/accounts/100332/24c/61fb1809e03f59a1842d12744d1b524c/61fb1809e03f59a1842d12744d1b524c.db: #012Traceback (most recent call last):#012  File "/mnt/workspace/swift/swift/account/auditor.py", line 119, in account_audit#012    if not broker.is_deleted():#012  File "/mnt/workspace/swift/swift/common/db.py", line 1530, in is_deleted#012    if self.db_file != ':memory:' and not self._exists:#012AttributeError: 'AccountBroker' object has no attribute '_exists'

I'm disappointed that probetests didn't catch that :\

How are we going to benchmark this?  My gut tells me it's faster than the extra sqlite lock/read business - but it's not like the object case where we were piggy backing on work we were already doing anyway.  Redbo was the resident xfs guru last I checked?  I sorta expect on new databases the xattr extents will be probably close to inode data and pretty cheap to read.  But on existing databases it seems possible that reading the xattr could incur a fat disk seek :\

I haven't tested replication yet, but as gholt pointed out earlier this solution doesn't solve a collision during rsync replication.  Still I'm hoping that it may keep things from getting jumbled together in the row by row chexor replication case.  Cause you know... that'd be something.'}, {'account_id': 6198, 'date': '2013-05-14 20:43:30.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 7: I would prefer that you didn't merge this

(2 inline comments)

"}, {'account_id': 9, 'date': '2013-05-22 06:03:04.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 7:

[{'created': '2013-04-10 18:37:27.000000000', 'message': 'DB md5-collide

Test against hash collide for Containers and Accounts

Also remove some redundent calls to os.path.exists()

commit_message:
DB md5-collide

Test against hash collide for Containers and Accounts
Store the account and container name in the extended attributes of
the DB file.

Also remove some redundent calls to os.path.exists()

Change-Id: I7c1dc7139ce8fa0c31a0c74951383a7432791af0
Fix: Bug #1158661

commit_message:
Hide db_file

This started as a small re-importation from the "big" LFS into the
DB broker level. Note that the existing GlusterFS UFO code does
not need this, because its initialize() is empty. So the checks
fail all over the place silently. However, when I wrote a "posix fs"
stub plugin, I had containers as directories and thus did not have
the "db_file". Also, I ran the tests which split the difference
between 204 and 201 being returned.

This version of the patch switches db_file to _db_file to illustrate
its "internal" nature. However, this seems like opening a whole
bunch of questions like what to do with db_type?

The .is_good() wrapper is simply called .exists() in a parallel
patch for MD5 deconflicting. We kept this as it seems a better fit.

This patch does NOT do anything about _get_xxxx_brocker(), because
it does not buy us much. If it were possible to get rid of it, then
it would be good, but as it is, GlusterFS relies on it to hook.
Therefore it seems pointless to attack it. The best we could do
is to make it an empty trampoline to the broker.

Change-Id: I34219248070d427b81834c60c7d4c054cfcc7f89

I am thinking about whether to let user update `status`.

But actually, we can update it through REST API rather than glanceclient. If it really need to prevent user to update `status`, we should leave the logic in glance.

So, I think the patch looks good.'}, {'account_id': 616, 'date': '2013-04-30 07:27:46.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2: Do not merge

Hi Yang Yu,

Rather than changing the v1 api to allow status to be updated by the end user, can we look at better error handling for this case? I see two possibilities when just thinking about it now:

1) When an instance is deleted during a snapshot, the connection to glance is killed midstream, leaving the image in the 'saving' status. Glance would need better error handling to detect this condition.

2) When an instance is deleted during a snapshot, nova is simply failing and never updating the image from the 'queued' status. In this case, it would be good to push the error handling logic into Nova.

Thanks!"}, {'account_id': 6981, 'date': '2013-05-08 02:55:57.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2:

Hi Mark Washenberger,

Thank you for your investigation and response.

Actually, for this defect, there are two fixes at least which are provided code review except mine, you can refer to the review link I pasted in the commit comments.

For these two code reviews, they all put the error handling logic in Nova. One is delete the image also when deleting the instance which is in snapshot state. Another one is set the image to Killed state via updating the checksum property for image in Nova. But they all have one issue that the image has disappeared but the end user can not know what happened for it.

So considering these limitation in Nova, I agree with you that we need more work in Glance to detect it, but I do not think Glance now has ability to listen on Nova, whether we need a blueprint to monitor Nova service or exchange message via MQ or not? What's your opinion?

Another question is why there is not ERROR state for image? Killed state can not be displayed, so we also need an error state for image."}, {'account_id': 6484, 'date': '2013-05-08 05:47:41.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2:

Agree +1

I think no matter if we allow the glance client update the status, it would be nice if there is an "error" state to indicate this kind of scenario. And I think we can just leave the delete option to end user instead of "killed" the image in silence.'}, {'account_id': 9, 'date': '2013-05-22 06:03:02.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2: Abandoned

code review expired after 2 weeks of no activity, it can be restored using the `Restore Change` button  under the Patch Set on the web interface'}, {'account_id': 9, 'date': '2013-05-22 06:03:02.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2:

code review expired after 2 weeks of no activity, it can be restored using the `Restore Change` button  under the Patch Set on the web interface'}]

commit_message:
snapshot keep in saving status after instance deleted

The snapshot would always be in the queued or SAVING status
after the VM is deleted or nova compute service is shutdown.
So I combined the review comments from the code review
https://review.openstack.org/#/c/24820 and review
https://review.openstack.org/#/c/25236, adding an error status
for image in glance, and make Nova to update the glance image
status via python-glanceclient.

For this fix, I submited other two code reviews in Nova and
Glance project below.

https://review.openstack.org/#/c/26943/
https://review.openstack.org/#/c/25236/

resolve bug 1143659
resolve bug 1064386

Change-Id: Ib31b89c954eddfe91ca73240af8926bda386e756

commit_message:
Reference AGENT OptGoup names in lowercase

To have consistent option group name format across projects,
oslo.config now normalizes all non lowercase group names to lowercase
when loading conf files.
Thus conf files are backwards compatible but option group references
in the code must now use lowercase before we update oslo.config.

This patch replaces all 'AGENT' references to 'agent'

Change-Id: Ie4f9957b4b33cea6ac22d5edbe3147c3f11f4443

revisions:
[{'created': '2013-05-21 01:46:30.000000000', 'message': "Add lowercase 'agent' group in quantum conf files

To have consistent option group name format across projects,
oslo.config now normalizes all non lowercase group names to lowercase
when loading conf files.

Thus conf files are backwards compatible but option group references
in the code must now use lowercase before we update oslo.config.

In the process of switching option group names to lowercase in Quantum,
we've confronted a chicken egg problem where root_helper is defined in 'agent'
but devstack executes iniset root_helper on 'AGENT'.

https://review.openstack.org/#/c/29738/

To have the above patch merge, there are two options,
1) Have oslo.config be case insensitive to group names.
2) Add a iniset to 'agent' in devstack while keeping iniset on 'AGENT'
   until above patch merges.

Option 1) is not possible since oslo.config is fixed to v1.1.0 and cores
only wish to have backward compatibility on conf files and not on how we
reference the option group in the code.
Option 2) seems to be the only solution to have review 29738 pass while
keeping compatibility with other quantum patches for the time being.

Therefore this patch adds an iniset on 'agent' above each iniset on 'AGENT'

Change-Id: I233e1a4f61aafe6c6070165f88006f06b1ad5ad5
"}, {'created': '2013-05-21 01:50:29.000000000', 'message': "Adds iniset to lowercase 'agent' group in quantum conf files

oslo.config now normalizes all non lowercase group names to lowercase
