but devstack executes iniset root_helper on 'AGENT'.

https://review.openstack.org/#/c/29738/

To have the above patch merge, there are two options,
1) Have oslo.config be case insensitive to group names.
2) Add a iniset to 'agent' in devstack while keeping iniset on 'AGENT'
   until above patch merges.

Option 1) is not possible since oslo.config is fixed to v1.1.0 and cores
only wish to have backward compatibility on conf files and not on how we
reference the option group in the code.
Option 2) seems to be the only solution to have review 29738 pass while
keeping compatibility with other quantum patches for the time being.

Therefore this patch adds an iniset on 'agent' above each iniset on 'AGENT'

Change-Id: I233e1a4f61aafe6c6070165f88006f06b1ad5ad5
"}]
commit_message:
Adds iniset to lowercase 'agent' group in quantum conf files

To have consistent option group name format across projects,
oslo.config now normalizes all non lowercase group names to lowercase
when loading conf files.

Thus conf files are backwards compatible but option group references
in the code must now use lowercase before we update oslo.config.

In the process of switching option group names to lowercase in Quantum,
we've confronted a chicken egg problem where root_helper is defined in 'agent'
but devstack executes iniset root_helper on 'AGENT'.

https://review.openstack.org/#/c/29738/

To have the above patch merge, there are two options,
1) Have oslo.config be case insensitive to group names.
2) Add a iniset to 'agent' in devstack while keeping iniset on 'AGENT'
   until above patch merges.

Option 1) is not possible since oslo.config is fixed to v1.1.0 and cores
only wish to have backward compatibility on conf files and not on how we
reference the option group in the code.
Option 2) seems to be the only solution to have review 29738 pass while
keeping compatibility with other quantum patches for the time being.

Therefore this patch adds an iniset on 'agent' above each iniset on 'AGENT'

Change-Id: I233e1a4f61aafe6c6070165f88006f06b1ad5ad5

Add CLI vs config file priority test

Add a test to show the current behaviour of config files overriding
CLI values, even where the CLI value comes after the --config-file
argument.

Change-Id: Iaa6dcee49339c096278cc11945cc244a665e6a0a

commit_message:
Capitalize boolean values in config files

This patch allows the usage of Puppet boolean values and still
configure values with OpenStack boolean style: True/False.

Change-Id: I413060bc2ec0a8d795a240cc144e503efae41e49

'}, {'account_id': 261, 'date': '2013-05-22 04:10:23.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 4: (1 inline comment)

This implementations allows for scheduling multiple agents for every network if the global configuration variable is enabled.
I thought the reference bug report was about allowing multiple agents for a specific network when the network -or subnet- is created.
In that case the implementation should be slightly different.

Apart from that, I do not have anything against N:M mappings between networks and dhcp_agents.'}, {'account_id': 1653, 'date': '2013-05-22 04:10:23.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 4.'}, {'account_id': 1653, 'date': '2013-05-22 04:10:23.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 4: (1 inline comment)

Hi,
I felt that the support per network would have been an overhead to the administrator. With the current API the administrator can assign a network to more than one agent.
Do you think that an API like this should be added?
Thanks
Gary'}, {'account_id': 3, 'date': '2013-05-22 04:10:23.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 5: Works for me

[{'created': '2013-05-22 04:10:23.000000000', 'message': 'Enable network to be scheduled to N DHCP agents

commit_message:
Remove unnecessary tags/attributes from our tests

Remove the following tags/attributes from our tests:
S3, EC2, slow, bug=lp912922, bug='lp1170718',
category='server-addresses', category='live-migration',
nagative, type='regression'

Now, we are left with:

Tag                   Total # of instances
--------------------  --------------------
'NO TAG'              192
gate                  62
negative              172
positive              110
smoke                 89
whitebox              2

Attribute             Total # of instances
--------------------  --------------------
type                  408

Change-Id: Idab48a7e1a53a3d64fb57ae3cd3975d665180aeb

[{'created': '2013-05-18 16:24:07.000000000', 'message': "Move tests into cinderclient package.

tests/__init__.py implies a package in the global namespace called
tests. That's not what these are - they're tests in the cinderclient
namespace.

Change-Id: I29c95bcd8747c3f5f21d5d900879c9b6b1c9a963

namespace.

"}, {'created': '2013-05-20 18:32:37.000000000', 'message': "Move tests into cinderclient package.

tests/__init__.py implies a package in the global namespace called
tests. That's not what these are - they're tests in the cinderclient
namespace.

Change-Id: I29c95bcd8747c3f5f21d5d900879c9b6b1c9a963
"}]
commit_message:
Move tests into cinderclient package.

tests/__init__.py implies a package in the global namespace called
tests. That's not what these are - they're tests in the cinderclient
namespace.

Change-Id: I29c95bcd8747c3f5f21d5d900879c9b6b1c9a963

The table actions' verbose names were getting initialised too
early. The most noticeable effect was all the red buttons being
displayed in English no matter the locale.

Fixes bug #1126324

Change-Id: I8e21a1ec73f11129317249d103c081e90fa13a34
"}]
commit_message:
Display table actions BatchActions buttons in the correct locale

The table actions' verbose names were getting initialised too
early. The most noticeable effect was all the red buttons being
displayed in English no matter the locale.

Fixes bug #1126324

Change-Id: I8e21a1ec73f11129317249d103c081e90fa13a34

revisions:
[{'created': '2013-05-22 04:04:14.000000000', 'message': "Reference OVS OptGoup names in lowercase

To have consistent option group name format across projects,
oslo.config now normalizes all non lowercase group names to lowercase
when loading conf files.
Thus conf files are backwards compatible but option group references
in the code must now use lowercase before we update oslo.config.

This patch replaces all 'OVS' references to 'ovs'

Change-Id: Id8697138d822e331a6776f847915c61b40f8dd6a
"}]
commit_message:
Reference OVS OptGoup names in lowercase

To have consistent option group name format across projects,
oslo.config now normalizes all non lowercase group names to lowercase
when loading conf files.
Thus conf files are backwards compatible but option group references
in the code must now use lowercase before we update oslo.config.

This patch replaces all 'OVS' references to 'ovs'

Change-Id: Id8697138d822e331a6776f847915c61b40f8dd6a

commit_message:
Rename iface -> port, and restructure node.

Rename "iface" to "port" in the DB models and exceptions.
Restructure the "node" table based on API discussion in review 29867.
Make some changes to the v1 api (still more to do).

Update unit tests based on the above changes.

Change-Id: If5e0ff856424255a5e1ebcb134d262c91845fa26

Thanks for the patch Dims

We need to do https://blueprints.launchpad.net/oslo/+spec/cfg-lowercase-groups first though - I really don't want Nova to start adopting a mix of upper and lowercase groups"}, {'account_id': 5638, 'date': '2013-04-23 14:18:20.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

Hey @markmc, do i need to add deprecated_name when i change the names? (drop sql_ prefix etc?)'}, {'account_id': 1247, 'date': '2013-04-23 14:23:33.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

Yep, you'll need to use deprecated_name

Probably good to have tests checking that (at least some of) the deprecated names and groups work, I guess"}, {'account_id': 4, 'date': '2013-04-23 14:55:54.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

so, would nosql-related options share the DATABASE group with sqlalchemy stuff?'}, {'account_id': 1247, 'date': '2013-04-23 15:08:39.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

Good question - I don't have a strong opinion, but e.g. if there were mongo specific config variables I'd say they should go in a 'mongo' section"}, {'account_id': 4, 'date': '2013-04-23 15:43:05.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

so shouldn't sqlalchemy specific config variables go in a 'sqlalchemy' section?"}, {'account_id': 5638, 'date': '2013-04-23 15:45:00.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 2.'}, {'account_id': 5638, 'date': '2013-04-23 15:45:37.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: (5 inline comments)

'}, {'account_id': 1247, 'date': '2013-04-23 15:47:26.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2:

Just to be clear - blocking this on blueprint cfg-lowercase-groups'}, {'account_id': 3, 'date': '2013-04-23 15:47:33.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2: Works for me

Build succeeded.

- http://logs.openstack.org/27345/2/check/gate-oslo-incubator-python27/1438 : SUCCESS
'}, {'account_id': 1653, 'date': '2013-04-24 05:46:09.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2:

Hi,
I have a number of points to make.
1. I am not sure that this should be blocked - this is preventing the integration of the common DB code into Quantum and other modules. 
2. The BP for the lowercase should make sure that it is case insensitive so that it is backward compatible. We do not want to break existing functionality.
3. Specifically related to the this patch. Maybe the "DATABASE" should be deprecated. Quantum should move towards using DEFAULT.
Thanks
Gary'}, {'account_id': 1247, 'date': '2013-04-24 12:55:49.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2:

1. I'm blocking it on the case insensitive groups thing because I don't want Nova to acquire an upper case group

2. Yes

3. There is a large number of database related config options. I think they should be in a group and 'database' is as good a name as any other."}, {'account_id': 1994, 'date': '2013-05-01 06:43:04.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2:

bp cfg-lowercase-groups patch:

https://review.openstack.org/#/c/27887/'}, {'account_id': 1994, 'date': '2013-05-10 15:23:11.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2:

bp cfg-lowercase-groups has merged.

should change DATABASE to database'}, {'account_id': 5638, 'date': '2013-05-10 15:55:32.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2:

-- dims'}, {'account_id': 5638, 'date': '2013-05-10 16:07:37.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2:

In summary ...

I like 'database' rather than 'sqlalchemy' - the former is more descriptive for users looking for a configuration option

We should switch back to 'database', merge this patch and have Quantum switch to using it

commit_message:
Specify database group instead of DEFAULT

At the request of Quantum folks, Let us switch from DEFAULT to
database for the database related options. This will help with
migration etc.

DocImpact

Fixes LP# 1171837

Change-Id: If602a6a7cc0f2a202632dd14574fea60dce4b589

commit_message:
Add test cases for default_config_files

It's pretty important we actually test the behaviour of falling back to
a default list of config files. Very surprising that we weren't alrady
testing this.

revisions:
[{'created': '2013-05-15 17:21:38.000000000', 'message': 'Reverse path SNAT for DNAT floating-ip.

This patch applies a reverse SNAT rule to allow instances that have an
assigned floating IP to communicate with other instances in the same
OpenStack deployment, security group rules permitting. The patch
allows members of the same private network to communicate with each
other using their floating-ips in a more consistent fashion. The rule
also addresses the situation where the target is on another private
network.

This will only work for interaction between two servers that both have
floating IPs assigned to them.

Specifically, this patch solves the problem where a target server
"sees" the private address of the client. By SNAT'ing to the client's
floating-IP, the "sees" the correct reply address and the reverse
route follows the same path that an actual external connection would
take. The SNAT ONLY occurs if a DNAT occurred before hand, allowing
communication on private networks using private IPs to remain fully
private and internal. The limitation is of course if a DNAT occurs for
other reasons, there may be issues.

Resolves bug 1178745

Change-Id: I55b7131cff5fd5a2ebf826945370d4d550e74136
(cherry picked from commit 314c419323ddd512babc4504ef8a4be1e04f2af7)
'}, {'created': '2013-05-20 20:35:34.000000000', 'message': 'Reverse path SNAT for DNAT floating-ip.

Change-Id: I55b7131cff5fd5a2ebf826945370d4d550e74136
(cherry picked from commit 314c419323ddd512babc4504ef8a4be1e04f2af7)
'}]
commit_message:
Reverse path SNAT for DNAT floating-ip.

This patch applies a reverse SNAT rule to allow instances that have an
assigned floating IP to communicate with other instances in the same
OpenStack deployment, security group rules permitting. The patch
allows members of the same private network to communicate with each
other using their floating-ips in a more consistent fashion. The rule
also addresses the situation where the target is on another private
network.

This will only work for interaction between two servers that both have
floating IPs assigned to them.

Specifically, this patch solves the problem where a target server
"sees" the private address of the client. By SNAT'ing to the client's
floating-IP, the "sees" the correct reply address and the reverse
route follows the same path that an actual external connection would
take. The SNAT ONLY occurs if a DNAT occurred before hand, allowing
communication on private networks using private IPs to remain fully
private and internal. The limitation is of course if a DNAT occurs for
other reasons, there may be issues.

Resolves bug 1178745

Change-Id: I55b7131cff5fd5a2ebf826945370d4d550e74136
(cherry picked from commit 314c419323ddd512babc4504ef8a4be1e04f2af7)

commit_message:
Add update method of security group name and description

make it possible to edit the name and description of security groups.

Fixes: bug #918393

Change-Id: I7b9dd3f9ad2f59aee1b37e06350ce8f5e3a40f64

commit_message:
Allow workflows to support multipart POST.

Enabled by setting multipart = True in the Workflow sublcass.

Required for blueprint: heat-ui

Change-Id: I557c7ad99333d69241e7fa7726f1db30939c8d2c

reviewers: [{'_account_id': 3, 'name': 'Jenkins', 'username': 'jenkins'}, {'_account_id': 1179, 'name': 'Clay Gerrard', 'email': 'clay.gerrard@gmail.com', 'username': 'clay-gerrard'}, {'_account_id': 2166, 'name': 'SmokeStack CI', 'username': 'smokestack', 'tags': ['SERVICE_USER']}, {'_account_id': 2622, 'name': 'Samuel Merritt', 'email': 'sam@swiftstack.com', 'username': 'torgomatic'}, {'_account_id': 2696, 'name': 'Darrell Bishop', 'email': 'dbishop@nvidia.com', 'username': 'darrellb'}, {'_account_id': 2828, 'name': 'Michael Barton', 'email': 'mike@weirdlooking.com', 'username': 'redbo'}, {'_account_id': 6198, 'name': 'Peter Portante', 'email': 'peter.a.portante@gmail.com', 'username': 'peter-a-portante'}]

[{'account_id': 2696, 'date': '2013-05-14 20:37:47.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

That doesn't work, but this does: http://paste.openstack.org/show/OnirxHGLvqGt26BHSFrX/"}, {'account_id': 2696, 'date': '2013-05-14 20:41:08.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

Also, some of the verbiage in the commit message ("If the emission of that packet blocks...") implies that the trampoline only happens if the UDP send would block.  I think eventlet trampolines regardless of whether the (actually non-blocking) socket would block or not... i.e. I think it trampolines instead of just checking that single socket for write-ability.  That's all handled in the hub (hopefully).'}, {'account_id': 2696, 'date': '2013-05-14 20:43:54.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

You might also consider referencing this blog post (which helps explain the problem and solution): http://anandology.com/blog/using-iterators-and-generators/'}, {'account_id': 2696, 'date': '2013-05-14 20:51:27.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

Can you reference (the just-created) Launchpad bug #1180110?'}, {'account_id': 2622, 'date': '2013-05-14 22:37:24.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 2.'}, {'account_id': 2622, 'date': '2013-05-14 22:38:57.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2:

Python is hard :/

Alright, I fixed it so everybody doesn't get their very own mutex (doh!). I can't replicate the probetests failure on my machine, though. Maybe post some more information on your setup?"}, {'account_id': 2622, 'date': '2013-05-14 22:40:04.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2:

Oh, and apparently this is no longer a draft. Good thing it's actually ready for review, I suppose."}, {'account_id': 2696, 'date': '2013-05-15 01:20:40.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2:

My SAIO is Ubuntu 11.10 running in a VirtualBox VM.

Software:
python-greenlet                 0.3.1-1ubuntu4
eventlet==0.12.1

/srv/swift-disk is a 1,024,000,000-byte file, mounted loopback at /mnt/sdb1 and carved into four pieces:

  $ ls -l /srv
  ...
  lrwxrwxrwx  1 root root         11 2012-08-21 13:09 1 -> /mnt/sdb1/1/
  lrwxrwxrwx  1 root root         11 2012-08-21 13:09 2 -> /mnt/sdb1/2/
  lrwxrwxrwx  1 root root         11 2012-08-21 13:09 3 -> /mnt/sdb1/3/
  lrwxrwxrwx  1 root root         11 2012-08-21 13:09 4 -> /mnt/sdb1/4/

  /etc/swift/proxy-server.conf:
  ...
  [DEFAULT]
  bind_port = 8080
  user = swiftstack
  log_facility = LOG_LOCAL1
  log_statsd_host = localhost
  log_statsd_metric_prefix = proxy01
  log_level = DEBUG
  log_headers = true

  [pipeline:main]
  pipeline = catch_errors mempeek healthcheck cache tempauth staticweb proxy-logging proxy-server
  ...


  $ swift-ring-builder ./object.builder 
  ./object.builder, build version 5
  262144 partitions, 3.000000 replicas, 2 regions, 4 zones, 4 devices, 0.00 balance
  The minimum number of hours before a partition can be reassigned is 1
  Devices:    id  region  zone      ip address  port      name weight partitions balance meta
               0       1     1       127.0.0.1  6010      sdb1   1.00     196606  -0.00 
               1       1     2       127.0.0.1  6020      sdb2   1.00     196608   0.00 
               2       2     2       127.0.0.1  6030      sdb3   1.00     196609   0.00 
               3       2     1       127.0.0.1  6040      sdb4   1.00     196609   0.00 


That's not everything, of course.  Feel free to ask specific questions. We've had John repro the issue (and fix) on a Lucid SAIO, but fail to do so on a Precise SAIO."}, {'account_id': 2622, 'date': '2013-05-15 18:22:33.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2:

recheck no bug'}, {'account_id': 3, 'date': '2013-05-15 19:35:05.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2: Works for me

'}, {'account_id': 2696, 'date': '2013-05-15 22:56:09.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2: Looks good to me (core reviewer)

Fixed my probe test problems and seems like a fix for an actual, if obscure, bug.'}, {'account_id': 2622, 'date': '2013-05-16 04:45:12.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2:

Looks like this can also be triggered by the logging if it's going to syslog, as IO on /dev/log or on a UDP socket can also cause a trampoline."}, {'account_id': 2696, 'date': '2013-05-21 03:15:53.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2:

That wasn't the only place this can happen... we should probably audit for every place a generator is passed into concurrently-run-by-greenthread code.

  May 20 00:49:12 proxy-server ERROR Unhandled exception in request:
  Traceback (most recent call last):
    File "/usr/lib/pymodules/python2.7/swift/proxy/server.py", line 240, in handle_request
      return handler(req)
    File "/usr/lib/pymodules/python2.7/swift/common/utils.py", line 1458, in wrapped
      return func(*a, **kw)
    File "/usr/lib/pymodules/python2.7/swift/proxy/controllers/base.py", line 86, in wrapped
      return func(*a, **kw)
    File "/usr/lib/pymodules/python2.7/swift/proxy/controllers/obj.py", line 733, in PUT
      conns = [conn for conn in pile if conn]
    File "/usr/local/lib/python2.7/dist-packages/eventlet/greenpool.py", line 218, in next
      return self.waiters.get().wait()
    File "/usr/local/lib/python2.7/dist-packages/eventlet/greenthread.py", line 166, in wait
      return self._exit_event.wait()
    File "/usr/local/lib/python2.7/dist-packages/eventlet/event.py", line 116, in wait
      return hubs.get_hub().switch()
    File "/usr/local/lib/python2.7/dist-packages/eventlet/hubs/hub.py", line 177, in switch
      return self.greenlet.switch()
    File "/usr/local/lib/python2.7/dist-packages/eventlet/greenthread.py", line 192, in main
      result = function(*args, **kwargs)
    File "/usr/lib/pymodules/python2.7/swift/proxy/controllers/obj.py", line 521, in _connect_put_node
      for node in nodes:
  ValueError: generator already executing (txn: txb47ff7339d5545fa9072211c8e0f3e3b) (client_ip: 192.168.150.9)
  May 20 00:49:12 proxy-server 192.168.150.9 192.168.150.9 20/May/2013/07/49/12 PUT /v1/AUTH_ss/ssbench_000016/1KB-bm1_000960 HTTP/1.0 500 - - ss%3Aadmin%2CAUTH_tk4c4d6baa077c4c748ef268e601415663 - 125 - txb47ff7339d5545fa9072211c8e0f3e3b - 0.5379

That was from Swift 1.7.6 or so, but I looked and it seems like it could still happen.

It should be noted that this happened while a node was under very heavy load, so this could be an edge case which "normal" operation avoids.'}, {'account_id': 1179, 'date': '2013-05-21 04:08:50.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2: I would prefer that you didn't merge this

K, my greps says the only other place we hand iter_nodes to a pool of consumers is in object PUT there what with the _connect_put_nodes like darrell said already...  Really the only other place we in the proxy we call spawn is _make_app_iter - and that seems legit.

But I guess we should wrap at *least* that iter_nodes before we close Bug 1180110.  Up to you if you want to wrap all the so-far-unaffected calls to iter_nodes in base as a warning to the next guy... Probably better to just add a comment on iter_nodes.

Also, I think you could (should?) probably come up with a test for this... Here's what I wrote to convince myself that serializing the generators doesn't screw up concurrency of the requests:

http://paste.openstack.org/show/37510/"}, {'account_id': 2622, 'date': '2013-05-21 18:46:14.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 3.'}, {'account_id': 2622, 'date': '2013-05-21 18:47:42.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3:

Alright, I wrapped up the other concurrently-accessed iter_nodes, and I cobbled together some unit tests.'}, {'account_id': 2622, 'date': '2013-05-21 18:48:37.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 4.'}, {'account_id': 2622, 'date': '2013-05-21 18:49:14.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 4:

Left some debugging crud in a test. :( Patch set 4 just removes the crud.'}, {'account_id': 6198, 'date': '2013-05-21 18:51:29.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 4: Looks good to me, but someone else must approve

'}, {'account_id': 2696, 'date': '2013-05-21 19:16:10.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 4: Looks good to me (core reviewer)

lgtm w/one suggestion for wording in a comment.'}, {'account_id': 3, 'date': '2013-05-21 19:32:59.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 4: Works for me

Patch set 5 just updates a comment to make it clear that ValueErrors *may* happen, but are not guaranteed. No code changes.'}, {'account_id': 2696, 'date': '2013-05-21 20:35:07.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 5: Looks good to me (core reviewer)

Yes, please, I like getting less 500s...'}, {'account_id': 1179, 'date': '2013-05-21 21:09:03.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 5: Looks good to me (core reviewer)

I think shops runnings statsd are more heavily effected by this bug.  When one of the primary nodes is down it's actually pretty consistently reproduceable, so on a small cluster with a downed node running statds - this can really kick the 'super highly available data storage system' story in the pants.

creiht had sorta mentioned in channel he was *trying* to review this (which is great cause it's sorta tricky and there's always the chance darrell, sam and myself may have missed something), but this is a pretty critical problem IMHO, we're trying to cut some packages with a fix, and I think we have a good patch.

Basically I'll approve this later today without a strong objection, but if some additional feedback comes in after the fact I'll be happy to address it in a later change.

Even better is creiht or someone else can come along and beat me to punch ;)"}, {'account_id': 3, 'date': '2013-05-21 21:24:04.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 5: Works for me

[{'created': '2013-05-14 20:11:43.000000000', 'message': "Fix ValueError from handoff logging.

If you have StatsD logging turned on, then the iterator returned by
Ring.get_part_nodes() will emit StatsD packets when it yields a
handoff node. If the emission of that packet blocks, then eventlet
will trampoline to another greenthread before returning from
next(). Now, if that other greenthread tries to call next() on that
iterator, it blows up with a ValueError.

You can see this happen sometimes in the proxy's make_requests method
if two of the primary nodes are down. Greenthread A goes into next()
to get a handoff node, but blocks on sending a StatsD packet, and so
eventlet trampolines to Greenthread B. Now, Greenthread B also calls
next() to get a handoff node, and dies with a ValueError.

This commit wraps up that iterator with a mutex to avoid this problem.

(Do note that to reproduce this, you must have StatsD logging enabled,
as that's the only thing in the node-iterator's code that might cause
a trampoline.)

Change-Id: I8fe13d7295c056a2cab9e084f5966078a49bdc13

commit_message:
Fix ValueError from handoff logging.

If you have StatsD logging turned on, then the iterator returned by
Ring.get_part_nodes() will emit StatsD packets when it yields a
handoff node. That network IO may make eventlet trampoline to another
greenthread before returning from next(). Now, if that other
greenthread tries to call next() on that same iterator, it blows up
with a ValueError.

Any socket IO inside a generator's next() method can cause this. It's
easiest to reproduce with StatsD logging turned on, but logging to
syslog can trigger it too.

You can see this happen sometimes in the proxy's make_requests method
if two of the primary nodes are down. Greenthread A goes into next()
to get a handoff node, then sends a StatsD packet, and so eventlet
trampolines to Greenthread B. Now, Greenthread B also calls next() to
get a handoff node, and dies with a ValueError.

This commit wraps up concurrently-accessed iter_nodes() iterators in a
new thing called a GreenthreadSafeIterator that serializes access.

Bug 1180110
Change-Id: I8fe13d7295c056a2cab9e084f5966078a49bdc13

This commit sets the default to the sql_connection
class parameter from the cinder class to false so that
it is optional.

The cinder class is intended to configure settings common
to all ciner roles and sql_connection is specific to the server

commit_message:
make sql_connection optional

This commit sets the default to the sql_connection
class parameter from the cinder class to false so that
it is optional.

The cinder class is intended to configure settings common
to all ciner roles and sql_connection is specific to the server
side roles. This commit makes it optional, so that nodes configured
only as volumes do not have to set sql_connections.

Change-Id: Id20dcc68779b2bb3bfb67fdc5b0862d0c86aa7b0

commit_message:
Use ugettext_lazy instead of ugettext.

We should use ugettext_lazy to let users in different languages
get correct translation.Though in views or similar places
we can use ugettext with no problems, we should make code
style consistent.

This also fix the issues that the django proxy objects appear on the
launching instance page instead of translated strings. Now the
translated quota strings are handled correctly.

Fixes: bug #1178722

Change-Id: I76f0d31e6546d70e5ece7e86a06f7eefd04861d2

commit_message:
Added optional arg to launch child processes

Removed unnecessary conditional stmts
Commented out reddwarf-api-workers in configs

Change-Id: I80505fbe2dfe84c2ad77d4f41cd0d876b90187ef
Implements: blueprint preforkreddwarf

nested standard.

OK,  just tested this against devstack.  That code does not work, even with attribute_ignore including domain_id:  it would need a default value instead.  This code works as is.

As I pointed out in the other review,  devstack overrides user_attribute_ignore, removing the domain_id value.  That means that it was reading the value from the backend datastore, where it was also populated by devstack.  To test this code , comment out the line:

user_attribute_ignore = enabled,email,tenants,tenantId

in /etc/keystone/keystone.conf'}, {'account_id': 2218, 'date': '2013-05-18 01:51:03.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 9.'}, {'account_id': 4, 'date': '2013-05-18 02:29:49.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 9:

commit_message:
Read-only default domain for LDAP (bug 1168726)

A proper fix to the above was also blocked by bug 1117356, so that's
fixed here as well (updates properly return the resulting entities).

Change-Id: I672b90e67545cc1fe65b05ef7f8af5b42ca6afc3

Import uuidutils and convert to it.

Instead of carrying a local implementation of is_uuid_like().

Change-Id: I4b7153dee3b99e5cbdef55d496f0c57c8c2e9e4c

commit_message:
Adding tests for rebuild image checks

Create instance has tests arounds it's image-checks, this patch just ports
those tests over to the rebuild case.

commit_message:
Add ImageNotActive check for instance rebuild

We have a check in place on create to test whether the image is marked
as deleted in Glance that doesn't exist on the rebuild method. This
patch adds that check and tests, with a follow-on patch forthcoming to
refactor the code to a shared method.

Fixes bug 1180604

Change-Id: I1e75313a72d2197e83f7dacf6bcbd6750dd490cd

commit_message:
Convert Nova to use Oslo service infrastructure.

Convert Nova to use the Oslo versions of:
* Service
* Launchers

Also add Service timers to the Service ThreadGroup.

blueprint use-oslo-services

Change-Id: Id8ab017f4525afd69fed322311f2d5cc3b6d6f98

commit_message:
setup.cfg misses swift filter

The file misses the swift middleware filter
paste.filter_factory =
swift = ceilometer.objectstore.swift_middleware:filter_factory

Change-Id: If7d844fdbcc4dc2b3ad0a0e184ac10fb7515d864
fixes: Bug #1180641

commit_message:
only set network_vlan_ranges for vlan network types

This commit updates the quantum module to ensure
that vlan specific configuration is only applied
when the tenant_network_type is vlan or flat.

it also adds tests that were previously missing from
quantum_plugins_ovs_spec.rb.

Change-Id: I97cffff55ad6ff6cb683efc282e0db46d4687c1a

commit_message:
db query should be empty string, not nil

Fixes TypeError - can't convert nil into String when trying to append
nil to the db_uri later down in the code

Change-Id: I3722829c5393a3f60dede078be131baf96288c2a

Ok, I see that the decorator does it.  For the record, I don't like relying on this decorator.  I think it couples the notifications and the implementation details way too much.  The notification on failure will include an internal function name, its arguments, and whatever exception it raised.  It would be nice if the report of failure was in a well defined format that was *not* tied to the implementation."}, {'account_id': 3, 'date': '2013-05-20 19:35:30.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 5: No score

commit_message:
Add notification for live migration

Fix bug 1167759

Currently, if live migration failed, nova compute did not send
notification, this causes other services such as nova-scheduler
to have no chance to do some operations

The fix add notification logic for live_migration like other
VM instance operations such as resize, run instance etc.

Change-Id: Iaf61f5268e07284fd7d69ff331ce3bacd380c02b

[{'created': '2013-05-21 00:33:47.000000000', 'message': "Add requests requirement capped <1.2.1.

Fixes bug 1182271.

* tools/pip-requires: The requests library released 1.2.1 today
which brings in sphinx as a new dependency. One of sphinx's
transitive dependencies is on a newer version of jinja than is
provided in the python-jinja2 package on CentOS 6, and since nova's
unit tests allow site-packages in the venv for libvirt support this
cap is needed so that gate-nova-python26 will continue to work.
Because requests is actually a dependency of python-cinderclient but
is only breaking nova's unit tests, it has to be added and come
before python-cinderclient in the pip-requires list. A separate
change has been proposed to openstack/requirements which will need
to merge first. https://review.openstack.org/29850

Change-Id: Ia198192d6231f71272d3aa4f5942828a45d86ceb
"}]
commit_message:
Add requests requirement capped <1.2.1.

Fixes bug 1182271.

* tools/pip-requires: The requests library released 1.2.1 today
which brings in sphinx as a new dependency. One of sphinx's
transitive dependencies is on a newer version of jinja than is
provided in the python-jinja2 package on CentOS 6, and since nova's
unit tests allow site-packages in the venv for libvirt support this
cap is needed so that gate-nova-python26 will continue to work.
Because requests is actually a dependency of python-cinderclient but
is only breaking nova's unit tests, it has to be added and come
before python-cinderclient in the pip-requires list. A separate
change has been proposed to openstack/requirements which will need
to merge first. https://review.openstack.org/29850

Change-Id: Ia198192d6231f71272d3aa4f5942828a45d86ceb

[{'created': '2013-05-21 19:56:22.000000000', 'message': 'Minor changes to quantum::agents::ovs

This patch contains two minor edits to the
quantum::agents::ovs code.

1. allow setting of the firewall_driver.

This code ensures that the firewall driver can be
either set to its default of IptablesFirewallDriver
or unset (which we believe is required in the case
of compute nodes with gre enabled)

2. explicitly remove tunneling configuration when
it is not being used. This is part of an ongoing
attempt to clean up configuration that are not
currently in use.

This patch also adds tests to verify the proposed
code.

Change-Id: I372889d1c8821605d60c91c1e244d1a4c83fcc5e

commit_message:
Minor changes to quantum::agents::ovs

This patch contains two minor edits to the
quantum::agents::ovs code.

1. allow setting of the firewall_driver.

This code ensures that the firewall driver can be
either set to its default of IptablesFirewallDriver
or unset (which we believe is required in the case
of compute nodes with gre enabled)

2. explicitly remove tunneling configuration when
it is not being used. This is part of an ongoing
attempt to clean up configuration that are not
currently in use.

This patch also adds tests to verify the proposed
code.

Change-Id: I372889d1c8821605d60c91c1e244d1a4c83fcc5e

[{'created': '2013-05-21 00:17:04.000000000', 'message': "Cap requests <1.2.1.

* tools/pip-requires: The requests library released 1.2.1 today
which brings in sphinx as a new dependency. One of sphinx's
transitive dependencies is on a newer version of jinja than is
provided in the python-jinja2 package on CentOS 6, and since nova's
unit tests allow site-packages in the venv for libvirt support this
cap is needed so that gate-nova-python26 will continue to work. A
corresponding patch is being drafted for nova, bug 1182271.

Change-Id: I2ea71d2bbc8a4e67a4c07672aadef218330641da
"}]
commit_message:
Cap requests <1.2.1.

* tools/pip-requires: The requests library released 1.2.1 today
which brings in sphinx as a new dependency. One of sphinx's
transitive dependencies is on a newer version of jinja than is
provided in the python-jinja2 package on CentOS 6, and since nova's
unit tests allow site-packages in the venv for libvirt support this
cap is needed so that gate-nova-python26 will continue to work. A
corresponding patch is being drafted for nova, bug 1182271.

Change-Id: I2ea71d2bbc8a4e67a4c07672aadef218330641da

commit_message:
Pass memcache_servers as array

the python-memcached module expects memcache_servers to be an
array of strings or an array of tuples. Since we don't care about
server weighting, we can use an array of tuples for the unit test.

Fixes bug 1172723

Change-Id: Iafba2bda545ea334d5aba7135e153d8589612ba4

commit_message:
blueprint test-cascade-deletes

This test case ensures that objects related to a user or role are
deleted when the user or role is deleted.

As I was working on Bug 963348, I created these test cases to ensure
the deleted were being propogated in the database. The bug was
invalid, so I am submitting the test as a blueprint

Change-Id: I1ad22777f03077fe243c79cd6177cabbd15ef5ae

[{'account_id': 6549, 'date': '2013-05-15 14:50:37.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1: Work In Progress

I have talked this change with Mark in IRC, current I need other guys to review this change to make sure it is good enough and will not make regress and keep the backwards compatibility.
After that I'd like give the unit test here."}, {'account_id': 6549, 'date': '2013-05-15 15:01:59.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Ready For Review

And as I said in https://bugs.launchpad.net/glance/+bug/1180377 , this fix also need change 2 points in nova-api code ("nova/compute/api.py"), they are call str() on the image properties, it should be unicode() after above change.

Just mark this to "Ready For review" temporarily for get maximum reviewer.'}, {'account_id': 3, 'date': '2013-05-15 15:32:18.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1: Doesn't seem to work

- http://logs.openstack.org/29245/2/check/gate-grenade-devstack-vm/3855 : FAILURE in 9m 00s (non-voting)
'}, {'account_id': 4992, 'date': '2013-05-16 07:19:35.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2: I would prefer that you didn't merge this

Would it not be better to save each and every attribute as unicode and decode on retrieve as a stardard practice.

As soon as one gets input from user encode, and for all things iternal work with the input in unicode and then just before exiting the system decide ut back.

Applying decode on an object that is already in un'code format leaves things unchanged. Likewise encode, so it should be safe from a backward compatibility perspective.
Does it make sense to a clean sweep of conversions?"}, {'account_id': 6549, 'date': '2013-05-16 07:34:57.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2:

@malini-k-bhandaru,
The current logic in glance (even not do this change), is just like you said, glanceclient send property in unicode to glance-api, then glance-registry save each and every attribute as unicode in database, and when glanceclient ask to retrieve them, those property (k/v pair) be encoding to utf-8 by glance-api, and send back to glancclient. I agree this is correct, those property should be enconded by utf-8, since those non-ascii characters need be passed via http header (k/v pair also, api v1.0 spec defined). but issue is that we should convert those utf-8 encoded property (k/v pair) back to unicode.

so maybe i'm confused, I just think you and me in the same way. why -1?"}, {'account_id': 6159, 'date': '2013-05-16 08:08:09.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2: I would prefer that you didn't merge this

@malini yeah, that's the ideal thing to do and is what has been done in clients (at least glance's, nova's and cinder's) but it was never done in the server side.

@zhi glanceclient "encodes" headers[0] before sending the request to the server and yes, it doesn't decodes incoming data. I agree with you about doing this in glanceclient (all clients and servers should do the same). Pls, instead of using .decode use [1]. Also, this is something that should happen in all requests that get some data from the server so, why not putting it in a more "common" place [2] (not sure about that being the right place, though)? 


[0] https://github.com/openstack/python-glanceclient/blob/master/glanceclient/common/http.py#L157

[1] https://github.com/openstack/python-glanceclient/blob/master/glanceclient/common/utils.py#L195

[2] https://github.com/openstack/python-glanceclient/blob/master/glanceclient/common/http.py#L230'}, {'account_id': 6549, 'date': '2013-05-16 09:50:56.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2:

@Flavio, thanks.
1. I agree, instead of using .decode use above [1]
2. Maybe we should putting it in a more "common" place, but it should not be above [2], it should be below [3], since a) glanceclient/v1/images.py:get() method call raw_request() method but not json_request(), so we should change http_request(). b) _http_request() method has more commonality.
For now, IMO, i'm not really sure we need get that commonality.

[3] https://github.com/openstack/python-glanceclient/blob/master/glanceclient/common/http.py#L212'}, {'account_id': 6549, 'date': '2013-05-16 10:22:15.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 3.'}, {'account_id': 3, 'date': '2013-05-16 11:12:51.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 3: Doesn't seem to work

revisions:
[{'created': '2013-05-15 14:45:45.000000000', 'message': 'Convert non-ascii characters within image property to unicode

Convert non-ascii characters within image property (key/value pair) to
unicode but utf-8 to prevent provisioning failure when cloud using qpid
backend.
This change also make the image property encoding consistency between
the image updating and the receiving. Before this, image property
updating use unicode, but receiving (get) result is utf-8.

Fixes: Bug #1180377

Change-Id: I010760c598a7e008c79f1240255708265352cdb5
Signed-off-by: Zhi Yan Liu <zhiyanl@cn.ibm.com>'}, {'created': '2013-05-16 06:07:35.000000000', 'message': 'Convert non-ascii characters within image property to unicode

Convert non-ascii characters within image property (key/value pair) to
unicode but utf-8 to prevent provisioning failure when cloud using qpid
backend.

commit_message:
Convert non-ascii characters within image property to unicode

Convert non-ascii characters within image property (key/value pair) to
unicode but utf-8 to prevent provisioning failure when cloud using qpid
backend.
This change also make the image property encoding consistency between
the image updating and the receiving. Before this, image property
updating use unicode, but receiving (get) result is utf-8.

Fixes: Bug #1180377

Change-Id: I010760c598a7e008c79f1240255708265352cdb5
Signed-off-by: Zhi Yan Liu <zhiyanl@cn.ibm.com>

commit_message:
Documentation about the initial configuration file and sample data.

The initial configuration file and sample data are both are helpful in getting
setup with a keystone development environment.

Change-Id: Ic100177abe8dda1510a183463e61e0b757986e97

I'm not sure if this is better for KVS but i implemented the change. To my mind it is more important that the flush removes the tokens from the main table, and in the case of the KVS backend saving these to an archive makes no sense. But honestly it probably doesn't matter. 

In the case of the token subclass I created a base and it does seem to work. I hadn't done this before as i wasn't sure of the complications of having a mixin here. Can someone with more sqlalchemy experience have a look at http://docs.sqlalchemy.org/en/rel_0_7/orm/extensions/declarative.html?highlight=mixin#mixing-in-columns and tell me if these should be defined using @declared_attr?"}, {'account_id': 7191, 'date': '2013-05-06 00:53:34.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 4.'}, {'account_id': 3, 'date': '2013-05-06 01:37:54.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 4: Doesn't seem to work

ayoung: No, after discussing with Brant and Dolph YOU came up with the above etherpad all on your own.'}, {'account_id': 7191, 'date': '2013-05-16 23:32:07.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 9:

Ok, I'm going to wait for a bit more of a consensus here. Timezones suck, it would have been useful to be in that conversation. 

You've hit across the main points. 

To use the ORM we need to have a primary key, my idea by leaving the primary key on the model but not the table is that we wouldn't get insert errors with collisions. We would get errors doing a .get(id) with conflicting ids (and it would be slow) but we never use the table beyond writing to it so it's not an issue. 

The Table() syntax (examples all through tests and migrations) would allow us to create this table without a PK but to make MySQL and Postgres tests work we have to build those tables via the ORM system. I'd love to have a crack at fixing that, we can start by approving my other test related patches.

Also note that I put a downgrade SQL command in and this may suffer the same problem of PK collision. IMO if you downgrade with archived tokens we should drop them.

Dolph, your solution with an autoincrement ID while technically an unnecessary column is a good compromise. 

Adam, I like the idea of generating a revoked CSV or such. I'm not sure about having a table in the DB that is not managed. However if we go that route i don't see the need to have a revoked_token or archived_token table at all, print a csv and then cleanup direct from token. 

Can't we solve a substantial amount of these slowness problems by putting an index on valid and expiry time?"}, {'account_id': 4, 'date': '2013-05-17 16:28:45.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 9:

regarding indexes, yes: https://review.openstack.org/#/c/26845/'}, {'account_id': 4, 'date': '2013-05-17 18:13:01.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 9:

reduced the scope of the blueprint to only concern deleting expired tokens... obviously the conversation about how to best archive/dump them gets more complicated so we can save that for another day... and continue to leave the issue in the hands of deployers for now

Jamie: I'd be happy to revise this patch accordingly if you want :)"}, {'account_id': 7191, 'date': '2013-05-17 22:31:40.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 9:

Dolph, I don't mind. I'm fine to finish it off, but i won't get around to it until monday. 

If you want it before then it's all yours.

the archive strategy. There is no strategy for dealing with this table.
KVS and memcache do not support archiving tokens.

commit_message:
Implement Token Flush via keystone-manage.

Creates a cli entry 'token_flush' which removes all expired tokens.

Fixes: bug 1032633
Implements: blueprint keystone-manage-token-flush
Change-Id: I47eab99b577ff9e9ee74fee08e18fd07c4af5aad

commit_message:
Add support for default --key values.

We are using a pattern of suppressing errors to allow missing keys
in some TripleO elements.

This allows simply specifying a default value inside
os-config-applier.

Change-Id: I15702d205bab995f918f2efcb75af832b760be74

Empty string is a perfectly valid raw string and the default type is
meant to prevent malicious characters, not empty strings.

Change-Id: I717bbcfe1a81b383782122870d0d727b28f40cce
'}]
commit_message:
Allow empty strings for raw and default types.

Empty string is a perfectly valid raw string and the default type is
meant to prevent malicious characters, not empty strings.

Change-Id: I717bbcfe1a81b383782122870d0d727b28f40cce

revisions:
[{'created': '2013-05-21 17:04:37.000000000', 'message': 'Building the image using dib no longer ignores the base element

When we build our image using dib, we should no longer use the -n flag which
suppresses the base element. With this fix, our first-boot.d script is now
being run on boot and the guest agent is installed successfully.

Fixes bug: 1182269

Change-Id: Ibdeb1f19b7b3e19e5709051251cdba1a99eda588
'}]
commit_message:
Building the image using dib no longer ignores the base element

When we build our image using dib, we should no longer use the -n flag which
suppresses the base element. With this fix, our first-boot.d script is now
being run on boot and the guest agent is installed successfully.

Fixes bug: 1182269

Change-Id: Ibdeb1f19b7b3e19e5709051251cdba1a99eda588

subject: Removed unused paramter '-force' when formatting NameNode
messages:
[{'account_id': 3, 'date': '2013-05-21 15:39:45.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1: Doesn't seem to work

Build failed.  For information on how to proceed, see https://wiki.openstack.org/wiki/GerritJenkinsGithub#Test_Failures

- http://logs.openstack.org/29937/1/check/gate-savanna-pep8/228 : FAILURE in 52s
- http://logs.openstack.org/29937/1/check/gate-savanna-python26/228 : SUCCESS in 2m 07s
- http://logs.openstack.org/29937/1/check/gate-savanna-python27/228 : SUCCESS in 1m 54s
"}, {'account_id': 6786, 'date': '2013-05-21 15:40:23.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1: I would prefer that you didn't merge this

Alex, could you, please, take a look on http://hadoop.apache.org/docs/r1.1.2/commands_manual.html

It looks like that this option is needed for Apache Hadoop.

Quote:

-force: formats the namenode and the user will NOT be prompted to confirm formatting of name directories in the local filesystem."}, {'account_id': 6786, 'date': '2013-05-21 15:41:20.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

recheck no bug'}, {'account_id': 3, 'date': '2013-05-21 15:43:37.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Works for me

Build succeeded.

- http://logs.openstack.org/29937/1/check/gate-savanna-pep8/229 : SUCCESS in 1m 01s
- http://logs.openstack.org/29937/1/check/gate-savanna-python26/229 : SUCCESS in 2m 09s
- http://logs.openstack.org/29937/1/check/gate-savanna-python27/229 : SUCCESS in 1m 52s
'}, {'account_id': 7125, 'date': '2013-05-21 15:58:09.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

Looking at hadoop 1.0.3 version the command '-force' doesn't exist here. I think it was added since 1.1.X version.

Description of -force from link you provided stats:
-force: formats the namenode and the user will NOT be prompted to confirm formatting of name directories in the local filesystem.

So this command has no effect when formatting namenode directory  at the first time because this directory doesn't exist in the system and user will not be prompted to format."}, {'account_id': 6786, 'date': '2013-05-21 16:12:34.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Looks good to me (core reviewer); Approved

Integration tests has been successfully completed, so, I think we can merge it.

Thank you.'}, {'account_id': 3, 'date': '2013-05-21 16:12:35.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: No score

Starting gate jobs.
http://status.openstack.org/zuul/'}, {'account_id': 3, 'date': '2013-05-21 16:15:55.000000000', 'content': 'Change has been successfully merged into the git repository.'}, {'account_id': 3, 'date': '2013-05-21 16:15:55.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Verified

Build succeeded.

- http://logs.openstack.org/29937/1/gate/gate-savanna-pep8/230 : SUCCESS in 2m 48s
- http://logs.openstack.org/29937/1/gate/gate-savanna-python26/230 : SUCCESS in 3m 08s
- http://logs.openstack.org/29937/1/gate/gate-savanna-python27/230 : SUCCESS in 3m 13s
'}]

commit_message:
Add update method of security group name and description

make it possible to edit the name and description of
common security groups, we can not rename the default
security group.

Fixes: bug #918393

Change-Id: I7003c47e054f032572adbb901be4dbc61839b695

[{'created': '2013-05-16 10:59:47.000000000', 'message': "Install new nose for tempest on RHEL.

 * python-nose on RHEL isn't new enough to support tempest.

Change-Id: I98107bf664a12f6252f74b4511e3228d511ff855
"}, {'created': '2013-05-20 18:12:30.000000000', 'message': "Avoid installing nose from an rpm.

 * python-nose on RHEL isn't new enough to support tempest.
   Since there is currently no way to selectively install rpm
   dependencies, this patch ensures that no rpm-based distro
   installs python-nose.

Change-Id: I98107bf664a12f6252f74b4511e3228d511ff855
"}, {'created': '2013-05-20 18:16:06.000000000', 'message': "Avoid installing python-nose for RHEL6.

 * python-nose on RHEL isn't new enough to support Tempest.

Change-Id: I98107bf664a12f6252f74b4511e3228d511ff855
"}]
commit_message:
Avoid installing python-nose for RHEL6.

 * python-nose on RHEL isn't new enough to support Tempest.

Change-Id: I98107bf664a12f6252f74b4511e3228d511ff855

[{'account_id': 4393, 'date': '2013-05-09 23:13:32.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

This (and the following patch) lets me do everything I need for object (de-)serialization, as shown here:

https://github.com/kk7ds/nova/commit/8c8d17f6158b85ffe5f28c20cfaa1bdcdbb31a54'}, {'account_id': 3, 'date': '2013-05-09 23:18:31.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Works for me

'}, {'account_id': 1030, 'date': '2013-05-10 07:07:23.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Looks good to me, but someone else must approve

'}, {'account_id': 1561, 'date': '2013-05-10 23:24:56.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1: I would prefer that you didn't merge this

(2 inline comments)

Nice work!  Some minor comments/suggestions ...

I also think it's worth having a blueprint for adding serialization hooks."}, {'account_id': 4393, 'date': '2013-05-11 00:14:35.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: (1 inline comment)

'}, {'account_id': 4393, 'date': '2013-05-11 00:17:47.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 2.'}, {'account_id': 3, 'date': '2013-05-11 00:20:52.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2: Works for me

Build succeeded.

- http://logs.openstack.org/28744/2/check/gate-oslo-incubator-pep8/1636 : SUCCESS in 00:01:32
- http://docs-draft.openstack.org/28744/2/check/gate-oslo-incubator-docs/1411/doc/build/html/ : SUCCESS in 00:02:02
- http://logs.openstack.org/28744/2/check/gate-oslo-incubator-pyflakes/1260 : SUCCESS in 00:01:29
- http://logs.openstack.org/28744/2/check/gate-oslo-incubator-python26/1595 : SUCCESS in 00:02:50
- http://logs.openstack.org/28744/2/check/gate-oslo-incubator-python27/1596 : SUCCESS in 00:02:19
'}, {'account_id': 1247, 'date': '2013-05-13 20:52:30.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2: I would prefer that you didn't merge this

Dan - could you check out my messaging branch and think about how best to model the concept in the new api: https://github.com/markmc/oslo-incubator/tree/messaging

You want to look at messaging/rpc/{client,dispatcher}.py

I'm thinking we'd add a messaging.serializer.MessageSerializer abstract based class with serialize() and deserialize() methods

We could have a NoopSerializer as a default and allow RPCClient and RPCDispatcher to be instantiated with an alternative serializer

I'm not sure I'd add knowledge of to_primitive() to oslo.messaging just yet ... not until oslo has a base class with this method

If we figure out how it should be in the new API, I think we should follow a very similar model for the legacy API

Hope that makes some sense and isn't a huge amount of work ... but we do need to make new stuff added to the legacy API gets carried forward"}, {'account_id': 1247, 'date': '2013-05-13 20:53:24.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2:

Would appreciate Doug's thoughts on modelling this idea in the new API"}, {'account_id': 2472, 'date': '2013-05-13 21:30:46.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2: (1 inline comment)

In the new API, what if we make the argument to call() a first-class object instead of a dictionary? Pass a instance of a subclass of Message to it for the outgoing value and a class representing the type of thing you expect to get back as a return value. The instance method serialize() can be used to get the outgoing data and the class method deserialize() can be used to construct an instance from the response. cast() wouldn't need to have the return type specified."}, {'account_id': 1247, 'date': '2013-05-13 21:54:38.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2:

Doug - in the new API, the arguments to call() are context, method, **kwargs ... remember, we're not exposing the concept of a message in the RPC API, it's all about method invocations"}, {'account_id': 1247, 'date': '2013-05-13 22:00:42.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2:

(You got me thinking though, Doug)

The client-side serialization case seems to be handled by just calling to_primitive() (or serialize, or whatever) on any objects that have that method

It's the de-serialization in the dispatcher is the problem - could we have a decorator that specified the desired type for any arguments that need special handling

e.g.

  @arg_type(instance=Instance)

or is that barf?"}, {'account_id': 4393, 'date': '2013-05-13 22:14:04.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2:

How do we know which ones need "special handling"?'}, {'account_id': 4393, 'date': '2013-05-13 22:40:06.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2: (1 inline comment)

Question for Doug.'}, {'account_id': 4393, 'date': '2013-05-13 23:26:46.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2:

Mark,

Encapsulating this in a Serializer object and passing that into proxy and dispatcher would be fine with me. In fact, I think it would let me unify the serialization and deserialization code between the proxy and dispatcher case, if I iterate over the args and just call Serializer.serialize_thing(), etc. Let me try to cook something up...'}, {'account_id': 4393, 'date': '2013-05-13 23:50:32.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2: (1 inline comment)

'}, {'account_id': 2472, 'date': '2013-05-14 00:14:52.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2: (1 inline comment)

Mark, you should stop acting surprised when I try to work messaging concepts in. ;-)

Seriously, if we're just taking **kwargs, then the clients should add methods for all of the calls and those methods should handle the serialization and deserialization. That avoids having a huge registry of all serialization capabilities in one place, and makes it easier for the rpc client code to be used because callers know what arguments are needed without going to look at the server code. It also makes it easier to deal with versioning, since the different methods can have different signatures. In such a design, cast() and call() would become private methods on the client.

I do like the idea of a decorator as a convenience for handling the type conversion in the server-side code (on the API object), too. What you described looks exactly like WSME. Maybe we could even use the same code."}, {'account_id': 4393, 'date': '2013-05-14 00:31:06.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2:

Mark,

Is this what you had in mind? I think this will easily move over to your "new world" stuff...

https://github.com/kk7ds/oslo-incubator/commit/8349d2fd7ad85825310b0e8db39114b267cd8a17'}, {'account_id': 2472, 'date': '2013-05-15 13:56:24.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2:

I think what Mark was describing would look a little more like https://github.com/openstack/ceilometer/blob/master/ceilometer/api/controllers/v2.py#L548

The decorator provides a class for each argument and the "deserialization" code takes the values out of the message to create instances of the classes for the arguments.

If we do use WSME, it will give us JSON strings, so we have a dictionary mapping argument names to the JSON encoded representation passing down into the RPC library, where it is encoded in some driver-specific way for transmission (but that's easy, since we know we just have a mapping of unicode strings and no other types for the drivers to deal with). On the other side of the call, the driver unpacks its wire-protocol and creates a mapping of unicode string pairs, which the WSME layer turns back into objects for us to use in the application code.'}, {'account_id': 4393, 'date': '2013-05-15 15:09:03.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2:

Hmm, so you mean we decorate all of our methods to declare when and where we expect to receive/return an object? Presumably we'd have to decorate the rpcapi.py methods as well as the manager methods.

My problem with doing so is it's a lot of marking up of each method we expect to be able to handle this, when we already have an effective way of (de-)serializing objects in a general way. If we push this generic work into the RPC layer so that it just "happens" we actually don't have to modify much of our existing code for it to work as it does today.'}, {'account_id': 1247, 'date': '2013-05-15 21:25:47.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2:

Having looked a bit more at Dan's Nova branch, I'm pretty convinced that the Serializer class approach makes the most sense

The strategy is for non-primitive objects to know how to serialize and deserialize themselves and the Serializer class in Nova is just a way of hooking in the object marshalling protocol into the RPC layer

i.e. objects are serialized using to_primitive() method, their primitive representation includes the class name which is used to look up the class whose from_primitive() method is used to deserialize

That's pretty simple and means the Nova serializer class isn't a "huge registry of all serialization capabilities" as Doug was worried about

I can see us including this serializer and the base object class in oslo.messaging once we've proven it out in Nova'}, {'account_id': 1247, 'date': '2013-05-15 21:28:15.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2:

Dan - couple of minor things on the serializer stuff

Could you add it as openstack.common.rpc.serializer - that way I can just re-use it directly in the new messaging API

Also, NoOpSerializer can just be a subclass of Serializer and then you don't need the Serializer.register() call"}, {'account_id': 4393, 'date': '2013-05-15 23:55:30.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2:

Sounds good, thanks Mark!

I'm out for the next couple of days, but I'll try to get this fixed up and submitted ASAP."}, {'account_id': 4393, 'date': '2013-05-19 21:14:14.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 3.'}, {'account_id': 3, 'date': '2013-05-19 21:16:41.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 3: Doesn't seem to work

Build failed.  For information on how to proceed, see https://wiki.openstack.org/wiki/GerritJenkinsGithub#Test_Failures

- http://logs.openstack.org/28744/3/check/gate-oslo-incubator-python27/1691 : SUCCESS in 1m 59s

revisions:
[{'created': '2013-05-09 23:11:51.000000000', 'message': 'Add serialization hooks to RpcProxy

This adds hooks in RpcProxy to serialize arguments on the way out
and to deserialize a response on the way back in from a call. The
base serialization implementation can call a to_primitive() method
on the argument, if it has one, making it likely to work for
actual users. The deserialization is just a pass-through hook
right now, which can be implemented appropriately in a subclass.

Change-Id: I0a33baddee3e28dfc47100eb3216b679558b0bdd
'}, {'created': '2013-05-11 00:17:47.000000000', 'message': 'Add serialization hooks to RpcProxy

This adds hooks in RpcProxy to serialize arguments on the way out
and to deserialize a response on the way back in from a call. The
base serialization implementation can call a to_primitive() method
on the argument, if it has one, making it likely to work for
actual users. The deserialization is just a pass-through hook
right now, which can be implemented appropriately in a subclass.

Related to blueprint rpc-object-serialization

Change-Id: I0a33baddee3e28dfc47100eb3216b679558b0bdd
'}, {'created': '2013-05-19 21:14:14.000000000', 'message': 'Add generic serialization support

This adds a generic serialization model that the RpcProxy and
RpcDispatcher will use to serialize and deserialize arguments
and return values. The base definition is provided, as well
as a default NoOpSerializer which performs no special
action (retaining the existing behavior).

Related to blueprint rpc-object-serialization

Change-Id: I0a33baddee3e28dfc47100eb3216b679558b0bdd
'}, {'created': '2013-05-20 13:39:02.000000000', 'message': 'Add generic serialization support

This adds a generic serialization model that the RpcProxy and
RpcDispatcher will use to serialize and deserialize arguments
and return values. The base definition is provided, as well
as a default NoOpSerializer which performs no special
action (retaining the existing behavior).

Related to blueprint rpc-object-serialization

Change-Id: I0a33baddee3e28dfc47100eb3216b679558b0bdd

commit_message:
Add generic serialization support

This adds a generic serialization model that the RpcProxy and
RpcDispatcher will use to serialize and deserialize arguments
and return values. The base definition is provided, as well
as a default NoOpSerializer which performs no special
action (retaining the existing behavior).

Related to blueprint rpc-object-serialization

Change-Id: I0a33baddee3e28dfc47100eb3216b679558b0bdd

subject: Pass quantum admin credentials when setting up client
messages:
[{'account_id': 3, 'date': '2013-05-16 17:27:15.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Works for me

Build succeeded.

- http://logs.openstack.org/29402/1/check/gate-nova-pep8/26042 : SUCCESS in 3m 08s
- http://docs-draft.openstack.org/29402/1/check/gate-nova-docs/20260/doc/build/html/ : SUCCESS in 2m 25s
- http://logs.openstack.org/29402/1/check/gate-nova-python26/21666 : SUCCESS in 11m 58s
- http://logs.openstack.org/29402/1/check/gate-nova-python27/21756 : SUCCESS in 8m 24s
- http://logs.openstack.org/29402/1/check/gate-tempest-devstack-vm-full/16343 : SUCCESS in 50m 54s
- http://logs.openstack.org/29402/1/check/gate-tempest-devstack-vm-postgres-full/16059 : FAILURE in 42m 58s (non-voting)
- http://logs.openstack.org/29402/1/check/gate-tempest-devstack-vm-quantum/22870 : SUCCESS in 19m 08s
- http://logs.openstack.org/29402/1/check/gate-grenade-devstack-vm/3939 : FAILURE in 11m 19s (non-voting)
- http://logs.openstack.org/29402/1/check/gate-nova-pylint/11645 : SUCCESS in 7m 54s (non-voting)
'}, {'account_id': 1561, 'date': '2013-05-16 17:35:34.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1: I would prefer that you didn't merge this

This is a pretty brute force solution ... I'd like to see if this could be solved without having to resort to this.

Can't you use a token to create a new token?  If so, can nova just create its own temporary token from the user's token so it controls how long it lasts?  I don't really like this solution either, because of the additional keystone traffic required.

Any other ideas here?  We could just accept this as the way it works ... that doesn't seem so unreasonable, as many things are done async from the API request."}, {'account_id': 6873, 'date': '2013-05-17 01:16:04.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

Russell, I don't think this is really forcing anything, it's just fixing a problem where if the token becomes invalid the operation continues to work.  The token could become invalid through several cases like it's deleted (the case in the bug), it expires, the user's role changes, etc.  In this flow, nova authenticates with the quantum client first (using the same credentials I'm passing in this patch) to get a token and then passes that token to the quantum client.  If the token becomes invalid, then quantum tries to re-authenticate (using the same quantum HTTPClient.authenticate method that nova is using to get the token in the first place).  The problem is nova doesn't supply the credentials to the client so it can't re-authenticate and it fails if the token becomes invalid.

I think this is probably more of an edge case, but it's a way to make the operation between nova and quantum more resilient.

If this clarifies the issue but the commit message is lacking, let me know and I can update that."}, {'account_id': 6873, 'date': '2013-05-17 15:22:37.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

Hmm, looks like this might fix the bug also:

https://review.openstack.org/#/c/23198/

They cache the credentials and pass them to the quantum client rather than re-create a token and client every time nova needs to talk to quantum.'}, {'account_id': 6873, 'date': '2013-05-21 16:03:34.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1: Abandoned

I'm going to abandon this change as it looks like https://review.openstack.org/#/c/23198/ will also fix the issue."}]
revisions:
[{'created': '2013-05-16 16:35:56.000000000', 'message': 'Pass quantum admin credentials when setting up client

This patch fixes a race condition where the user gets a token, uses it
to delete an instance, and immediately deletes the token before 
quantum can use it to clean up the network associated with the 
instance. Note that in this scenario the user is not waiting for the 
instance to be completely deleted before deleting the token that is 
passed to quantum.

Fixes bug 1177579

Change-Id: I3fe369402cbb0bc38ff3e528ba0eb0e7189cd66f
'}]
commit_message:
Pass quantum admin credentials when setting up client

This patch fixes a race condition where the user gets a token, uses it
to delete an instance, and immediately deletes the token before 
quantum can use it to clean up the network associated with the 
instance. Note that in this scenario the user is not waiting for the 
instance to be completely deleted before deleting the token that is 
passed to quantum.

Fixes bug 1177579

Change-Id: I3fe369402cbb0bc38ff3e528ba0eb0e7189cd66f

commit_message:
Allow suppression of v1 API.

Fixes bug 1180567

The v1 API is on the deprecation path, so should not require
that distros have all its dependencies available.

Thus we add a new configuration option to allow the v1 app
creation to be suppressed.

Change-Id: Ib5af241a57f54754be534c9acb92a377362571e3

commit_message:
Makes error message consistent with volume-attach

The patch for bug-1166770 hid the real exceptions raised by
check_attach. This patch fixes it so that more meaningful
exception messages can be given to the user and that they are
consistent with the volume-attach error messages

Change-Id: Ic5e93decffe8ccefe6d273033095a767b256f3cb
fixes: bug 1166770

commit_message:
Fallback to publicURL if adminURL is not found.

This change falls back on publicURL if the adminURL is not found in
the service catalog.  This change maintains the historic default
behavior of using 'adminURL' if it is there.

Also, adds a new exception type to handle the case where a suitable
endpoint type is not found in the catalog.  Without this, the
exception encountered is a KeyError that is not accurately reported to
the caller of the quantum command line.

Added unit tests for the url_for method of the Service Catalog which
trigger the problem with the previous code base and pass with this
proposed fix.

Fixes: Bug #1123383
Change-Id: If89fde3c80ad1858333395462ac9a6855618a499

Choose publicURL from keystone catalog by default.

Previous behavior was to choose adminURL.

Change-Id: Id414a20e6f4e863d3fec982b5a1173afa5531d28
Fixes: Bug #1123383

commit_message:
Expand controller abbreviations in WSGI resources

Several properites were expanded in the interest of readability. When in
doubt, be a little more verbose; you'll spend a lot more time reading
code than writing it.

Change-Id: I352bc8fab70c4c3707003bf528a37e61742aceb5
Implements: blueprint bp/grizzly-debt

[{'created': '2013-05-07 06:09:28.000000000', 'message': 'Update security_group_api param

The security_group_api value now should either be nova or quantum depending
if one is using nova security groups or quantum security groups. When set to
quantum all nova security group api requests are proxied to quantum.

Change-Id: Ib619ac3ce8face0cea59f9de145562bd6e8e1762

commit_message:
Update security_group_api param

The security_group_api value now should either be nova or quantum depending
if one is using nova security groups or quantum security groups. When set to
quantum all nova security group api requests are proxied to quantum.

Change-Id: Ib619ac3ce8face0cea59f9de145562bd6e8e1762

commit_message:
Clean up exception handling in the WSGI transport driver.

This patch localizes try...except blocks, DRYs construction of
certain HTTP exceptions, and modifies what types of exceptions
are thrown (in some cases), to be more precise.

I also factored out some input validation code that happened
to be mixed up with all the exception handling.

Implements: blueprint grizzly-debt
Change-Id: I1030308bed1ec55477b176bf022118d53b46b7ff

commit_message:
rename tests -> api

Now that all the other tests are moved out of the tests directory
we can rename tests -> api to reflect that these tests are api
testing, and need to use only the internal clients.

Clean up references from other parts of OpenStack to the new api
namespace.

Reorder the imports as required with this naming change.

Added README.rst

Change-Id: I19203957f917b59e7c8a3838c590937752461a2f

commit_message:
tests : add explicit dependency on cinderclient 1.0.4

https://review.openstack.org/#/c/28054/ introduces a test requirement
for the latest python-cinderclient, attempting to run with 1.0.3 results
in test_volume failing.  In due course we should probably fix test_volume
so it actually fakes the client instead of having this dependency

Change-Id: If9a649c7ce98125076e74243b17d115ca10acd01

commit_message:
Run the dnspython dependency back.

The initial dnspython dependency was probably a bit aggressive.  Ubuntu
Oneiric and Precise both packaged 1.9.4 and there's not too much in the
package changelog to recommend 1.10.0 over 1.9.4, at least not for a
requirement.

Change-Id: I8e2a03e4a89ee0f36c860cdaf21a7a0fea1709ca

revisions:
[{'created': '2013-04-29 18:57:16.000000000', 'message': 'Fixes race condition of deleting floating ip

Fixes bug #1172599
reproduce steps:
1. create an instance
2. get a floating ip from pool
3. associate the ip to instance created at step 1
4. delete the instance and the ip at a very little interval

reason may be that:
1. the action of delete ip find the ip is associated to a fixed ip at
   first(at api level)
2. and then the fixed ip is released when the instance is deleted
3. so nova-network manager findes this issue and raises
   exception.FloatingIpNotAssociated(address=floating_address)

Change-Id: I253d0b240451e8a728532639e9857894f6fc6870
(cherry picked from commit a5923541e990326a9b850926e74026d5947ae142)
'}]
commit_message:
Fixes race condition of deleting floating ip

Fixes bug #1172599
reproduce steps:
1. create an instance
2. get a floating ip from pool
3. associate the ip to instance created at step 1
4. delete the instance and the ip at a very little interval

reason may be that:
1. the action of delete ip find the ip is associated to a fixed ip at
   first(at api level)
2. and then the fixed ip is released when the instance is deleted
3. so nova-network manager findes this issue and raises
   exception.FloatingIpNotAssociated(address=floating_address)

Change-Id: I253d0b240451e8a728532639e9857894f6fc6870
(cherry picked from commit a5923541e990326a9b850926e74026d5947ae142)

revisions:
[{'created': '2013-05-02 19:06:35.000000000', 'message': "xenapi: Don't swallow missing SR exception

The existing code would catch a missing SR exception and bail out of the
`update_status` method before finishing, causing required keys to be missing.
The end-result was code breaking later on when it tried to access these keys.

Since an SR is required to generate these required stats keys, we shouldn't
swallow the StorageRepositoryNotFound exception and instead should fail-fast.

Fixes bug 1175357

Change-Id: I3d65ae807fb2d86277bc0061c1967a87792b6662
(cherry picked from commit b6aac988e46147154d49e938ecf9b67831613636)
"}]
commit_message:
xenapi: Don't swallow missing SR exception

The existing code would catch a missing SR exception and bail out of the
`update_status` method before finishing, causing required keys to be missing.
The end-result was code breaking later on when it tried to access these keys.

Since an SR is required to generate these required stats keys, we shouldn't
swallow the StorageRepositoryNotFound exception and instead should fail-fast.

Fixes bug 1175357

Change-Id: I3d65ae807fb2d86277bc0061c1967a87792b6662
(cherry picked from commit b6aac988e46147154d49e938ecf9b67831613636)

- don't run the tests in parallel as the db tests have one connection

nova_tests hackery:
It seems testtools/testr imports everything and I just don't see a way of
running things in tests/ and nova_tests/ seperately but in one testenv.
So if you want to use testr directly you will need to:
 testr run
 cd nova_tests
 testr run

So if you want to use testr directly you will need to:

commit_message:
Replace nose with testr

- add .testr.conf (in base dir and nova_tests)
- remove all references to nose
- adjust paths: A couple of tests would assume the current directory
  was ./tests/ but it is now ./
- don't run the tests in parallel as the db tests have one connection
  per test class.

nova_tests hackery:
It seems testtools/testr imports everything and I just don't see a way of
running things in tests/ and nova_tests/ seperately but in one .test.conf.
So if you want to use testr directly you will need to:
 testr run
 cd nova_tests
 testr run

part of bug 1177924
Change-Id: I41875dcf94463fa5f9c07a7840c37089226c59ad

commit_message:
Use fixtures in the tests

TempDir() makes sure all files created under it are deleted
at the end of the tests.
FakeLogger() hides logs when the test passes and displays logs
for failed tests.

part of bug 1177924
Change-Id: I07acb66daa1932d7864a5431f1b64570b747ce5a

commit_message:
Fix cinder always converts raw images even if they are already raw

During the creation process of the command "cinder create --image-id"
cinder tries to convert the image no matter what the orign format is.
Thus the process can be speed up by simply checking if the image already
has the good format, if so we don't run the qemu-img command.

Change-Id: Ie683735c3dede9944bd5d41c729596b04b72c17d
Fixes: bug #1180831

'}, {'account_id': 4257, 'date': '2013-05-17 15:52:12.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 7:

After discussing with Thomas on IRC yesterday, I now realise I was looking at the wrong API documentation (the Nova Volume Attachments extension).

Volume attachment _has_ actually moved to Cinder, but it's undocumented in the "API Complete Reference" (why would anybody ever need to do that, right?).

So, from the cinderclient code, it appears that properties that appeared in the original patch were correct:
* instance_uuid
* volume_id
* mountpoint

Sorry for the confusion :('}, {'account_id': 4715, 'date': '2013-05-19 23:50:25.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 7: I would prefer that you didn't merge this

(1 inline comment)

I am a bit confused here:

 Zane said the properties should be:
    instance_uuid
    volume_id
    mountpoint

 but in the code it has:
 properties_schema = {'server_id': {'Type': 'String',
                      'volumeId': {'Type': 'String',
                      'device': {'Type': 'String',

 Thomas/Zane which one is correct?"}, {'account_id': 2834, 'date': '2013-05-20 03:56:46.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 7: I would prefer that you didn't merge this

to update the commit message then to be consistent.'}, {'account_id': 2834, 'date': '2013-05-21 05:25:46.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 7: I would prefer that you didn't merge this

commit_message:
Implement OS::Cinder::VolumeAttachment

This creates a new volume attachment resource with Cinder specific
naming.

Change-Id: Ie73b929925c58e47f3509d57dd385cbd4ea5a4c1

commit_message:
update proposed API to be more resource oriented

/node/<id> is really the resource, so the id should change in
location, and not be at the end of the resource

Change-Id: I59853b33017b7eb59f053b985531ef4ea281bc79

commit_message:
engine : cleanup Resource.update error paths

The current update code uses a nasty pattern where returning an
arbitrary string from Resource.update is interpreted in parser.Stack
as an error.  Instead use exceptions which is much nicer :)

Change-Id: I2ddebfd6bbec3dc229012406da72dd928fcc4595
