commit_message:
Reference DEFAULT_SERVICETYPE OptGoup names in lowercase

To have consistent option group name format across projects,
oslo.config now normalizes all non lowercase group names to lowercase
when loading conf files.
Thus conf files are backwards compatible but option group references
in the code must now use lowercase before we update oslo.config.

This patch replaces all 'DEFAULT_SERVICETYPE' references to
'default_servicetype'

Change-Id: Iccab055c4664e11c9618706e594416194065048b

commit_message:
Reference QUOTA OptGoup names in lowercase

To have consistent option group name format across projects,
oslo.config now normalizes all non lowercase group names to lowercase
when loading conf files.
Thus conf files are backwards compatible but option group references
in the code must now use lowercase before we update oslo.config.

This patch replaces all 'QUOTA' references to 'quota'

Change-Id: I74c2a35aea7a52f9586eb598fe52d2cecb1851ef

commit_message:
Make logging level in unit tests configurable.

Added a debug option to unittest(BaseTestCase) which sets logging level of
fixtures.FakeLogger to DEBUG. To enable this option, set OS_DEBUG=True or
OS_DEBUG=1 in environment variables.

Fixes: bug #1181925
Change-Id: Id09008ddabb837290edf12e1cbd014dc74760113

revisions:
[{'created': '2013-05-20 22:19:43.000000000', 'message': 'Allow RPC_API_NAMESPACE on RpcProxy objects

This allows one to subclass RpcProxy for use with a particular
namespace without having to repeatedly pass the namespace into the
make_namespaced_msg() method.  This new RPC_API_NAMESPACE attribute will
be used for the make_msg() call.  It is defaulted to None to match previous
behavior.

Change-Id: Ied62df839cda0be6f9f9b060bbfc22e086f61be8
'}]
commit_message:
Allow RPC_API_NAMESPACE on RpcProxy objects

This allows one to subclass RpcProxy for use with a particular
namespace without having to repeatedly pass the namespace into the
make_namespaced_msg() method.  This new RPC_API_NAMESPACE attribute will
be used for the make_msg() call.  It is defaulted to None to match previous
behavior.

Change-Id: Ied62df839cda0be6f9f9b060bbfc22e086f61be8

  - Sanity check for from_port, to_port, and IP protocol when adding
    a security rule
  - Print one more column 'Id' for security groups
  - If there are multiple security groups with the same name, the group
    can't be deleted unless an ID is specified. However, there is no code
    to search and delete security group by ID. So, _get_secgroup() will
    get group by ID if the input is like a UUID. If not found, then get
    group by name.
  - Some corresponding changes for help messages.
  - Test case changes after adding sanity check.

Change-Id: Ibd82d8404bdd64e4bca2f8b25756bfaff7b28194
Signed-off-by: Shane Wang <shane.wang@intel.com>

    to search and delete security group by ID. So, _get_secgroup() will

Change-Id: Ibd82d8404bdd64e4bca2f8b25756bfaff7b28194

commit_message:
Cleanup nova subcommands for security groups and rules

The Changes include:
  - Sanity check for from_port, to_port, and IP protocol when adding
    a security rule
  - Print one more column 'Id' for security groups
  - If there are multiple security groups with the same name, the group
    can't be deleted unless an ID is specified. However, there is no code
    to search and delete security group by ID. So, _get_secgroup() will
    get group by ID if the input is like a UUID. If not found, then get
    group by name.
  - Some corresponding changes for help messages.
  - Test case changes after adding sanity check.

Change-Id: Ibd82d8404bdd64e4bca2f8b25756bfaff7b28194
Signed-off-by: Shane Wang <shane.wang@intel.com>

commit_message:
Create quantum networks for server tests.

Allows compute tests to utilize the quantumclient to create
required networks for the randomly generated tenants used in the
compute.servers tests.

Update: * pep8 fix.
        * Skip tests if quantum available with no tenant
          credentials.
        * Create and raise net/subnet creation exceptions.

Change-Id: I2000e392d25e7b7206500740a0797262bdcedebb
Fixes: (LP: #1092009)

commit_message:
Move common code into a separate function.

test_get_valid and test_get_valid_key2 test tempurl with a
single key and two keys respectively. This change moves common code
for these tests into a separate function.

Change-Id: Ifee211285e27df03d041a4c357b7c1f0c96ed6a8

commit_message:
Make br-ctlplane bridge configuration persistent.

Config /e/n/i to have br-ctlplane configured on first boot
and persistent across reboots.

Fixes: bug #1178099
Change-Id: Idf557e198e9803a37bd1a8c163ff461edb32a6f4

commit_message:
Allow the HTTPClient consumer to pass endpoint_type.

Changes the default behavior of the client.  It will now choose
publicURL by default rather than adminURL.

Now allows the consumer to pass adminURL, internalURL or some other
endpoint type when constructing a Client to override this default
behavior.

Adds --endpoint-type option to the shell client.  Defaults to the
environment variable OS_ENDPOINT_TYPE or publicURL.  This was
patterned after the same option in the Nova client.

Adds a new exception type to handle the case where a suitable endpoint
type is not found in the catalog.  Without this, the exception
encountered is a KeyError that was not clearly reported to the caller
of the quantum command line.

Change-Id: Iaffcaff291d433a605d8379dc89c1308096d36c2
Fixes: Bug #1176197

commit_message:
Add ability to save builder data to a disk file

Instances of the RingBuilder class can store its data to a disk file by
the save method and load it by the load method.

blueprint argparse-in-swift-ring-builder

Change-Id: I69fdf0693ca9f520d235a795ecdd2da310dcd5d3

Change-Id: I6661d99937614b4b444de2e2542ab36e4424878d
'}]
commit_message:
Set version available when loading V2 admin api

If the admin service is loaded without the public service it does not
register a version and so will not respond to /v2/.

Change-Id: I6661d99937614b4b444de2e2542ab36e4424878d

I thought we were going to get a wiki explaining the file layout directory layout prior to considering this change.  Has that been posted?"}, {'account_id': 6072, 'date': '2013-05-21 06:03:04.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 5:

commit_message:
Being more defensive around the use_ipv6 config option

fixes bug 1175725

Will allow for the flag to be set to filter out ipv6 if
configured but will not add ipv6 to template if ipv6 is not
configured in quantum. This will allow spwan to continue
working in the case where ipv6 is not configured but flag
use_ipv6 is set in nova.

Change-Id: I26ebdff81efcdeff827521cec247d2c443a5e0ad
(cherry picked from commit 005b9950ac84bf3ae06c24ee018f192064060428)

commit_message:
Fix a deleted flavor still could be shown

This commit fix 2 problems, 1. A deleted flavor still show
2. 'flavor-show' a new flavor which id use previous deleted
flavor id will show the deleted flavor information.

Change-Id: I9586009af76fbf716c3a3f4c126ace47ea9094eb
Fixes: bug 1168260
Depends On: I143903cb

commit_message:
UpdateStack for AWS::AutoScaling::ScalingPolicy

Implemented update support of the ScalingPolicy resource
in an existing stack. ScalingAdjustment, AdjustmentType,
and Cooldown properties are allowed properties for update.
A handle_update method is added to update differences in
the template.

Change-Id: Ieeae93560a315a8a35c6fb2d8f1d78a89123bec3
blueprint: scalingpolicy-update-stack

commit_message:
Adds sudo check for privileged operations.

Adds root user check to determine whether or not sudo is required
for MySQL status and installation.  We now run sudo -l to verify
that the user is in the sudoers file, the credentials are then
cached for the rest of the operations.

bug 1181701

Change-Id: I294b269046ee2049b0fdee3c871096387cefbf24

commit_message:
engine : remove unused update states/status

We have some aws-isms in the update code related to different
update states, which is not actually used anywhere, so may as
well remove it - it's probably easier at least for now to focus
on the three update states of COMPLETE/FAILED/REPLACEMENT

Change-Id: Ieeaf92ab0fec6bbfab3dddf2d8fecb0b38c1b2fc

'}, {'account_id': 2243, 'date': '2013-05-09 22:55:20.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: I would prefer that you didn't merge this

Hi Jenny,

Thanks for putting this together, forgive the question here, but wouldn't it be possible to implement this further down the line in say "cinder/volume/volume_types.py" to be consistent with how we do the notifications for volumes?

Maybe I'm missing something here but having this as an API extension seems inconsistent.  I'll gladly revert my -1 if I'm wrong about this.'}, {'account_id': 7482, 'date': '2013-05-10 18:38:23.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 2.'}, {'account_id': 7482, 'date': '2013-05-10 19:15:30.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2:

Hi John,

Thanks for your feedback. If we implement the notifier further down to "cinder/volume/volume_types.py", there are 2 cases that the notifier will not be generated at all at this layer. 

Case 1: To recreate an existing volumeType. The exception "VolumeTypeExists" will be thrown by db.volume_type_create() in create() where only catch DBError. Same for NotFound exception case.

Case 2: To delete a non-existed volumeType. NotFound exception will be thrown by volume_types.get_volume_type() in _delete() before volume_types.destroy() is called. To add notifier in volume_types.py will not help in this case.

Please let me know if you have other concerns.'}, {'account_id': 3, 'date': '2013-05-10 19:28:33.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2: Works for me

commit_message:
Adds notifiers to both volumeTypes and volumeTypeExtraSpecs

1. add notifier to create and delete volumeTypes
2. add notifier to create, update and delete volumeTypeExtraSpecs

Implements: notifiers for volumetypes and extra specs
Fixes: bug #1176259
Change-Id: I30fe6cb764e5fda7c876a8b7256d9b0c0f4a7fdd

The test code does a good job of testing that the query parameters make it though intact to the API. However, there is no test that the get_account/container functions correctly handle the marker logic when you are getting a full listing. As you know, the get_account/container functions keep making GET requests, using marker to pick up the "next" bunch of names. A test that verified that this is done correctly would be useful -- especially as GET/end_marker stops *before* it returns the end_marker.

I had hoped to post an example of what I mean, but I'm failing to pass a body to fake_http_connection(). I'll keep trying.'}, {'account_id': 2622, 'date': '2013-05-10 23:19:52.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 4: Looks good to me (core reviewer)

I certainly agree with Donagh McCabe that such a test would be useful, but I think it's fine to have that added on in a separate patch.

As it is, this patch adds code and tests for 'end_marker' and 'path', and as a bonus, also gives us the missing tests for a bunch of other params."}, {'account_id': 330, 'date': '2013-05-21 00:14:35.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 4: Looks good to me, but someone else must approve

commit_message:
Update swift_ring_builder to support replicator...

Updates swift_ring_builder rebalancing parsing to support the
latest upstream replicator_id and replicator_port changes.

This correspondes with swift 1.8+ upstream development.

Fixes LP Bug #1182197.

Change-Id: Ibbaf75ca22cad95b22f9b5f03b547db8c47a9ea4

revisions:
[{'created': '2013-05-10 21:00:15.000000000', 'message': 'Swap the order of baremetal partitions.

Automatically growing the root partition via cloud-init depends on there being
empty space after the partition in the partition table. The current layout has
no such space. We could either put the swap partition at the end of the disk
rather than just after the root partition, or we can switch the order of the
partitions. Neither seems intrinsically better so I have opted for the smallest
code change.

Fixes bug 1178118.

Change-Id: I3b0688a24e284f3d3bd890a09ff3cf3ebf76877b
'}]
commit_message:
Swap the order of baremetal partitions.

Automatically growing the root partition via cloud-init depends on there being
empty space after the partition in the partition table. The current layout has
no such space. We could either put the swap partition at the end of the disk
rather than just after the root partition, or we can switch the order of the
partitions. Neither seems intrinsically better so I have opted for the smallest
code change.

Fixes bug 1178118.

Change-Id: I3b0688a24e284f3d3bd890a09ff3cf3ebf76877b

commit_message:
Add respawn limit to prevent infinite respawn.

The respawn count is not incremented until post-start exits, so we
need to set the count lower than the interval to allow for the lag
caused by the one second sleep. Two times in 5 seconds seems like
enough to handle the occasional unexpected crash but stay dead when
things are badly broken.

Change-Id: I8eaca6f9ea131861a42d473ffc5c09a41226ce0e

commit_message:
Rename requires files to standard names

From bug report:
Rename tools/pip-requires to requirements.txt and tools/test-requires
to test-requirements.txt. These are standard files and tools in the
general world are growing intelligence about them.

Change-Id: I5d3bad7654e4ce101d19b40215d8c1cc93dd9832
Fixes: Bug #1179008

commit_message:
Correct DiskFilter description

The description of the DiskFilter scheduler mentioned only
ephemeral storage. This commit updates that description to
include root storage as well.

Fixes bug #1182259

Change-Id: Ib3f01c564fe04bc3ce5e077569efb7245d42eea7

commit_message:
Start openvswitch in Fedora based instructions

Without starting the openvswitch init script, ovs-vsctl
won't work properly since the ovsdb and kernel modules
are not loaded.

Change-Id: I0133817bb9648ab8f6106d5ed3000043af498ca0

subject: Fixes for the GlusterFS driver
messages:
[{'account_id': 3, 'date': '2013-05-14 18:00:25.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Works for me

Build succeeded.

- http://docs-draft.openstack.org/gate-openstack-cli-guide/check/1315/cli/quick-start : SUCCESS in 00:03:38

'}, {'account_id': 4523, 'date': '2013-05-17 16:08:53.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1: I would prefer that you didn't merge this

(1 inline comment)

"}, {'account_id': 6859, 'date': '2013-05-17 16:55:55.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

Regarding Eric's inline comment:

It's a fair observation. Just to clarify, though, you have been using GlusterFS *volumes* with EL6? GlusterFS as an instance store will work on most kernels because Nova correctly determines if O_DIRECT is supported and changes the caching options on the fly. This dynamic configuration does not happen for volumes yet. 

O_DIRECT for FUSE wasn't enabled until Linux kernel 3.4 released in May of 2012. If you have working GlusterFS volumes with EL6, I think it's safe to assume it's because O_DIRECT was backported to the kernel version you are using (2.6).

If that's true, then I agree that the note I'm proposing can come off as confusing. Maybe the note can be changed to read something like:

"You must use a Linux kernel greater than version 3.3 (or a RHEL kernel of 2.6.32) ... "'}, {'account_id': 4523, 'date': '2013-05-17 17:18:47.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

Correct, O_DIRECT for FUSE was backported to RHEL/CentOS 6.3 kernels.  This puts the required revision at 2.6.32-220, I think.  (All EL6* uses 2.6.32-xxx.)

Probably easiest to say something like "(or kernel 2.6.32 in EL/CentOS 6.3 or newer)".'}, {'account_id': 6859, 'date': '2013-05-17 18:30:11.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 2.'}, {'account_id': 3, 'date': '2013-05-17 18:43:01.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2: Works for me

Fixes for the GlusterFS driver

This patch adds a note about which kernel version is
required for GlusterFS-based volumes. Also fixes formatting.

Change-Id: I73238528f89247bb8717914b509c4728ab805e68

[{'created': '2013-05-20 21:32:09.000000000', 'message': 'Set TZ environment variable to avoid a stat call

By setting the TZ environment variable for the WSGI process we avoid
the stat("/etc/localtime") on every request handled that logs using
strftime().

Change-Id: Ifc78236a99ed193a42389e383d062b38f57a5a31
Signed-off-by: Peter Portante <peter.portante@redhat.com>
'}]
commit_message:
Set TZ environment variable to avoid a stat call

By setting the TZ environment variable for the WSGI process we avoid
the stat("/etc/localtime") on every request handled that logs using
strftime().

Change-Id: Ifc78236a99ed193a42389e383d062b38f57a5a31
Signed-off-by: Peter Portante <peter.portante@redhat.com>

commit_message:
Fix two documentation warnings.

The crossdomain doc was named *.xml instead of *.rst causing it to not
get built or included in the toctree where it was supposed to.

The apache deployment guide wasn't linked to from anywhere, so I added
it under the normal deployment guide.

Change-Id: I817a1f2ca1ed7913e8ea5155cc1fac07caf0b637

commit_message:
Don't delete containers when they weren't created.

When swift-bench is run in direct mode, don't try to delete the
containers which weren't created.

Fixes bug 1177960.

Change-Id: Ice07e8729bb776e2b215894cf95fb80b64167a8d

[{'created': '2013-05-07 01:38:01.000000000', 'message': "Fixing backend Token purging for memcache

Added in functionality to prune the token_lists (user or revocation)
to ensure we do not fill up a complete memcache page and cause
token issuing/revoking to fail.  The flush only occurs if a memcache
page is full when a new token is issued (or revoked) with exception
to the list functions if the max_*_list_size options are set to a
non-zero value.

This changeset also adds in the capability to administratively
expire long-lived-tokens in the case the that list(s) have
exceeded an appropriate size (filled up a page).

The dummy memcache driver will now behave a bit more like a
real memcache (where the data stored in the cache isn't modified
when a reference to the original data/get of data is changed).

New options added:
* max_revocation_list_size:
        maximum size of the revocation list before a flush is
        called.  0 means no flush will be called unless the
        memcache page is full.

* max_user_record_list_size:
        maximum size of the user_record holding the references to
        the actual tokens. This is only relevant when a call to
        token_api.list_tokens() is made. A value of 0 indicates
        we do not care about the list size and will only
        flush if the memcache page is full

* max_compare_and_set_retry:
        The number of retries that will be attempted when performing
        an update of the user_record or the revocation-list record.
        This is relevant due to the use of CAS (compare and set)
        function of the memcache client. This allows for multiple
        keystone processes/wsgi/etc to run without worry of race
        conditions clobbering the lists.

Change-Id: I82706abfe70cdea06a923e08d0428c7865c194a7
Fixes: bug #1171985

commit_message:
Fixing backend Token purging for memcache

Added in functionality to prune the token_lists (user or revocation)
to ensure we do not fill up a complete memcache page and cause
token issuing/revoking to fail.  The flush only occurs if a memcache
page is full when a new token is issued (or revoked) with exception
to the list functions if the max_*_list_size options are set to a
non-zero value.

This changeset also adds in the capability to administratively
expire long-lived-tokens in the case the that list(s) have
exceeded an appropriate size (filled up a page).

The dummy memcache driver will now behave a bit more like a
real memcache (where the data stored in the cache isn't modified
when a reference to the original data/get of data is changed).

New options added:
* max_revocation_list_size:
        maximum size of the revocation list before a flush is
        called.  0 means no flush will be called unless the
        memcache page is full.

* max_user_record_list_size:
        maximum size of the user_record holding the references to
        the actual tokens. This is only relevant when a call to
        token_api.list_tokens() is made. A value of 0 indicates
        we do not care about the list size and will only
        flush if the memcache page is full

* max_compare_and_set_retry:
        The number of retries that will be attempted when performing
        an update of the user_record or the revocation-list record.
        This is relevant due to the use of CAS (compare and set)
        function of the memcache client. This allows for multiple
        keystone processes/wsgi/etc to run without worry of race
        conditions clobbering the lists.

Change-Id: I82706abfe70cdea06a923e08d0428c7865c194a7
Fixes: bug #1171985

[{'created': '2013-05-21 00:08:49.000000000', 'message': 'get_security_groups now creates default security group

If one called get_security_groups() previously the default security
group would not be created until the tenant created a network. This
exposed a bug when an admin creates a shared network and a tenant tried
to boot a vm on it without having any networks.

Fixes bug 1171997

Change-Id: I899203424c03353a1ee6567c9ddbaecd7dc25001
'}]
commit_message:
get_security_groups now creates default security group

If one called get_security_groups() previously the default security
group would not be created until the tenant created a network. This
exposed a bug when an admin creates a shared network and a tenant tried
to boot a vm on it without having any networks.

Fixes bug 1171997

Change-Id: I899203424c03353a1ee6567c9ddbaecd7dc25001

commit_message:
update-port error if port does not exist in nvp

Previously the NVP plugin would query NVP for the quantum port id that was
stored in the port as a tag in NVP. Later, a look up table was added in order
to directly look up the ID without having to go to NVP. The problem that can
arise is that if a port was created in folsom before this lookup table was
added and then deleted from NVP directly an error will be raised when calling
update_port(). This patch fixes this potential problem.

Fixes bug 1172006

Conflicts:

	quantum/plugins/nicira/nicira_nvp_plugin/QuantumPlugin.py

Change-Id: I08c74e305449f7fe32897abf43ceb430c959b02d
(Cherry picked from 31946ebb5d7748fada269bd867f0e6d6e02ef736)

commit_message:
Allow secure user password update.

This patch allows the ability for user password to be updated via
a command prompt so the password doesnt show up in the bash history.
The prompted password is asked twice to verify the match.
If user cntl-D's the prompt a message appears suggesting user to use
either of the options to update the password.

Fixes: bug#938315

Change-Id: I4271ae569b922f33c34f9b015a7ee6f760414e39

commit_message:
relax amqplib and kombu version requirements

as nova did while ago.

this particular version of kombu doesn't work if newer msgpack happens
to be installed on the system.

bug 1178512

Change-Id: I2749623036723b5a772b1c4c01dc07437e421925
(cherry picked from commit 3a50a702f94344ef9903d1c7342d7d516e44a254)

commit_message:
Fix fake bmc driver.

The fake BMCDriver implementation accidentally copied, rather than
inherited from, the base class definition.

Change-Id: Ic2552dfdc93ad262c6ce04126f1133cd543bd800

'}, {'account_id': 1926, 'date': '2013-05-20 22:39:55.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

Just wondering, is there any particular reason its only needed on Red Hat systems ?'}, {'account_id': 2265, 'date': '2013-05-20 22:39:55.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1: I would prefer that you didn't merge this

(2 inline comments)

"}, {'account_id': 5756, 'date': '2013-05-20 22:39:55.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: (2 inline comments)

'}, {'account_id': 5756, 'date': '2013-05-20 22:39:55.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

correction: we don't have a separate l3 agent PACKAGE. not service. :p"}, {'account_id': 5756, 'date': '2013-05-20 22:39:55.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

and on there server.pp change, ubuntu has a quantum-common package that pretty much everything already relies on that has the config files that are being modified. So no change required for them either.'}, {'account_id': 5756, 'date': '2013-05-20 22:39:55.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: (2 inline comments)

'}, {'account_id': 5756, 'date': '2013-05-20 22:39:55.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

It's because we don't have a separate l3 agent service, so the l3 agent.ini is actually part of the quantum package instead."}, {'account_id': 7010, 'date': '2013-05-20 22:39:55.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Looks good to me, but someone else must approve

'}, {'account_id': 7156, 'date': '2013-05-20 22:39:55.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1: I would prefer that you didn't merge this

(2 inline comments)

"}, {'account_id': 3, 'date': '2013-05-20 22:39:55.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2: Works for me

Build succeeded.

- http://logs.openstack.org/27566/2/check/gate-puppet-quantum-puppet-unit-2.6/83 : SUCCESS in 00:00:31
- http://logs.openstack.org/27566/2/check/gate-puppet-quantum-puppet-unit-2.7/83 : SUCCESS in 00:00:35
- http://logs.openstack.org/27566/2/check/gate-puppet-quantum-puppet-unit-3.0/83 : SUCCESS in 00:00:30
- http://logs.openstack.org/27566/2/check/gate-puppet-quantum-puppet-unit-3.1/83 : SUCCESS in 00:00:28
'}, {'account_id': 5756, 'date': '2013-05-20 22:39:55.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2: I would prefer that you didn't merge this

Without something like the l3.pp change I had in Patch 1, this still fails with:

ERROR : Error during puppet run : err: /Stage[main]/Quantum::Agents::L3/Quantum_l3_agent_config[DEFAULT/admin_tenant_name]/ensure: change from absent to present failed: Could not set 'present on ensure: No such file or directory - /etc/quantum/l3_agent.ini

This is because on RH systems, there is no l3 agent package. Since Quantum_l3_agent_config<||> ~> Service['quantum-l3'] and Quantum_l3_agent_config has no dependency that requires Package['quantum'] which is where l3_agent.ini lives on RH systems, then the l3_agent.ini ends up getting edited when it hasn't necessarily been installed.

After adding the l3.pp change back to this change, though, this patch works."}, {'account_id': 7156, 'date': '2013-05-20 22:39:55.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2:

commit_message:
Support platforms without quantum server package

RedHat platforms don't have a separate package for the quantum server.

Change-Id: Ied83733f1dc8ec55a664e1d9c7119d3105a0a8e2

commit_message:
Editable default quota support

Implement blueprint edit-default-quota

DocImpact

Using the class quotas named `default` as the default editable quotas.

We can use the following novaclient command to update default quota:

nova quota-class-update default <key> <value>

Change-Id: I5a5001fadcbd61d550ebd5bdc33613b0ffdf29b2

commit_message:
Added attribute 'ip' to server search options.

Allows all tenants to use attribute 'ip' in server search options.
For this fix, added attribute 'ip' to server search options.
Modified the existing test case to verify 'ip' search for all tenants.

Implements: blueprint add-attribute-ip-in-server-search-options

Change-Id: Ic24ee67d729f77d56c4fe3e1d4110865550c2154

Ed: I agree with most of your comments except for certain lines where you oppose the "/" in favor of encapsulation with paranthesis. Maybe you could spend some time making a case for why the later should be perfered over the former and present it at next week's #reddwarf meeting.'}, {'account_id': 1375, 'date': '2013-05-20 22:06:01.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 18:

http://www.python.org/dev/peps/pep-0008/#maximum-line-length

"The preferred way of wrapping long lines is by using Python's implied line continuation inside parentheses, brackets and braces. Long lines can be broken over multiple lines by wrapping expressions in parentheses. These should be used in preference to using a backslash for line continuation."'}, {'account_id': 1375, 'date': '2013-05-20 22:06:01.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 18: I would prefer that you didn't merge this

(16 inline comments)

Sure is a lot to cover at once.

I think you should mention in your commit message the migration from mock to mockito as it encompasses changes in a lot of unrelated tests. That, or those unrelated changes should be pulled out into a different changeset."}, {'account_id': 5293, 'date': '2013-05-20 22:06:01.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 18.'}, {'account_id': 5293, 'date': '2013-05-20 22:06:01.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 18: (16 inline comments)

Thanks for the good comments Ed et al. I've addressed them in the new patchset.

We're using mockito instead of mock in most of the new guestagent unittests now. Justin (juice) brought this up in one of the reddwarf meetings a couple of weeks ago and there seemed to be no objections to doing this.

I think the idea was that it was okay to use it in the new tests as needed, but we don't have to make a concerted effort to go out of the way to change all the current Mock dependencies to mockito."}, {'account_id': 3, 'date': '2013-05-20 22:06:01.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 19: Doesn't seem to work

commit_message:
Backup and Restore for reddwarf instances.

Implemented backup and restore for reddwarf instances.

Implements spec/consistent-snapshots

Change-Id: Ic1e78545f9e90ab986665a58f524081dcde6894b

commit_message:
Fixes some user and user-access call errors.

delete-user now 404s if the user doesn't already exist
change-password now 404s if any user doesn't exist
change-password now 400s if any user is invalid
tests added for these three cases
error messages for BadRequests in user calls more specific

fixes bug #1181261

Change-Id: I6c8bcd3d5af99e8c6d49029eaeb26b87a49279d8

messages:
[{'account_id': 1561, 'date': '2013-05-17 13:56:15.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

I actually didn't *really* want to do this as mixins, but I think it's ok.  You can actually expose multiple objects via the rpc dispatcher, so that would be cleaner.  The problem is that it's incredibly invasive to the conductor unit tests, so I just settled on this."}, {'account_id': 6873, 'date': '2013-05-17 14:05:20.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: (2 inline comments)

Looks clean, just a couple questions.'}, {'account_id': 2835, 'date': '2013-05-17 14:29:52.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

I'm not crazy about the mixin approach;  I like the multiple dispatcher object idea, ideally in separate modules.  The unit test fixes do sound rather horrible, though. :)"}, {'account_id': 3, 'date': '2013-05-17 14:45:22.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Works for me

revisions:
[{'created': '2013-05-17 13:53:22.000000000', 'message': 'Split up conductor manager.

The conductor manager is evolving to take on more tasks.  Most of the
methods added originally are db proxy methods.  To organize the code a
bit more, split the db proxy methods out into their own class.
Similarly, split out the quota methods into their own mixin class.

Change-Id: I1bee025c94ab3d1524002c4ff70a88f06ec961b7
'}]
commit_message:
Split up conductor manager.

The conductor manager is evolving to take on more tasks.  Most of the
methods added originally are db proxy methods.  To organize the code a
bit more, split the db proxy methods out into their own class.
Similarly, split out the quota methods into their own mixin class.

Change-Id: I1bee025c94ab3d1524002c4ff70a88f06ec961b7

'}, {'account_id': 261, 'date': '2013-05-14 06:03:02.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

It took me a hour to debug the problem!
I have to admin iptables unit tests are quite difficult to understand for me.

However, the code for security groups is actually relying on the capability of adding the same rule multiple times (one for each port), leveraging the fact that upon iptables-restore this rule ends up at the bottom of the chain.

With this change, this rule was not ending up anymore at the bottom of the chain, and so this might have been an error as -j ACCEPT on the sg-chain should be the last rule.

I ensure now the order implemented by IptablesManager is the one the user expects, by removing and re-appending a rule if it's duplicated."}, {'account_id': 3, 'date': '2013-05-14 06:03:02.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2: Works for me

recheck no bug'}, {'account_id': 261, 'date': '2013-05-14 06:03:02.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 3:

Malini,

you have a sensible comment indeed.
I think you also suggested the right solution.
While we cannot use -C as we're executing iptables-save/iptables-restore for enforcing the rules, we can definitely leverage the fact that iptables-save produces rule that are formatted in a canonical way.

Therefore, even if the predicates, actions, and modifiers are shuffled when the rule is inserted, when the apply method is invoked this will turn out in duplicate lines. Hence it should be easy to ensure the input to iptables-restore has no duplicate line."}, {'account_id': 3, 'date': '2013-05-14 06:03:02.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 4: Works for me

'}, {'account_id': 261, 'date': '2013-05-14 06:03:02.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 4:

Hi Brian, I think your comment is spot-on.
This patch as it is solves the problem when you specify two exactly identical rules, but does not address the general issue.

Improving the iptables manager so that it can handle correctly predicates, actions and matching modules, would be definitely a huge plus.

For instance one could do:
IpTablesRule.setChain('your-snat-chain)
IpTablesRule.addPredicate(SourcePredicate('192.168.0.0/24')
IpTablesRule.addPredicate(InputInterface('xxxjff')
IpTablesRule.setAction(SNATAction('10.0.0.1')

Given iptables' complexity, as you say this is far from trivial. If third party libraries cannot be used, then it might be worth doing a blueprint which ideally should target oslo so that nova-network too could leverage the new library.

For the time being, I think that ensuring no duplicate line is fed to iptables-restore might ensure duplicate rules are not stored in iptables."}, {'account_id': 261, 'date': '2013-05-14 06:03:02.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 4.'}, {'account_id': 3, 'date': '2013-05-14 06:03:02.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 5: Works for me

'}, {'account_id': 261, 'date': '2013-05-14 06:03:02.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 8:

Regarding testing the behaviour with 'top=True', it seems this is not possible because the current iptables manager interprets this attribute in an unclear way.

Basically, when top=True it simply removes duplicates from the list of current lines; in this way when the list is reverted and duplicates are removed again, the rules with top=True will end up on the top of the returned list - which is obtained after reversing again the list of rules after removing duplicates.

This approach assume the rule to put on top is already in the list of applied rules, so that the 'duplicate removal' trick works. Indeed, creating two new rules on an empty table, with the 2nd having top=True, does not put the 2nd rule on top when iptables-restore is invoked. This might or might not be a bug, and it's being investigated separately.

This patch however ensures that if a rule is added twice, with top=False first and top=True then, the rule is stored only once - this is achieved by removing 'top' from the __eq__ method for the IpTablesRule class."}, {'account_id': 261, 'date': '2013-05-14 06:03:02.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 8.'}, {'account_id': 261, 'date': '2013-05-14 06:03:02.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 8: (1 inline comment)

Matt, thanks for your comment.

I have been actually thinking of abandoning this patch for more than a week (and indeed I've removed the dependency on this of another patch I had). this is pretty much for the same reason you've pointed out.

Basically we all know iptables allows you to duplicate rules (btw, it's been *just* 15 years? It feels like 150 to me!). The iptables manager should just be a proxy to iptables, probably not a library that allows you to use iptables the way quantum wants to.

So the bug is probably not really in iptables manager, but in the module that uses it (in this case the l3_agent, since it adds the same rule twice)."}, {'account_id': 642, 'date': '2013-05-14 06:03:02.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 8: Looks good to me, but someone else must approve

(1 inline comment)

Thought inline, otherwise I'm fine with it"}, {'account_id': 748, 'date': '2013-05-14 06:03:02.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 8: (1 inline comment)

Question inline.'}, {'account_id': 1131, 'date': '2013-05-14 06:03:02.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 4:

More of a comment than a question since I also have a patch in the queue for the iptables_manager code.

This code has always been fragile in the sense that you must use the iptables-save/restore syntax when specifying rules, that was true in the Nova code as well (-I eth0 vs --interface eth0).

This comment in linux_net.py (nova) hints at the problem:

 Note: The rule must be exactly identical to the one that
 was added. You cannot switch arguments around like you
 can with the iptables CLI tool.

And to Malini's comment about having iptables check for the existence of a rule, I'm not sure that will work as iptables is more than happy to insert the same rule twice, even if specified exactly the same:

--> sudo iptables -A OUTPUT --source 10.1.2.3 --proto tcp
--> sudo iptables -A OUTPUT --source 10.1.2.3 --proto tcp
--> sudo iptables -L OUTPUT -n
Chain OUTPUT (policy ACCEPT)
target     prot opt source               destination         
           tcp  --  10.1.2.3           0.0.0.0/0           
           tcp  --  10.1.2.3           0.0.0.0/0

Having something to put rules into a canonical format, say, in add_rule(), such that it's in the syntax iptables-save would use might be a good idea, but I'm afraid it would get complex very fast as iptables is complex itself.

Maybe eventually the iptables python library will be stable enough to help out here, but for now I think we're stuck with what we have.

Maybe I should have just sent this to the mailing list..."}, {'account_id': 1131, 'date': '2013-05-14 06:03:02.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 7: (1 inline comment)

'}, {'account_id': 2031, 'date': '2013-05-14 06:03:02.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

recheck no bug'}, {'account_id': 2031, 'date': '2013-05-14 06:03:02.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Looks good to me (core reviewer)

Nice!'}, {'account_id': 2031, 'date': '2013-05-14 06:03:02.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1: I would prefer that you didn't merge this

It looks like we should update test cases in security groups"}, {'account_id': 4992, 'date': '2013-05-14 06:03:02.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1: I would prefer that you didn't merge this

(1 inline comment)

"}, {'account_id': 4992, 'date': '2013-05-14 06:03:02.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3: I would prefer that you didn't merge this

Salvatore, my point is if we are seeking to prevent the addition of duplicate rules and preserve order (your newest patch set) .. not quite accomplishing it.

The IptablesRule class does a string comparison on the rule.
The rule in reality is equivalent even if the arguments are shuffled around a bit ..

For example: 
sudo iptables --append INPUT --source 198.3.4.5 -j ACCEPT --proto tcp
sudo iptables --append INPUT --source 198.3.4.5  --proto tcp -j ACCEPT

are really the same .. 

$ sudo iptables -L 
Chain INPUT (policy ACCEPT)
target     prot opt source               destination         
nova-api-INPUT  all  --  anywhere             anywhere            
ACCEPT     udp  --  anywhere             anywhere             udp dpt:domain
ACCEPT     tcp  --  anywhere             anywhere             tcp dpt:domain
ACCEPT     udp  --  anywhere             anywhere             udp dpt:bootps
ACCEPT     tcp  --  anywhere             anywhere             tcp dpt:bootps
ACCEPT     tcp  --  198.3.4.5           anywhere            
ACCEPT     tcp  --  198.3.4.5            anywhere  

THis is why I mentioned a canonical form for the rule .. it is a pain .. requires parsing .. perhaps re-ordering with 
-j at the end, --source in the beginning, dealing with the full form versus the short (-s versus --source) etc.

Would it make sense to delegate the task of checking for rule existance to iptables itself? It has a command "--check or -C chain"  Check for the existence of a rule

If you think this is a non-issue, please say so, and I revoke my objection.

Regards
Malini'}, {'account_id': 4992, 'date': '2013-05-14 06:03:02.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 4: I would prefer that you didn't merge this

Automatically re-added by Gerrit trivial rebase detection script."}, {'account_id': 4992, 'date': '2013-05-14 06:03:02.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 5: I would prefer that you didn't merge this

commit_message:
Ensure no duplicate rule in IPTablesManager

Bug 1159898

This patch simply adds a check when adding a new rule into a table.
The rules attribute was not transformed into a set as this
might have altered the order in which rules are written to chains.

Also, this patch assumes two rules are equal regardless of the value
of the 'top' attribute. This is for avoiding duplicates when top=True

Change-Id: I99004aacdf99c0bc07adf7880e15a013fb186dec

commit_message:
Template content tests

Changed some 'pending' template tests to check for attributes, defaults,
and platform specific changes.
Also, noticed that the spec memcached servers list was a string,
and the template uses .each, so I changed it to an array.
And changed the Berksfile to use stackforge

Also, updated spec tests to use new cookbook name 'openstack-dashboard'
and found 1 lingering 'horizon' attribute in dash-site template

Change-Id: I80d57c6f37583aec374f837c9b832576ac0e8b1b

The nova-network did not honor nic ordering, so nics were attached in db
natural order. This patch sorts the networks honor requested nic
ordering when Nova calls the nova-network API.

Fixes bug: #1170725

Change-Id: I7dd04ac7bdda95c626cbb0fe35be0aadacb4bd2a

commit_message:
Make nova-network support requested nic ordering

The nova-network did not honor nic ordering, so nics were attached in db
natural order. This patch sorts the networks honor requested nic
ordering when Nova calls the nova-network API.

Fixes bug: #1170725

Change-Id: I7dd04ac7bdda95c626cbb0fe35be0aadacb4bd2a
Signed-off-by: zhiyanl-cn <zhiyanl@cn.ibm.com>
(cherry picked from commit 90d3371be6c7ec2fc85c92f4744adf4f83003522)

[{'created': '2013-05-02 07:17:08.000000000', 'message': 'Fixes: bug #1175356

Future implementations of keystone API v3 will support server-side
filtering using key/value attributes. See:
https://github.com/openstack/identity-api/blob/master/openstack-identity-api/src/markdown/identity-api-v3.md#list-entities-filtered-by-attribute

To support this functionality **kwargs need to be passed from the
v3 classes to keystoneclient.base.CrudManager.list. See:
https://github.com/openstack/python-keystoneclient/blob/master/keystoneclient/base.py#L232

This is not fully implemented server-side for all attributes so it's difficult to
document exactly which attributes will work. An example of a working attribute is:
keystone.users.list(name="someone")

commit_message:
Refactor v3 API to support filtering

Fixes: bug #1175356

Future implementations of keystone API v3 will support server-side
filtering using key/value attributes. See additional details:
https://github.com/openstack/identity-api/blob/master/openstack-identity-api/src/markdown/identity-api-v3.md#list-entities-filtered-by-attribute

To support this functionality **kwargs need to be passed from the
v3 API classes to keystoneclient.base.CrudManager.list.

This is not fully implemented server-side for all attributes so it's difficult to
document exactly which attributes will work. An example of a working attribute is:
keystone.users.list(name="someone")

Change-Id: I148093fbe37700f890ed44148aa3f63f34ee5ff5

revisions:
[{'created': '2013-05-20 19:02:13.000000000', 'message': 'Add a new PrettyTable parsing function

The current state of (at least some) OpenStack CLI tools do not provide a
mechanism for outputting data in formats other than PrettyTable output.
Therefore this function is intended to parse PrettyTable output into a
usable array of hashes. Similarly, it will flatten Property/Value tables
into a single element array.

This change adds a parser as well as the associated rspec tests for that
parser. The initial use case for this function is to allow the Identity
LWRP to replace HTTP/S calls with Identity CLI calls. As much of what
happens with the CLI involves chaining UUIDs, this function is critical
to make that happen.

All tests pass.

Change-Id: Icac7fcd1670f3240d59b07fce25cf8283ba2e0d8
'}, {'created': '2013-05-20 19:19:06.000000000', 'message': 'Add a new PrettyTable parsing function

The current state of (at least some) OpenStack CLI tools do not provide a
mechanism for outputting data in formats other than PrettyTable output.
Therefore this function is intended to parse PrettyTable output into a
usable array of hashes. Similarly, it will flatten Property/Value tables
into a single element array.

This change adds a parser as well as the associated rspec tests for that
parser. The initial use case for this function is to allow the Identity
LWRP to replace HTTP/S calls with Identity CLI calls. As much of what
happens with the CLI involves chaining UUIDs, this function is critical
to make that happen.

commit_message:
Add a new PrettyTable parsing function

The current state of (at least some) OpenStack CLI tools do not provide a
mechanism for outputting data in formats other than PrettyTable output.
Therefore this function is intended to parse PrettyTable output into a
usable array of hashes. Similarly, it will flatten Property/Value tables
into a single element array.

This change adds a parser as well as the associated rspec tests for that
parser. The initial use case for this function is to allow the Identity
LWRP to replace HTTP/S calls with Identity CLI calls. As much of what
happens with the CLI involves chaining UUIDs, this function is critical
to make that happen.

Note well: bumping the version of this cookbook to 0.2.1

All tests pass.

Change-Id: Icac7fcd1670f3240d59b07fce25cf8283ba2e0d8

Hi,
The Quantum API does not support hostname as part of the API (https://github.com/openstack/quantum/blob/master/quantum/api/v2/attributes.py#L437)
This is currently supported by a port binding extension:
https://github.com/openstack/quantum/blob/master/quantum/extensions/portbindings.py#L26. 
So you will need to do 
port_req_body['port']['binding:host_id']
Please note that this is not supported by all plugins.
Thanks
Gary"}, {'account_id': 447, 'date': '2013-02-07 18:52:53.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 5:

To clarify my above comment - this nova patch should go in as soon as it is ready. It does not depend on any corresponding change in quantum - the binding:host_id attribute has been defined since the portbindings extension was first implemented in quantum. Plugins that do not need the binding:host_id attribute will safely ignore it. This patch should not wait for either the quantum patch referenced in the commit message or the ml2 plugin implementation, both of which require it, to be merged.'}, {'account_id': 447, 'date': '2013-02-12 16:42:44.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 7: I would prefer that you didn't merge this

revisions:
[{'created': '2013-02-04 19:44:24.000000000', 'message': 'This is a one line change in nova/network/quantumv2/api.py to pass the hostname
on which the instance was started to Quantum. The associated quantum OVSPlugin
changes pass this hostname to hardware device vendors management stations to
allow them to segment the network in a more precise manner (for example
automatically trunk the vlan on the physical switch port connected to the
compute host on which the VM instance was started).

See https://review.openstack.org/#/c/20754/ for the associated Quantum/OVSPlugin
changes.

Change-Id: I510be53aeda0608a49378ca8eb4766de0af590f3
Implements: blueprint ovsplugin-hardware-devices
'}, {'created': '2013-02-04 19:54:26.000000000', 'message': 'allocate_for_instance(): Pass host to quantum.create_port()

This is a one line change in nova/network/quantumv2/api.py to pass the hostname
on which the instance was started to Quantum. The associated quantum OVSPlugin
changes pass this hostname to hardware device vendors management stations to
allow them to segment the network in a more precise manner (for example
automatically trunk the vlan on the physical switch port connected to the
compute host on which the VM instance was started).

See https://review.openstack.org/#/c/20754/ for the associated Quantum/OVSPlugin
changes.

Change-Id: I510be53aeda0608a49378ca8eb4766de0af590f3
Implements: blueprint ovsplugin-hardware-devices
'}, {'created': '2013-02-05 22:18:40.000000000', 'message': 'allocate_for_instance(): Pass host to quantum.create_port()

This is a one line change in nova/network/quantumv2/api.py to pass the hostname
on which the instance was started to Quantum. The associated quantum OVSPlugin
changes pass this hostname to hardware device vendors management stations to
allow them to segment the network in a more precise manner (for example
automatically trunk the vlan on the physical switch port connected to the
compute host on which the VM instance was started).

See https://review.openstack.org/#/c/20754/ for the associated Quantum/OVSPlugin
changes.

Change-Id: I510be53aeda0608a49378ca8eb4766de0af590f3
Implements: blueprint ovsplugin-hardware-devices
'}, {'created': '2013-02-06 20:13:59.000000000', 'message': "Adds support to the OVSPlugin to interface with multi-vendor hardware
devices/management stations.

This diff describes a generic python API within the OVS quantum plugin
which will enable support for different hardware backends for L2 network
segregation (VLANs, tunneling, etc.)

This may be useful for existing data centers with hardware switches which needs
to be used along with Openstack infrastructure. In this case a hardware vendor
may introduce the OVS plugin extension which will allow using vendor's hardware
within Openstack along with Open vSwitch virtual switches to provide L2 network
segregation.

This will allow automatic L2 network provisioning on the hardware devices
alongside with the open vswitch provisioning in the compute node hypervisors.

This diff includes the source code for an Arista Driver which supports
provisioning of Arista TOR (top-of-the-rack) switches alongside with open
vswitches.

There is a related one line change needed in nova/network/quantumv2/api.py,
allocate_for_instance() to pass the hostname on which the instance was started to
Quantum create_port().

commit_message:
Pass instance host-id to Quantum using port bindings extension.

This is a nova change to pass the hostname on which the instance was started to
Quantum. The assoociated quantum OVSplugin changes pass this hostname to
hardware device vendors management stations to allow them to segment the network
in a more precise manner (for example automatically trunk the vlan on the
physical switch port connected to the compute host on which the VM instance was
started).

Implements: blueprint vm-host-quantum

Change-Id: I510be53aeda0608a49378ca8eb4766de0af590f3
Signed-off-by: Gary Kotton <gkotton@redhat.com>
Signed-off-by: Aaron Rosen <arosen@nicira.com>

this should be done in a new middleware, similar to xml_body'}, {'account_id': 4, 'date': '2013-03-15 00:04:19.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2:

(also blocking because this needs to wait for havana)'}, {'account_id': 2218, 'date': '2013-03-15 00:45:04.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2:

Thanks for the reviews guys, but don;t get too worked up about the details.  I just posted this to show you what I was thinking. 

It will need a significant amount of work before it is ready.'}, {'account_id': 2218, 'date': '2013-03-15 00:47:33.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2: (2 inline comments)

As far as the "new middleware"  agreed, except that the XML middleware is going to need some rework as well.  We'll need something to keep track of the order of transforms, and only perform the XML transform if the HTML one is not performed.  I am thinking that we'll have a "content type select" middleware that will then select  the xml or html middleware.'}, {'account_id': 4, 'date': '2013-03-22 15:21:32.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2:

@ayoung: the xml_body middleware only performs a json->xml transformation if xml is requested, and updates headers accordingly.

if a user requests or submits text/html, then an html middleware should do the appropriate transformation to/from json. xml and html middlewares therefore wouldn't affect each other and shouldn't be dependent on a third middleware"}, {'account_id': 2218, 'date': '2013-03-22 15:36:58.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2:

Dolph, regarding  xml_body middleware

While that is the approach we want to take, multiple accepts headers in practice come in from the browser,  and we need to honor the order of precedednce between them.  So when both XML and HTML can be accepted, we should return HTML format, and only return XML if it is the only Accepted format.'}, {'account_id': 9, 'date': '2013-03-30 06:03:04.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2:

code review expired after 1 week of no activity after a negative review, it can be restored using the `Restore Change` button under the Patch Set on the web interface'}, {'account_id': 9, 'date': '2013-03-30 06:03:04.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2: Abandoned

commit_message:
html

A simple HTML rendering that should make it possible for keystone
to work with a web browser.  For now, it makes links clickable,
and adds a link to a login page, that then requests a token.

Change-Id: Iebc03fabbcdbecb205eb28f43a4c82ad0f3054e9

commit_message:
Convert to oslo strutils.bool_from_string.

The only functional difference here is that the value '2' is now
treated as False instead of True. I suspect that's ok.

Change-Id: I30e75470cb3c312d7f92d389995eb6d845dd2fb0

revisions:
[{'created': '2013-05-20 19:28:25.000000000', 'message': 'The utils module in oslo is no more.

The utils module in oslo has been removed (with most of its
functionality moving across to strutils). Luckily it was imported
in heat but never actually used, so removing it is relatively easy.

Change-Id: Ic3cb8bb9bbae282f5a753c6abe58b1d47ad640db
'}]
commit_message:
The utils module in oslo is no more.

The utils module in oslo has been removed (with most of its
functionality moving across to strutils). Luckily it was imported
in heat but never actually used, so removing it is relatively easy.

Change-Id: Ic3cb8bb9bbae282f5a753c6abe58b1d47ad640db

subject: Fix for nova-compute service not beeing started.
messages:
[{'account_id': 3, 'date': '2013-05-17 14:33:54.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Works for me

Build succeeded.

- http://logs.openstack.org/29557/1/check/gate-cookbook-openstack-compute-chef-lint/35 : SUCCESS in 3m 54s
- http://logs.openstack.org/29557/1/check/gate-cookbook-openstack-compute-chef-unit/35 : SUCCESS in 3m 54s
'}, {'account_id': 7, 'date': '2013-05-17 16:55:51.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: I would prefer that you didn't merge this

There is a unit test in spec/compute_spec.rb that validates that nova-compute is started on boot:


    it "starts nova compute on boot" do
      expect(@chef_run).to set_service_to_start_on_boot "nova-compute"
    end

Please add a unit test to ensure that the service is actually started:

    it "starts nova compute" do
      expect(@chef_run).to start_service "nova-compute"
    end

More information on ChefSpec matchers can be found here: https://github.com/acrmp/chefspec

Thanks!
-jay'}, {'account_id': 216, 'date': '2013-05-17 17:00:07.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

Also be sure to update spec/compute-redhat_spec.rb as well, since redhat uses a different service naming.'}, {'account_id': 2340, 'date': '2013-05-20 10:19:20.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 2.'}, {'account_id': 3, 'date': '2013-05-20 10:24:19.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2: Works for me

commit_message:
always set the signing_dir

keystoneclient tries to create this directory if it does not exist and
the default is ~/keystone-signing

Change-Id: I71b61d0016504b8d67dd3295b805ceb8b92ef726

commit_message:
Do not produce a broken /e/n/i file.

Ifupdown, the package that interprets /etc/network/interfaces when
'service networking restart' is issued, will raise an error if the
same interface is defined twice. So we need to be sure we're not
accidentally overwriting any existing interfaces.

Change-Id: Ibb639999e64292141dcb8eb02820470a246be27c

revisions:
[{'created': '2013-05-20 18:59:30.000000000', 'message': "Install 'quantum' pgk before Quantum_api_config.

Add a resource chain to ensure the 'quantum' package is installed
before the quantum api is configured. This ensures
/etc/quantum/api-paste.ini is in place and fixes issues using this
module on distros where there is no explicit quantum server package
(RHEL).

Fixes LP Bug #1181727.

Change-Id: I11359d5ec9be17186cf1cdb0ccf63b35ca10b06d
"}]
commit_message:
Install 'quantum' pgk before Quantum_api_config.

Add a resource chain to ensure the 'quantum' package is installed
before the quantum api is configured. This ensures
/etc/quantum/api-paste.ini is in place and fixes issues using this
module on distros where there is no explicit quantum server package
(RHEL).

Fixes LP Bug #1181727.

Change-Id: I11359d5ec9be17186cf1cdb0ccf63b35ca10b06d

commit_message:
Add virtual_power_type support to boot-stack element.

Allows users who do not use native Ubuntu environments to
more easily set a virtual_power_type other then virsh.

Change-Id: I7b6152df6eef5359098f10cac3eb6c358c0d66d2
Authored-by: Chris Krelle <nobodycam@gmail.com>

commit_message:
Check network vlan ranges for correctness.

Check that the range beginning and end tags are valid values 1-4094.
Supply two global constants for min/max vlan tags and update all
local usage of these values to use the global constants.

Fixes: Bug #1169266
Change-Id: I054a8bebd16d95ea40414e3cecb6d24a970c730f

[{'created': '2013-05-20 18:43:22.000000000', 'message': 'Move the ensure_nbd function call.

Move the ensure_nbd function call from the disk-image-create to the
disk-image-get-kernel. The image creation process does not use qemu-nbd
anymore.

Change-Id: I8ff2ad54f322a9e33d52408fa4e253a7b45900c7
'}]
commit_message:
Move the ensure_nbd function call.

Move the ensure_nbd function call from the disk-image-create to the
disk-image-get-kernel. The image creation process does not use qemu-nbd
anymore.

Change-Id: I8ff2ad54f322a9e33d52408fa4e253a7b45900c7

commit_message:
Refactor the first boot routine.

Setting up a routine to run at first time the system boot may vary from
distribution to distribution. This patch will remove the logic from the
diskimage-builder code and put it into the elements.

The base element will now deploy a dib-first-boot script and each OS
element will ensure that this script runs at rc.local time. By doing
that we will put the OS specific stuff in the OS elements and remove
the embedded code out of the img-function file.

Change-Id: I24c5d1b1185de5693f145347fe912245f1ba7dfe

commit_message:
Allow deploy ramdisk to be built with custom elements.

In the boot-stack element, we can specify the list of those
elements that we want to include inside our deploy ramdisk by
listing them in the config.json file.

Change-Id: Ice83c2e14cff8a0a91490cb511b548105a422e6a
Fixes: bug #1178094

Where do we show that we're using or requiring SSL in the tests?"}, {'account_id': 1375, 'date': '2013-05-20 18:27:24.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 5: Looks good to me, but someone else must approve

Sorry, I was worried the changes were forcing SSL.
Getting these Oslo updates in is hard work, thanks for making it work.'}, {'account_id': 4693, 'date': '2013-05-20 18:27:24.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 5: No score

Ed, we're not using or forcing ssl at this point. We wanted to add that ability, and apparently it's already implemented in Oslo. The thing is, we're "stuck" on a 6 months old version of Oslo. Since it'll be pretty painful to upgrade the entire Oslo package to tip all at once, we decided to update what we need when we need it. There is a tool for that, developed by the Oslo guys, where you feed it with the module you need, and it'll spit out all the dependencies. So basically, the only changes you see in our (reddwarf) code base, are those that suffered regression bugs due to some new code introduced in the latest version of Oslo, mostly in those dependent modules, not even directly the one we need - wsgi. If it makes you feel more comfortable, you can look at it as if it's merely a partial update of the bigger Oslo package, plus the required adjustments to our code.
Please take another look and see if you can +1 it.
thanks!'}, {'account_id': 4693, 'date': '2013-05-20 18:27:24.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 5: Looks good to me, but someone else must approve

Automatically re-added by Gerrit trivial rebase detection script.'}, {'account_id': 6162, 'date': '2013-05-20 18:27:24.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 5: Looks good to me, but someone else must approve

Automatically re-added by Gerrit trivial rebase detection script.'}, {'account_id': 6162, 'date': '2013-05-20 18:27:24.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 5.'}, {'account_id': 3, 'date': '2013-05-20 18:27:24.000000000', 'content': 'Change has been successfully merged into the git repository.'}, {'account_id': 3, 'date': '2013-05-20 18:27:24.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 5: Verified

Build succeeded.

- http://logs.openstack.org/28721/5/gate/gate-reddwarf-python27/648 : SUCCESS in 2m 58s
'}]

commit_message:
Refresh Oslo code - add support for ssl

We want to add ssl support for the reddwarf api server.
For this, updating the openstack/common/wsgi module, and
all it's dependencies as a result of using:
$> python update.py --base reddwarf --dest-dir ../reddwarf --modules wsgi
(details:https://wiki.openstack.org/wiki/Oslo)

I'm commenting out the "six" update, since it seems to break
our fake mode testing with regard to reddwarf-cli.

I'll open a separate bug for it.

Change-Id: I763d06658488bd1ca1eac5a2ba1ffde5629f842f
Fixes: Bug #1178421

One small whitespace change (see inline commnet). Otherwise this looks good to me."}, {'account_id': 1, 'date': '2013-05-10 21:17:37.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

  #TODO sbaker install an image from jenkins.tripleo.org:8080'}, {'account_id': 4571, 'date': '2013-05-15 01:19:52.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 2.'}, {'account_id': 7556, 'date': '2013-05-15 01:19:54.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2:

Build failed.

- http://logs.openstack.org/28650/2/check/gate-tempest-devstack-vm-full/None : LOST
- http://logs.openstack.org/28650/2/check/gate-tempest-devstack-vm-postgres-full/None : LOST (non-voting)
- http://logs.openstack.org/28650/2/check/gate-tempest-devstack-vm-quantum/None : LOST
- http://logs.openstack.org/28650/2/check/gate-grenade-devstack-vm/None : LOST (non-voting)
'}, {'account_id': 4571, 'date': '2013-05-15 01:31:14.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2:

Some heat tests will spawn full ubuntu or fedora servers for integration and functional testing. The images that are spawned need to already have our in-instance tools (heat-cfntools) installed on them. So we need custom built images available to run our tests.

jenkins.tripleo.org has some diskimage-builder jobs which build these custom images, specifically:
http://jenkins.tripleo.org:8080/job/autobuilt-images/elements=ubuntu%20vm%20heat-cfntools/
http://jenkins.tripleo.org:8080/job/autobuilt-images/elements=fedora%20vm%20heat-cfntools/

I'm not sure of the best way to get these images into devstack-gate, but options might be:
1. download latest built images for every run (could be slow, and a broken image could cause heat test failures)
2. download known good images for every run (could be slow but maybe not, its all in hpcloud)
3. bake known good images into the zuul images

I've added monty into this review to get an opinion.

Since the IMAGE_URLS part is commented out I'm hoping this change can get in before an images strategy is decided on - there will be heat tests which do not spawn servers, and the ones that do will be disabled until images are available."}, {'account_id': 3, 'date': '2013-05-15 02:05:50.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2: Works for me

Build succeeded.

- http://logs.openstack.org/28650/2/check/gate-tempest-devstack-vm-full/15997 : SUCCESS in 45m 35s
- http://logs.openstack.org/28650/2/check/gate-tempest-devstack-vm-postgres-full/15713 : FAILURE in 45m 45s (non-voting)
- http://logs.openstack.org/28650/2/check/gate-tempest-devstack-vm-quantum/22465 : SUCCESS in 25m 35s
- http://logs.openstack.org/28650/2/check/gate-grenade-devstack-vm/3632 : FAILURE in 10m 20s (non-voting)
'}, {'account_id': 1, 'date': '2013-05-15 17:14:04.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2: I would prefer that you didn't merge this

Okay, makes sense.  My understanding after speaking with Monty is that the tripleo folks will get DiB running in the OpenStack CI infrastructure, optionally incorporating it into the devstack-gate so that changes to it which would break heat tests can't land.  Then it can publish images to static.openstack.org, which is a reliable, infra-team managed source from which we can fetch images.

I believe we'll want all that to happen before we start gating on tests involving those images, as we'd rather not be responsible for infrastructure we can't fix.

So all that is to say this change looks good, except one small thing:

Would you mind adding a default value setting for the new env variable into devstack-vm-gate-wrap.sh?  That's more or less the de-facto documentation for those parameters, plus we also might want to do some branch-specific settings with it later as well."}, {'account_id': 4571, 'date': '2013-05-16 05:02:39.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 3.'}, {'account_id': 3, 'date': '2013-05-16 05:46:38.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3: Works for me

commit_message:
DEVSTACK_GATE_HEAT conditional for enabling heat

Disabled by default, will need to be enabled for heat tempest tests

Change-Id: Id1e18c8c26b7791fd8d82fc5adaf2f9e7713abd4

subject: 'm1.tiny' now has root_gb=1

messages:
[{'account_id': 2243, 'date': '2013-05-01 23:39:25.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

Personally I like having the tiny flavor of 0, and with some non-xen hypervisors this seems to work fine (at least I use it all the time).

Anyway, I can create my own flavors with 0 root-disk size easily enough (of course, ummm.... well anyway).  

Just wondering if there's an alternative to 10 Gig and what others are thinking about this."}, {'account_id': 475, 'date': '2013-05-01 23:50:59.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

John: Yeah, there are definitely good use-cases for a root_gb=0.

Still having `tiny` not work out-of-the-box for Xen users is kind of a pain.

root_gb=0 could always be added as an additional flavor in the migration, perhaps coming after the 'standard' flavors to highlight the fact that it should be chosen w/ care."}, {'account_id': 2243, 'date': '2013-05-02 00:01:13.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Looks good to me, but someone else must approve

Makes sense, thanks Rick, I see your point about compatibility issues.'}, {'account_id': 3, 'date': '2013-05-02 00:08:03.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1: Doesn't seem to work

Build failed.  For information on how to proceed, see https://wiki.openstack.org/wiki/GerritJenkinsGithub#Test_Failures

"}, {'account_id': 1561, 'date': '2013-05-02 01:59:07.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1: I would prefer that you didn't merge this

So the difference in behavior between different virt drivers is part of the issue here.  Is it valid or not?  Why isn't it consistently handled across drivers?"}, {'account_id': 475, 'date': '2013-05-02 02:25:47.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

Russell: Yeah I'd agree the consistency between virt-drivers w.r.t root_gb is an issue as well.

I *think* Xen is doing the right thing here in enforcing a size check of the image against the declared root-volume size, so if possible, I'd like to see similar checks added to the other virt-drivers.

Know of any reasons why this would be a bad-idea?

Maybe the order of operations should be:

1. Fix the instance_type flavors for the two reasons listed above

2. Create a BP to add size checks for the other virt-drivers, e.g. a `check_image_size' function to driver.py that each implementation can override, and then a refactoring of xenapi, to use this new function.

Thoughts?"}, {'account_id': 782, 'date': '2013-05-02 17:13:28.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

The 0GB used to mean, don't resize and go with the default disk size of the image from glance. If you add volumes for all your extra storage, or ephemeral disks, I could see 0GB being useful.

But it does cause the resize and auto_config code to try and make the disk into a negative size, so this 0GB case is really not handled well in the XenAPI driver."}, {'account_id': 782, 'date': '2013-05-02 17:16:27.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

Sorry, didn't read the conversation properly. I guess the question is, do we want 0GB in the default list, given most useful cases in Xen break quite badly.

I think the correct answer is to fix the Xen code to work with 0GB. But thats quite a lot of work. I am thinking about the case where you want to use separate ephemeral disks + volumes for storage, and not resize the root disk."}, {'account_id': 191, 'date': '2013-05-02 17:19:05.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Looks good to me, but someone else must approve

coming from xen, i feel the need to + this patch. I think the greater issue here is why we include flavors at all if everyone is going to have specific requirements..'}, {'account_id': 191, 'date': '2013-05-02 17:20:08.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

and by include I mean, why should we populate this table.'}, {'account_id': 1030, 'date': '2013-05-04 19:28:45.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

I remember there being a specific reason why root_gb was changed to 0 before.  Vish might remember.  I also think Johannes was involved... as it came about as related to the ephemeral_gb addition.'}, {'account_id': 67, 'date': '2013-05-07 00:07:20.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

0 means don't resize the base disk at all. It was very valuable for testing, but it leads to all sorts of problems in practice. I would suggest we actually change the size for m1.tiny to 1 and possibly disallow the option to create 0 root size flavors via a config option."}, {'account_id': 67, 'date': '2013-05-07 00:07:31.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1: I would prefer that you didn't merge this

"}, {'account_id': 782, 'date': '2013-05-09 09:28:39.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: I would prefer that you didn't merge this

I like having a small number of flavours to help ease testing.

But maybe go for 5GB, so it keeps in the same ratio as the memory?

I don't like changing the meaning of tiny, but it seems better than the alternatives.

Should we mark the zero GB root disk as "for testing only" in the docs? Resize goes crazy when you resize down to tiny, and there are all sorts of other issues in the XenAPI driver, like auto_disk_config not working.'}, {'account_id': 475, 'date': '2013-05-09 21:00:04.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

I like John's suggestion of keeping the ratio of memory/disk consistent, i.e. go with 5GB. Any reason we shouldn't go that route?

The idea of deprecating 0GB root with a config-flag seems like a good one for now."}, {'account_id': 1561, 'date': '2013-05-10 15:58:03.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

+1 for leaving this behavior in, but not having it in the default flavors'}, {'account_id': 1525, 'date': '2013-05-10 16:27:25.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Looks good to me, but someone else must approve

I also agree that keeping 0 as "leave the disk alone" is a nice feature and it just shouldn't included with the default flavors.'}, {'account_id': 67, 'date': '2013-05-11 18:22:12.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

having to deal with resizes to 5g for tiny is a pain in for small testing deploys. If you are testing on a vm, disk space is often at a premium.'}, {'account_id': 1711, 'date': '2013-05-12 00:51:57.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: I would prefer that you didn't merge this

If we keep the "size=0 meaning no resize" feature (which I totally think we should for compatibility and kinda useful), then it seems the XenAPI driver should be patched to support it. After that's done, what's the incentive to change the default tiny flavor from 0 to something else?'}, {'account_id': 67, 'date': '2013-05-12 02:26:19.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

Yun: the main issue is that it messes up things like accounting and scheduling. It allows you to create an image with size 400GB and then launch it with tiny. Good for testing but not good for production use. Having a default flavor that is bad for production is a bit nasty.'}, {'account_id': 475, 'date': '2013-05-14 20:39:46.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 2.'}, {'account_id': 1711, 'date': '2013-05-14 21:19:53.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2:

Vish: good point. I hadn't thought about that."}, {'account_id': 1711, 'date': '2013-05-14 21:20:44.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2:

I'm wondering which is better for compatibility/upgrade: change tiny to 1GB or delete tiny as default flavor and add a different flavor, e.g. micro with default 1GB? Thanks."}, {'account_id': 3, 'date': '2013-05-14 21:31:54.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2: Doesn't seem to work

Build failed.  For information on how to proceed, see https://wiki.openstack.org/wiki/GerritJenkinsGithub#Test_Failures

revisions:
[{'created': '2013-05-01 23:22:20.000000000', 'message': "Fix incorrect root_gb for default 'tiny' instance

The current value of 0 for root_gb has two problems:

1) It doesn't follow the power-of-two pattern of the rest of the
instance_types

2) More importantly, instances cannot be created with it because the
_check_vdi_size function will see that any image has a size greater than the
allowed size of root_gb which is 0.

Fixes bug 1175383

Change-Id: Ifa5827c7f87dae95214bc4a585adce5735a05d83
"}, {'created': '2013-05-14 20:39:46.000000000', 'message': "'m1.tiny' now has root_gb=1

`root_gb=0` indicates that a disk-resize shouldn't occur which is not
something that a default flavor should have enabled. This is
especially true of one named 'tiny' since the unresized image could
potentially be very large, leading to the unexpected result of a
'tiny' instance consuming a massive amount of disk.

The no-resize behavior is still supported, so if it's being relied on
for testing, additional, non-default flavors can still be created that
enable it.

Fixes bug 1175383

Change-Id: Ifa5827c7f87dae95214bc4a585adce5735a05d83

commit_message:
'm1.tiny' now has root_gb=1

`root_gb=0` indicates that a disk-resize shouldn't occur which is not
something that a default flavor should have enabled. This is
especially true of one named 'tiny' since the unresized image could
potentially be very large, leading to the unexpected result of a
'tiny' instance consuming a massive amount of disk.

The no-resize behavior is still supported, so if it's being relied on
for testing, additional, non-default flavors can still be created that
enable it.

DocImpact
Fixes bug 1175383

Change-Id: Ifa5827c7f87dae95214bc4a585adce5735a05d83

revisions:
[{'created': '2013-05-18 20:20:14.000000000', 'message': "Fix require_context() decorators.

require_context() and require_admin_context() decorators
don't copy attributes of a decorated function (func_name,
__doc__, __module__) to a wrapper function. This makes
introspection and debugging harder and should be fixed.

Fixes bug 1181606.

Change-Id: I0926df92a40d3fc09b94a0c4b1ded63039abf18b
"}]
commit_message:
Fix require_context() decorators.

require_context() and require_admin_context() decorators
don't copy attributes of a decorated function (func_name,
__doc__, __module__) to a wrapper function. This makes
introspection and debugging harder and should be fixed.

Fixes bug 1181606.

Change-Id: I0926df92a40d3fc09b94a0c4b1ded63039abf18b

commit_message:
Update the README file development section.

Add more prerequisites to set up a local environment for development on
Ubuntu and the Fedora equivalents.

* libxml2 and libxslt are needed to build lxml.
* mysql libs are needed to build MySQL-python.

Change-Id: I4627b34ba72d677975c8c067e981fca732d78215

commit_message:
Adding the start of notifications

* Adds a nofity mixin for the taskmanager models
* Adding a usage verifier test
* Adding tests for usage notifications
* Adding extra parameters to match Nova notifications

Implements: blueprint reddwarf-notifications
Change-Id: I61193c238fac6e14d360f3e17baeb5302aa7d720

commit_message:
Re-introduced support for rpc delete_queue

Fixed leaking queues in rabbitmq since our guestagents' queues no longer
go away when the db instances are deleted.

Fixes bug: 1180693

Change-Id: I5ed18929a611307656cfa6da2c9aaed34624e4a1

commit_message:
Make ManagerWithFind abstract and fix its descendants

ManagerWithFind requires list() method in its descendants.
Make it abstract and fix its improper descendants that do
not implement list() (SecurityGroupRuleManager and many others).

Fixes: bug #1180393
Change-Id: Ic8b466a57554018092c31c6d6b3ea62f181d7000

[{'created': '2012-09-09 05:40:00.000000000', 'message': "Update password for keystoneclient, securely.

Bug: 938315

If new password is not specified in command line, read from the
prompt.

* keystoneclient/v2_0/shell.py
  do_user_password_update(): Argument --pass is optional.
  Prompt for new password. If they don't match, try 3 times.

Change-Id: I7420a8b0d9ab018c16b374d8fa2ecb1b24ac6013
"}, {'created': '2012-09-30 04:42:57.000000000', 'message': 'Update password for keystoneclient, securely.

Bug: 938315

If new password is not specified in command line, read from the
prompt.

* keystoneclient/utils.py
  prompt_for_password(): New method to prompt for password.

* keystoneclient/v2_0/shell.py
  do_user_password_update(): Argument --pass is optional.
  Prompt for new password, if it is not specified in
  command line.

Change-Id: I7420a8b0d9ab018c16b374d8fa2ecb1b24ac6013
'}]
commit_message:
Update password for keystoneclient, securely.

Bug: 938315

If new password is not specified in command line, read from the
prompt.

* keystoneclient/utils.py
  prompt_for_password(): New method to prompt for password.

* keystoneclient/v2_0/shell.py
  do_user_password_update(): Argument --pass is optional.
  Prompt for new password, if it is not specified in
  command line.

Change-Id: I7420a8b0d9ab018c16b374d8fa2ecb1b24ac6013

[{'created': '2013-04-26 19:31:08.000000000', 'message': 'Validate password & email during create_user

* Validates if password is not NULL
* Validates if password is not all white spaces
* Checks if Min passwd length = 1 and Max passwd length = 1024
* If email ID is passed, then employs a quicky sanity regex check to
  validate the mail id format. Not a strict parser

Implements bp create-user-validation.
Fixes bug 999084.
